Repeal of former title 22. —

Laws 1973, ch. 251, repealed former title 22 and enacted §§ 22.1-1 to 22.1-426 [§§ 22-1-101 to 22-27-101], constituting a complete recodification of the Wyoming election laws.

Annotations from cases decided under former title 22 and other repealed statutory provisions have been placed under comparable sections within this title.

History of former title. —

The original basic act from which the election laws derived was Laws 1890, ch. 80, §§ 1 to 182, and it covered generally all phases of elections. At the time of the 1945 compilation, almost all of these sections, as amended, were still in effect, although the election laws had been supplemented by a large number of additional independent acts and several sections had been added to Laws 1890, ch. 80, by Laws 1890-91, ch. 68, and Laws 1897, ch. 53.

Between 1945 and the 1957 compilation, the legislature enacted a number of statutes relating to elections. Notable among these were the permanent registration act, Laws 1949, ch. 122, and the two election law revision acts found in Laws 1951, chs. 127 and 139. These statutes repealed many of the sections of the 1945 compilation derived from Laws 1890, ch. 80, amended others, and enacted many new provisions which were incorporated in former title 22. Certain provisions of that title were affected by Laws 1953, ch. 166 and Laws 1957, ch. 120. Laws 1961, ch. 235 completely revised chapters 1 to 6, 9, and 11 to 13 of former title 22, as amended by Laws 1959, chs. 101, 167 and 201. After its revision in 1969, former title 22 was subsequently amended by Laws 1963, chs. 100, 157; 1965, ch. 16; 1967, chs. 14, 38, 118, 222; 1969, ch. 206; 1971, chs. 177, 196, 226, 227, 240, 250; 1971 Sp. Sess., chs. 3, 4.

Constitutionality of former provisions governing minor partyballot access. —

The former provisions of the Wyoming Election Code governing minor party ballot access were unduly burdensome and, hence, unconstitutional. Blomquist v. Thomson, 591 F. Supp. 768, 1984 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 19379 (D. Wyo.), rev'd, 739 F.2d 525, 1984 U.S. App. LEXIS 20277 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1984) (decided under pre-1984 version of former § 22-1-102(g) and prior to enactment of former § 22-4-201 et seq.).

Chapter 1 Wyoming Election Code

  • § 22-1-101.  Citation.
  • § 22-1-102.  Definitions.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

25 Am. Jur. 2d Elections § 1 et seq.

29 C.J.S. Elections § 1 et seq.

§ 22-1-101. Citation.

This act is cited as the Wyoming Election Code of 1973, as amended.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to bond elections see §§ 22-21-101 to 22-21-112.

As to school elections, see §§ 22-22-101 to 22-22-304.

As to municipal elections, see §§ 22-23-101 to 22-23-1007.

As to offenses and penalties in connection with elections, see §§ 22-26-101 to 22-26-121.

As to suffrage and elections generally, see art. 6, §§ 1 to 22, Wyoming Const.

As to election of legislators, see art. 3, § 5, Wyoming Const.

For provisions requiring special election in cities and towns on question of acquisition of public utility plants, etc., by condemnation, etc., see § 1-26-808.

As to liability of radio and television stations for libel and slander in regard to statements made by political candidates, see § 1-29-102.

As to election of coroner, see § 7-4-101.

As to election on formation of conservation districts, see § 11-16-110.

As to special election with reference to formation of new county, see § 18-1-306 et seq.

As to election for establishment of county building fund, see § 18-4-201.

As to election with reference to county viaduct and subway bonds, see § 18-4-503 et seq.

As to election for establishment of county zoning district, see § 18-5-104.

As to elections in cities and towns with reference to relocation of state highways, see § 24-7-101.

As to election on question of establishment of hospital district, see § 35-2-401.

As to procedure for initial election of trustees of hospital districts, see § 35-2-404.

As to election of trustees after organization of sanitary and improvement district, see § 35-3-103.

For duty of county commissioners to hold election of board of directors or fire protection districts, see § 35-9-202.

As to election on dissolution of irrigation district, see §§ 41-7-1002, 41-7-1003.

As to election of drainage district commissioners, see § 41-9-116 et seq.

As to election upon dissolution of drainage districts, §§ 41-9-601 to 41-9-603.

Law reviews. —

For article, "Wyoming Election Law: Proposals for Reform”,see 12 Wyo. L. Rev. 29 (2012).

§ 22-1-102. Definitions.

  1. The definitions contained in this chapter apply to words and phrases used in this Election Code and govern the construction of those words and phrases unless they are specifically modified by the context in which they appear. As used in this Election Code:
    1. “Automatic tabulating equipment” means apparatus that automatically examines and counts votes recorded on paper ballots or ballot cards and tabulates the results;
    2. “Ballot” means the cardboard, paper or other material upon which a voter marks his votes;
    3. “Ballot card” means a ballot that can be counted using automatic tabulating equipment;
    4. Repealed by Laws 2014, ch. 108, §  2.
    5. “Ballot proposition” is any question or measure submitted to a vote of the people of the state, a subdivision thereof, county, district, city or town, and includes a constitutional amendment, initiative, referendum, bond measure, or any other question or measure required to be approved by a vote of the people;
    6. “Bond” means any bond, note, certificate of indebtedness, coupon, or other obligation for the payment of money, issued by any political subdivision, including any bond payable from taxes, revenues or other sources;
    7. “Candidate’s campaign committee” means every group of two (2) or more persons who join together for the purpose of raising, collecting or expending money to be used in the aid of the election of a specific candidate for public office. If more than one (1) committee forms to support the candidate, the candidate shall designate which committee shall be his or her principal campaign committee;
    8. “Chief judge” means the person selected to be responsible for the security of ballot envelopes and voter ballots. The chief judge shall serve as the primary contact at the polls to the county clerk;
    9. “City clerk” means a clerk of a municipality;
    10. “Convention” is an organized assemblage of electors or delegates representing a political party;
    11. “Counting center” is the location or locations designated by the county clerk for the automatic tabulating and counting of ballots;
    12. “County chairman” means the county chairman of a political party or the state chairman if the party has no chairman for the particular county;
    13. “Election,” when used without qualifying adjectives, means all elections participated in by the voters of a city, town, county, district or the state;
    14. “Electronic voting system” is a system employing an electronic voting device in conjunction with paper ballots or ballot cards, or other system of secret voting and automatic tabulating equipment for the recording, tabulating and counting of votes in an election;
    15. “Envelope” means any type of container used to contain or hold election documents;
    16. “Independent candidate” is a person who is running for nomination or election to a public office but who does not represent a political party;
    17. “Major political party” means a political organization whose candidate for any one (1) of the offices of the United States house of representatives, governor or secretary of state, received not less than ten percent (10%) of the total votes cast for that office in the most recent general election;
    18. “Minor political party” means a political organization whose candidate for any one (1) of the offices of the United States house of representatives, governor or secretary of state, received not less than two percent (2%) nor more than ten percent (10%) of the total votes cast for that office in the most recent general election;
    19. “Municipality” includes a first class city as defined by W.S. 15-1-101(a)(iv) and a town as defined by W.S. 15-1-101(a)(xiv);
    20. “Political action committee” means any group of two (2) or more persons organized and associated for the purpose of raising, collecting or spending money for use in the aid of, or otherwise influencing or attempting to influence, directly or indirectly, the election or defeat of candidates for public office, candidate’s committees, or political parties, for support of or opposition to any initiative or referendum petition drive or for the adoption or defeat of any ballot proposition;
    21. “Political subdivision” includes any county, city, town, school district, community college district, hospital district, water conservancy district, cemetery district, fire protection district, or any other political subdivision of the state constituting a body corporate, whether incorporated under general act, special charter, or otherwise;
    22. “Pollbook” means a book, or hardware, software or any combination thereof commonly referred to as an electronic pollbook, used in a polling place on election day containing information specified by law;
    23. “Poll list” is the list of registered voters as compiled by the clerk for use by election judges at the polls. The poll list shall:
      1. Include the names and residence addresses of electors registered in the precinct;
      2. Indicate the precinct and various districts in which each elector resides;
      3. Indicate political party affiliation of the electors, if any;
      4. Indicate which electors have registered by mail and must show identification;
      5. Indicate which electors have submitted absentee ballots in the election prior to the printing of the poll list;
      6. Provide for the notation of:
        1. A sequential number for each elector voting at the polls;
        2. Electors who cast provisional ballots;
        3. Electors who cast absentee ballots if the absentee ballots are processed and counted at the polls;
        4. Electors who change political party affiliation at the polls.
      7. Provide for the recording of the same information for electors who register at the polls;
      8. Provide other space as required for election management purposes.
    24. “Poll watcher” means a person certified by the county chairman of a political party to observe voter turn out and registration. A “poll watcher” is not an election official;
    25. “Provisional party” means a political organization which has filed a legally valid petition as provided under article 4 of chapter 4 of this code. The filing of a legally valid petition entitles the provisional party to participate in the next general election. If the provisional party’s candidate for any one (1) of the offices of the United States house of representatives, governor or secretary of state, receives not less than two percent (2%) of the total votes cast for that office in that election, the provisional party does not lose party status;
    26. “Qualified elector” includes every citizen of the United States who is a bona fide resident of Wyoming, has registered to vote and will be at least eighteen (18) years of age on the day of the election at which he may offer to vote. No person is a qualified elector who is a currently adjudicated mentally incompetent person, or who has been convicted of a felony and his civil or voting rights have not been restored. A literacy test shall not be imposed as a condition to voting in any election;
    27. “Registration” is the entry and verification of the name and voter information of a qualified elector on the official registry list, as provided in W.S. 22-3-104(f) and 22-3-108;
    28. “Registry agent” is a county clerk, his deputies, a tribal clerk, his deputies, a city clerk, his deputies, and an election judge during any election specified in W.S. 22-2-101(a)(i) through (viii);
    29. “Registry list” is the list by precinct of the names, addresses, party affiliations and precinct and district numbers of the registered electors in the county prepared by the secretary of state or county clerks for distribution as provided in W.S. 22-2-113;
    30. “Residence” is the place of a person’s actual habitation. The construction of this term shall be governed by the following rules:
      1. Residence is the place where a person has a current habitation and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning;
      2. A person shall not gain or lose residence merely by reason of his presence or absence while:
        1. Employed in the service of the United States or of this state; or
        2. A student at an institution of learning; or
        3. Kept at a hospital or other institution; or
        4. Stationed at or residing on a military reservation or installation or at a transient camp maintained for relief purposes by the government of the United States in this state. No person shall be excluded as a voter solely because of his residence on a federal enclave within the state. This factor shall be considered with all others in the determination of the person’s residence within the state for voting purposes.
      3. A person shall not lose his residence by leaving his home to go to another state, another district of this state, or to another country for temporary purposes, with the intent of returning, if he has not registered in the other state, district or country;
      4. A person shall not gain residence in a county if he enters it without the intent of making it his current actual residence;
      5. If a person removes to another state with the intent of making it his residence, he loses his residence in Wyoming; except that in a general election year, if his registration is valid in Wyoming when he leaves this state and he is unable to qualify under the laws of his new state of residence to vote at the primary or general election, he shall be deemed to have retained residence in Wyoming for purposes of voting by absentee ballot in the primary or general election;
      6. A person who takes up or continues his abode at a place other than where his family resides, shall be a resident of the place where he actually abides;
      7. Candidates seeking election to the office of United States senator or representative in congress shall not, at the time of knowingly seeking nomination or election as provided by paragraph (liii) of this subsection, claim or currently be claiming any residence or receive the benefits of residency from any other state, excluding the benefits of residency related to or incidental from maintaining a residence at or near the United States capital.
    31. “Square” for purposes of chapter 6 of this code shall include a box or oval used to designate the area for casting a vote;
    32. “Tally sheet” means the document used to tabulate hand counted paper ballots;
    33. Repealed by Laws 2018, ch. 118, §  2;
    34. “Voting device” means:
      1. Repealed by Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 2.
      2. A device for marking the ballots with ink or another substance; or
      3. Any other method for recording votes on ballots so that the ballot may be tabulated by means of automatic tabulating equipment.
    35. “Write-in vote” is a vote cast for a person whose name does not otherwise appear on the official ballot as a candidate for the office for which his name is written in by the voter;
    36. “Federal office” means the offices of president and vice-president of the United States, United States senator and representative in congress;
    37. “Immediate family” means a spouse, parent, sibling, child or other person living in the individual’s household;
    38. “Election assistance” does not include the posting of campaign signs or the availability of campaign materials;
    39. “Acceptable identification” means:
      1. For purposes of voter registration, one (1) of the identification documents or other proof of identity as specified by rule of the secretary of state as adequate proof of the identity of a voter;
      2. For purposes of in person voter identification immediately before voting at a polling place or absentee polling place, any of the following:
        1. A Wyoming driver’s license as defined by W.S. 31-7-102(a)(xxv);
        2. A tribal identification card issued by the governing body of the Eastern Shoshone tribe of Wyoming, the Northern Arapaho tribe of Wyoming or other federally recognized Indian tribe;
        3. A Wyoming identification card issued under W.S. 31-8-101;
        4. A valid United States passport;
        5. A United States military card;
        6. A driver’s license or identification card issued by any state or outlying possession of the United States;
        7. Photo identification issued by the University of Wyoming, a Wyoming community college or a Wyoming public school;
        8. A valid Medicare insurance card. This subdivision is repealed effective December 31, 2029;
        9. A valid Medicaid insurance card. This subdivision is repealed effective December 31, 2029.
    40. “Canvass” means the audit function that culminates in the final certification of official election returns;
    41. “Provisional ballot” means a ballot provided to a voter whose right to register or to vote cannot be determined at the polls or verified at the election office, in order to allow the voter to cast a ballot at the polls which shall be counted only if the ballot is determined to be a valid ballot as provided in this Election Code;
    42. “Recount” is the processing of ballots through the tabulation system for an additional time or times, conducted for the specific purpose of counting votes again in any specific race, based upon the criteria of W.S. 22-16-109 or 22-16-111;
    43. “Retabulation” is the process of running ballots back through the tabulation system for an additional time or times for the express purpose of reconciling the count;
    44. “Tribal clerk” means an official designated by the Eastern Shoshone Tribe and an official designated by the Northern Arapaho Tribe of the Wind River Reservation acting pursuant to a cooperative agreement entered into by a county and the respective tribe pursuant to W.S. 16-1-101, which agreement provides for the official to provide services as a registry agent under the direct supervision and control of the county clerk;
    45. “Print” means to write in letters and reproduce whether on paper or other medium by mechanical, magnetic or electrical process;
    46. “Voter registration system” means the single, uniform, official, interactive, computerized, statewide voter registration system containing the registration information of every legally registered elector in the state;
    47. “Precinct” means an area with established boundaries within a political subdivision used for casting and counting votes;
    48. “Polling place” means the physical location where voters cast their ballots on election day;
    49. “Vote center” means a polling place at which any registered elector in the political subdivision holding the election may vote, regardless of the precinct in which he resides, connected through secure internet connections to provide voting information to and receive voting information from the electronic pollbook maintained by the county clerk and used as an option to traditional polling places at the discretion of the county clerk;
    50. “Overvote” means a vote placed on a ballot question in excess of the allowable votes for that ballot question;
    51. “Undervote” means a vote that could have been made on a ballot question but which was not made on that ballot question;
    52. “Unsuccessful candidate” means a person who did not win the election but whose name was printed on the ballot and who received one (1) or more votes in the primary election.
    53. “Candidate” means any person who knowingly seeks nomination or election to public office by:
      1. Filing an application for nomination by primary election, nomination by political party convention or by petition for nomination;
      2. Write-in, except that this subparagraph shall not apply to a person elected to public office by write-in at a general or special election who did not seek or campaign for election to the office;
      3. Forming a campaign committee; or
      4. Receiving contributions or making expenditures, or giving consent for any individual to receive contributions or make expenditures, in order to secure nomination or election to public office.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-2; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1984, ch. 40, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2000, ch. 66, § 1; 2001, ch. 19, § 1; ch. 116, § 1; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2; 2003, ch. 80, § 1; ch. 132, § 1; 2004, ch. 94, § 2; 2005, ch. 110, § 1; 2008, ch. 115, § 2; 2013 ch. 31, § 1, effective July 1, 2013; 2014 ch. 108, §§ 1, 2, effective March 10, 2014; 2015 ch. 76, § 1, effective July 1, 2015; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015; 2018 ch. 118, §§ 1, 2, effective March 14, 2018; 2021 ch. 114, § 1, effective July 1, 2021; 2021 ch. 167, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2004 amendment, in (a)(ii), substituted “marks” for “records,” and deleted “and includes ballot cards, paper ballots, and ballot labels” at the end of the paragraph; in (a)(xiv), substituted “employing an electronic voting” for “employing a voting,” and inserted “or other system of secret voting” following “paper ballots or ballot cards”; in (xli) inserted “register or to” following “a voter whose right to,” and substituted “cast a ballot at the polls which shall be counted only if the ballot is determined to be a valid ballot as provided in this Election Code” for “vote”; added (a)(xlv); and made stylistic changes.

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2004.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, rewrote (a)(xxiii), clarifying the definition of “poll list”; in (a)(xvii), substituted “entry and verification of the name and voter information” for “entry of the name”; in (a)(xxix), substituted “the names, addresses, party affiliations and precinct and district numbers of the registered electors” for “electors,” and substituted “secretary of state or county clerks for distribution as provided in W.S. 22-2-113” for “county clerks”; and added (a)(xlvi).

The 2008 amendment, repealed (a)(xxxiv)(A) which defined “voting device.”

Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, substituted “or” for “circle,” and deleted “arrow or other distinctive area” following “oval” in (a)(xxxi).

The 2014 amendment, repealed former (a)(iv), which read: ““Ballot label” means the cards, papers, booklet, pages, or other materials that contain the names of offices and candidates and statements of ballot propositions to be voted on and which are used in conjunction with ballot cards”; and in (a)(xiv), deleted “ballot labels.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2015 amendments. — The first 2015 amendment, by ch. 76 § 1, effective July 1, 2015, added (a)(xlvii).

The second 2015 amendment, by ch. 138 § 1, effective Mar. 4, 2015, rewrote (a)(xxii), which formerly read: “`Pollbook' is a book used in a precinct on election day containing oaths of election officials, tally sheets, the poll list, and other information specified by law”; and added (a)(xlvii) through (a)(xlix).

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

The 2018 amendments. — The first 2018 amendment, by ch. 118, § 1, added (a)(liii).

The second 2018 amendment, by ch. 118, § 2, repealed former (a)(xxxiii), which read: "Valid write-in candidate" means a candidate who has qualified as a write-in candidate by following the procedures and requirements of W.S. 22-5-501.

Laws 2018, ch. 118, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 14, 2018.

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

The 2021 amendments. —

The first 2021 amendment, by ch. 114, § 1, effective July 1, 2021, in (a)(xxxix), added the (a)(xxxix)(A) designation, "For purposes of voter registration," at the beginning; added (a)(xxxix)(B); and made related changes.

The second 2021 amendment, by ch. 167, § 1, effective July 1, 2021, added (a)(xxx)(G).

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Candidate's failure to be registered. —

Candidate's failure to be registered to vote at the time of filing her application for nomination was inconsequential and a mere irregularity since shortly thereafter she reregistered and met all criteria during the primary election, the general election, and at the time she assumed the municipal office. Rue v. Carter, 919 P.2d 633, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 110 (Wyo. 1996).

Municipal candidacy requires dwelling or place of habitation within municipal boundaries. —

One may not be a candidate for municipal office in a city or town without having and maintaining a dwelling or place of habitation physically situated within the municipal boundaries of such city or town. Karn v. Hayes, 530 P.2d 156, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 121 (Wyo. 1975).

Thus, where there was no showing that appellant had a place of fixed habitation within the corporate limits of the city to which she had the intention of returning, she had not brought herself within the statutory qualifications to stand for election in that city. Karn v. Hayes, 530 P.2d 156, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 121 (Wyo. 1975).

Candidate convicted of felony in another state unqualified to run for county commissioner. —

The district court correctly ruled that a candidate, who had been convicted of a felony in another state and who had not had his rights restored in Wyoming, was unqualified to run for county commissioner. The fact that Wyoming might have treated the candidate's conviction as a misdemeanor had it occurred here, and that the candidate did not lose his civil rights in the state of conviction, did not alter this outcome. However, the court erred in issuing a writ of mandamus directing the holding of a special election, as a judgment annulling the election in which the unqualified candidate's name appeared on the ballot was the appropriate remedy. Mills v. Campbell County Canvassing Bd., 707 P.2d 747, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 588 (Wyo. 1985).

Quoted in

Murphy v. State Canvassing Bd., 12 P.3d 677, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 205 (Wyo. 2000); Woodruff v. Wyoming, — F.3d —, 2002 U.S. App. LEXIS 21060 (10th Cir. Oct. 7, 2002).

Chapter 2 General Provisions

  • § 22-2-105.  Terms of office and offices voted on at general elections.
  • § 22-2-106.  Election of presidential and vice-presidential electors.
  • § 22-2-107.  When elected state and county officers assume offices.
  • § 22-2-108.  Secretary of state to certify officers to be elected.
  • § 22-2-109.  County clerk to publish proclamation.
  • § 22-2-110.  Computing periods of time.
  • § 22-2-111.  Employees time off to vote.
  • § 22-2-112.  Hours of county clerk's office on election day.

  • § 22-2-115.  [Renumbered.]

  • § 22-2-118.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-2-119.  Qualified elector may vote; acceptable identification requirement; provisional ballots.

  • § 22-2-121.  Chief election officer to prepare forms; rules; advice.
  • § 22-2-122.  State and federal share of qualified election expenses; election readiness account.

§ 22-2-101. Applicability and construction of Election Code generally.

  1. Chapters 1 through 28 of this Election Code apply to the following elections:
    1. General elections;
    2. Primary elections;
    3. Special elections to fill vacancies in the office of representative in congress;
    4. County elections;
    5. Municipal elections;
    6. School and community college elections;
    7. Bond, mill levy and political subdivision tax elections;
    8. Any special election;
    9. Election of supervisors of a soil conservation district in a county whose board of county commissioners has, on or before May 1 of any year, adopted a resolution to make this Election Code apply;
    10. Elections held under chapter 29 of this title if:
      1. The special district principal act is silent on the matter; and
      2. Chapter 29 of this title and rules promulgated pursuant to that chapter are silent on the matter.
  2. This Election Code shall be construed so that all legally qualified electors may register and vote, that those who are not qualified shall not vote, and that fraud and corruption in elections shall be prevented.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-3; Laws 1980, ch. 19, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1994, ch. 99, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to primary elections, § 22-5-219.

As to special elections to fill vacancies in the office of representative in congress, see §§ 22-18-103 and 22-18-104.

As to bond elections, see §§ 22-21-101 to 22-21-112.

As to school elections, see §§ 22-22-101 to 22-22-304.

As to municipal elections, see §§ 22-23-101 to 22-23-1007.

As to election of supervisors of conservation districts generally, see §§ 11-16-119 and 11-16-120.

Editor's notes. —

Laws 1971, ch. 11, § 1, redesignated soil conservation districts as conservation districts. See §§ 11-16-101 to 11-16-134.

§ 22-2-102. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, related to the applicability of chapters 1 through 28 of the Election Code to special district elections.

§ 22-2-103. Chief election officers.

The secretary of state is the chief election officer for the state and shall maintain uniformity in the applications and operations of the election laws of Wyoming. Each county clerk is the chief election officer for the county.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-5; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2.

Cited in

State ex rel. Willis v. Larson, 539 P.2d 352, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 157 (Wyo. 1975).

§ 22-2-104. Election dates.

  1. A general election shall be held for all the precincts of this state on the Tuesday next following the first Monday in November of each even-numbered year.
  2. A primary election shall be held at the regular polling places for each precinct on the first Tuesday after the third Monday in August in general election years for the nomination of candidates for partisan and nonpartisan offices to be filled at the succeeding general election and for the election of major party precinct committeemen and committeewomen.
  3. A May town election as authorized by W.S. 22-23-202 shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in the month of May every two (2) years.
  4. Every bond election shall be held on the same day as a primary election or a general election, or on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in May or November, or on the first Tuesday after the third Monday in August.
  5. The election of members of the board of trustees of each school district and community college district shall be held for each district on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November in general election years.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-6; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

The 2015 amendment, in (a), substituted “for all the precincts” for “in all the precincts”; in (b), substituted “for each precinct” for “in each precinct”; and in (e), substituted “for each district” for “in each district.”

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

§ 22-2-105. Terms of office and offices voted on at general elections.

  1. The terms of office and offices voted on at general elections are as follows:
    1. Two Year Term. — At every general election there shall be elected the number of representatives in congress to which this state is entitled and members of the Wyoming house of representatives;
    2. Four Year Term. — At the general election in 1974 and in every fourth (4th) year thereafter, there shall be elected the following officers: one (1) governor, one (1) secretary of state, one (1) state treasurer, one (1) state auditor, one (1) superintendent of public instruction, county clerks, county treasurers, county assessors, county coroners, county and prosecuting attorneys, district attorneys, sheriffs, clerks of the district court. At every general election there shall be elected the necessary member or members of the Wyoming senate and county commissioners. The question of retention of a circuit court judge or a magistrate of the circuit court shall be submitted:
      1. For a circuit court judge, to the electorate of all counties within the circuit;
      2. For a magistrate required by law to stand for retention, to the electorate of the county wherein the magistrate serves.
    3. Six Year Term. — At the general election in 1976 and in every sixth year thereafter, there shall be elected one (1) United States senator for the term next ensuing. At the general election in 1978 and every sixth year thereafter there shall be elected one (1) United States senator for the term next ensuing. At each general election the retention of district judges for unexpired balances of or new six (6) year terms shall be submitted to the electorate of the several judicial districts, as necessary;
    4. Eight Year Term. — At every general election to the retention of a justice or justices of the Wyoming supreme court for unexpired balances of or new eight (8) year terms shall be submitted to the electorate of the entire state as necessary.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-7; Laws 1978, ch. 45, § 1; 1979, ch. 133, § 2; 1981 Sp. Sess., ch. 22, § 1; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 2000, ch. 24, § 4; 2001, ch. 10, § 1; 2009, ch. 168, § 201.

Cross references. —

As to when terms of legislators begin, see art. 3, § 5, Wyo. Const.

As to election of governor, see art. 4, § 3, Wyo. Const.

As to the election, qualification and term of state officers generally, see art. 4, § 11, Wyo. Const.

As to number, election and term of supreme court justices, see art. 5, § 4, Wyo. Const.

As to division of state into districts and election and term of district judges, see art. 5, § 19, Wyo. Const.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in (a)(ii), deleted “and justices of the peace” from the end of the first sentence and deleted “In those counties that have established a circuit court” from the beginning of the last sentence; and in (a)(ii)(A), deleted “except for any county which is not a part of the circuit court system” from the end.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Abolition of office. —

An office, even if it be a constitutional one, may be abolished at any time by a new constitution, or by amendment of the existing one. Reals v. Smith, 8 Wyo. 159, 56 P. 690, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1899).

When district judge may be elected. —

A district judge may be elected at any general election where the office will become vacant by the expiration of a term subsequent to such election and prior to the next general election. State ex rel. Burdick v. Schnitger, 17 Wyo. 65, 96 P. 238, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1908).

Election of governor. —

A person elected to fill a vacancy in the office of governor on Tuesday next after the first Monday of November, 1892, was elected at a general election. In re Moore, 4 Wyo. 98, 31 P. 980, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1893).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Residence and Settlement Laws, Their Effect on Elections, Welfare, and the Right of Free Movement,” see 12 Wyo. L.J. 50 (1957).

§ 22-2-106. Election of presidential and vice-presidential electors.

At the general election in 1976 and every fourth year thereafter, there shall be elected the number of electors of president and vice-president of the United States to which the state is entitled.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-8.

Cross references. —

As to presidential and vice-presidential electors, see §§ 22-19-101 to 22-19-109.

§ 22-2-107. When elected state and county officers assume offices.

All state and county officers elected at a general election shall assume their offices on the first Monday in January next following their election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-9.

Officer qualified at election, but not at commencement of term. —

Eligibility to office is a continuing requirement, and an officer who is qualified at the time of the election but who is not qualified at the time of the commencement of his term cannot hold the office. State ex rel. Willis v. Larson, 539 P.2d 352, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 157 (Wyo. 1975).

§ 22-2-108. Secretary of state to certify officers to be elected.

Between the twenty-fourth day of April and the third day of May in each general election year, the secretary of state shall transmit to the county clerk of each county a certified list stating what officers, other than county and precinct officers, are to be nominated or elected at the election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-11; Laws 1990, ch. 42, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2008, ch. 115, § 1.

The 2008 amendment, effective July 1, 2008, substituted “transmit to the county clerk of each county a certified list” for “mail to the county clerk of each county a written certificate.”

Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

§ 22-2-109. County clerk to publish proclamation.

  1. Between one hundred one (101) and ninety-one (91) days before each primary election the county clerk in each county shall publish at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the county and post in the county clerk’s office and at the place where each municipality within the county regularly holds its council meetings a proclamation setting forth the date of the election, the offices to be filled at the election including the terms of the offices, the number of persons required by law to fill the offices, the filing deadline for the offices and the requirements for filing statements of campaign contributions and expenditures. The proclamation shall also include the aforementioned information regarding offices to be filled at the general election and any other pertinent primary election information. In addition, the description of any ballot proposition submitted to the voters of the state, a political subdivision thereof, county or other district shall be included.
  2. Between ninety (90) and seventy (70) days before each general election, the county clerk in each county shall publish at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the county and post in the county clerk’s office and at the place where each municipality within the county regularly holds its council meetings a proclamation setting forth the following:
    1. The date of the election;
    2. For any offices not previously included in the proclamation published pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, the offices to be filled at the election including the terms of the offices and the number of persons required by law to fill the offices;
    3. The requirements for filing statements of campaign contributions and expenditures not previously included in the proclamation published pursuant to subsection (a) of this section;
    4. Any other pertinent general election information;
    5. The legislative description of each proposed constitutional amendment or other ballot proposition submitted to the voters of the state, a political subdivision thereof, county or other district.
  3. Minor errors in any proclamation shall not invalidate the forthcoming election.

History.

Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2015 ch. 76, § 1, effective July 1, 2015; 2018 ch. 101, § 1, effective March 14, 2018.

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, substituted “campaign contributions” for “campaign receipts” near the end of the first sentence in (a) and (b).

The 2018 amendment, redesignated the existing language of (b) as the present introductory language and (b)(i) through (b)(v); in the introductory language, substituted “Between ninety (90) and seventy (70) days” for “Between forty-five (45) and thirty-five (35) days”; in (b)(ii), added “For any offices not previously included in the proclamation published pursuant to subsection (a) of this section”; in (b)(iii), substituted “not previously included in the proclamation published pursuant to subsection (a) of this section” for “and” at the end; in (b)(iv), deleted “In addition” at the end; in (b)(v), deleted “shall be included” at the end; and made related changes.

Laws 2018, ch. 101, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 14, 2018.

Stated in

Populist Party v. Herschler, 746 F.2d 656, 1984 U.S. App. LEXIS 17718 (10th Cir. 1984).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

What is “public place” within requirement as to posting of election notices, 90 ALR2d 1210.

§ 22-2-110. Computing periods of time.

  1. Except for special elections to fill vacancies for a congressman under W.S. 22-18-105 through 22-18-109, periods of time are computed by excluding the specific day and counting the prescribed number of days, including Saturdays, Sundays and full legal holidays. If the first day of a time period falls on a Saturday, Sunday or full legal holiday, the preceding day which is not a Saturday, Sunday or full legal holiday shall be used. If the last day of a time period falls on a Saturday, Sunday or full legal holiday, the next day which is not a Saturday, Sunday or full legal holiday shall be used. All days, except the specific day, but including the last day, shall be used to compute the time limits established under W.S. 22-18-105 through 22-18-109 unless the last day of a time period falls on a Saturday, Sunday or full legal holiday in which case the next day which is not a Saturday, Sunday or full legal holiday shall be used.
  2. When used to compute periods of time:
    1. “Not later than” is computed by counting the prescribed number of days;
    2. “Not less than” is computed by counting the prescribed number of days and adding one (1) additional day to the computed time.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-13; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 47, § 1; 2015 ch. 8, § 1, effective February 25, 2015.

The 2015 amendment, added the first and last sentence in (a).

§ 22-2-111. Employees time off to vote.

  1. Any person entitled to vote at any primary or general election or special election to fill a vacancy in the office of representatives in the congress of the United States is, on the day of such election, entitled to absent himself from any service or employment in which he is then engaged or employed for a period of one (1) hour, other than meal hours, the hour being at the convenience of the employer, between the time of opening and closing of the polls. Such elector shall not, because of so absenting himself, lose any pay, providing he actually casts his legal vote.
  2. This section shall not apply to an employee who has three (3) or more consecutive nonworking hours during the time the polls are open.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-14; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-2-112. Hours of county clerk's office on election day.

The office of county clerk shall remain open for election business on election day during normal hours of election operations. With prior notice to the public the office of county clerk may be closed to all nonelection business except the recording of documents.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-15; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

§ 22-2-113. Availability and form of registry lists; use of copies; election record; purging.

  1. The secretary of state shall furnish at a reasonable price registry lists to any candidate for a political office in the state, candidate’s campaign committee, political party central committees and officials thereof, elected officials, political action committees, individuals promoting or opposing a ballot issue or candidate and to organizations which promote voter participation. The county clerks may elect to furnish the lists and, if they do so, shall make them available to all on an equal basis. All lists are for political purposes only and are not available for commercial use. The lists may be in the form of printouts, mailing labels or other electronic format as available. The lists may be reproduced for political purposes.
  2. Repealed by Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 5.
  3. Information copied from campaign contribution and expenditure reports filed by state and local candidates may be used for political purposes but shall not be used for commercial purposes.
  4. Unless otherwise specifically stated in this Election Code, all election records of the county clerk are public. The availability and dissemination of such records shall be in accordance with the Wyoming Public Records Act. Election records containing social security numbers, portions of social security numbers, driver’s license numbers, birth dates, telephone numbers, tribal identification card numbers, e-mail addresses and other personally identifiable information other than names, gender, addresses and party affiliations are not public records and shall be kept confidential. When necessary, members of the county or state canvassing boards may access confidential information for purposes of this code but shall maintain its confidentiality.
  5. The county clerks shall purge and update voter registration information on the voter registration system not later than the fifteenth day of February each year and shall notify the secretary of state upon completion, but not later than February 15 of each year.

History.

Laws 1977, ch. 186, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-15.1; Laws 1991, ch. 243, §§ 2, 5; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2004, ch. 94, § 2; 2005, ch. 110, § 1; 2009, ch. 100, § 2; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014; 2015 ch. 76, § 1, effective July 1, 2015.

The 2004 amendment rewrote (d), which formerly read: “Unless otherwise specifically stated in this Election Code, all election records of the county clerk are public. The availability and dissemination of such records shall be in accordance with the Wyoming Public Records Act. Election records containing social security numbers are not public records if all other information contained in the record is otherwise available for public inspection.”

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2004.

The 2005 amendments. —

The first 2005 amendment, by ch. 110, § 1, effective July 1, 2005, in (a), substituted “registry” for “computerized voter registration”; and in (e), deleted “and submit” after “purge,” substituted “information on the voter registration system” for “lists,” and deleted “to the secretary of state” at the end.

The second 2005 amendment, by ch. 130, § 1, effective July 1, 2005, in (d) inserted “tribal identification card numbers.”

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, deleted “state generated unique voter identification numbers,” preceding “birth dates” in the third sentence of (d).

The 2014 amendment , in the next-to-last sentence of (a), substituted “may” for “shall”, and deleted “tapes”; in the third sentence of (d), inserted “e-mail addresses”; and in (e), added “an shall notify the secretary of state upon completion, but not later than February 15 of each year.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, in (c), substituted “campaign contribution” for “campaign receipts.”

Wyoming Public Records Act. —

The Wyoming Public Records Act, referred to in the second sentence in subsection (d), apparently means article 2 of chapter 4 of title 16, i.e., §§ 16-4-201 through 16-4-205.

§ 22-2-114. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, related to the construction of the Election Code.

§ 22-2-115. [Renumbered.]

Renumbered by Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 4.

Cross references. —

As to state bond elections, see § 22-21-201.

§ 22-2-116. Restrictions on holding more than 1 elected public office.

No person may hold an elective public office in any governmental entity which either provides any funding for or receives any funding from another governmental entity in which that person holds elected public office. If a person also is elected to a public office while holding another public office such that this section is applicable, the person shall resign from the public office first held prior to assuming the new office.

History.

Laws 1983, ch. 183, § 1; 1985, ch. 66, § 1.

§ 22-2-117. Vote required for election; ratification.

  1. Partisan and nonpartisan candidates who receive the largest number of votes for each office to be filled at the general election are elected.
  2. Repealed by Laws 2009, ch. 100, § 3, ch. 168, § 202.
  3. With the exception of constitutional amendments and statewide initiatives and referenda, all ballot propositions shall be passed if the majority of those casting ballots on that proposition vote in favor of such proposition.
  4. A proposed amendment to the constitution of the state of Wyoming submitted by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of each of the houses of the state legislature or a proposed new constitution submitted by a constitutional convention shall be placed on the ballot at the next general election and shall be ratified if approved by a majority of the electors voting at the next general election.
  5. If votes in an amount in excess of fifty percent (50%) of those voting in the general election are cast in favor of adoption of an initiated measure, the proposed law shall be enacted, and the secretary of state shall so certify. The act shall become effective ninety (90) days after certification.
  6. If votes in an amount in excess of fifty percent (50%) of those voting in the general election are cast in favor of rejection of an act referred, the act is rejected, and the secretary of state shall so certify. The act rejected by referendum is void thirty (30) days after certification.

History.

Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2009, ch. 100, §§ 2, 3; ch. 168, §§ 201, 202.

The 2009 amendments. —

The first 2009 amendment, by ch. 100, § 2, in (a) deleted “With the exception of justices of the peace,” preceding “partisan”.

The second 2009 amendment by ch. 168, § 201,in (a), deleted “With the exception of justices of the peace,” preceding “partisan,” and by Ch. 168, § 202, repealed (b). While neither of the amendments gave effect to the other, all have been given effect in this section as set out above.

Editor's notes. —

W.S. 5-4-101, referred to in (b), was repealed by Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 2. See now § 5-9-104.

§ 22-2-118. [Repealed.]

History:

Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 1; repealed by 2014 ch. 108, § 2, effective March 10, 2014.

§ 22-2-119. Qualified elector may vote; acceptable identification requirement; provisional ballots.

Except as specifically provided otherwise, a person may vote only if the person is a qualified elector, only in the precinct in which the person resides and, if voting in person, only if the person presents acceptable identification immediately before voting at the polling place or absentee polling place. If a person is unable to present acceptable identification immediately before voting at the polling place or absentee polling place, the person may vote by provisional ballot pursuant to W.S. 22-15-105.

History.

Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 1; 2021 ch. 114, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2021 amendment, effective July 1, 2021, added "; acceptable identification requirement; provisional ballots" in the section heading; substituted "the person" for "he" twice, added "and, if voting in person, only if the person presents acceptable identification immediately before voting at the polling place or absentee polling place. If a person is unable to present acceptable identification immediately before voting at the polling place or absentee polling place, the person may vote by provisional ballot pursuant to W.S. 22-15-105" at the end and made a related change.

§ 22-2-120. Publication of Election Code.

The secretary of state, not later than the first of July in general election years, shall publish the Election Code on the secretary of state’s official website.

History.

Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 1; 2015 ch. 76, § 1, effective July 1, 2015; 2017 ch. 86, § 1, effective July 1, 2017.

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, in the first sentence, inserted “and municipal”; and deleted the former last sentence, which read: “The county clerk shall furnish copies of the Election Code to municipal clerks and election officials.”

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, substituted “publish” for “distribute copies of” and substituted “on the secretary of state’s official website” for “to county and municipal clerks.”

§ 22-2-121. Chief election officer to prepare forms; rules; advice.

  1. In carrying out his responsibilities under title 22, the secretary of state shall prepare:
    1. Written directives and instructions relating to and based on the election laws;
    2. Sample copies of prescribed and suggested forms;
    3. Advice or request from the attorney general’s office advisory opinions on the effect of election laws and their application, operation and interpretation.
  2. The secretary of state shall promulgate such rules as are necessary to maintain uniform voting and vote counting procedures and orderly voting.
  3. The secretary of state shall have the authority to issue a directive to the county election officers necessary to ensure voter registration and elector participation when a uniformed services or emergency personnel elector could not otherwise vote.
  4. The secretary of state is authorized to adopt rules and regulations necessary to comply with the requirements of the Help America Vote Act of 2002, Public Law 107-252, including a state-based administrative complaint procedure, which shall not be subject to the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act.
  5. The secretary of state is authorized to adopt rules and regulations necessary to comply with the requirements of the Military and Overseas Voter Empowerment Act of 2009, P.L. 111-84, and shall have the authority to issue directives to county election officers necessary to ensure compliance with the act. Directives authorized under this subsection may include:
    1. That ballots be available for Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act voters forty-five (45) days prior to the election;
    2. How ballots are to be transmitted electronically;
    3. How returned ballots shall be tabulated; and
    4. What information shall be provided to Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act voters.
  6. The secretary of state shall have the authority to issue directives to county election officers necessary to ensure the proper conduct of elections, including voter registration and elector participation when there is a declared natural disaster or other impending or declared emergency which interferes with an election.
  7. The secretary of state shall adopt rules and regulations that allow for the counting of ballots at a central counting center. The rules shall specify procedures for delivering ballots to the central counting center.

History.

Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 1; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2; 2003, ch. 183, § 1; 2004, ch. 94, § 2; 2010, ch. 57, § 1; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014; 2019 ch. 159, § 1, effective January 1, 2020.

The 2004 amendment, in (c), substituted “uniformed services” for “military”; and in (d) added “which shall not be subject to the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act” at the end of the paragraph.

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2004.

The 2010 amendment, added (e).

Laws 2010, ch. 57, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 8, 2010.

The 2014 amendment, added (f).

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2019 amendment, effective January 1, 2020, added (g).

Editor's notes. —

Public Law 107-252 is generally codified at 42 U.S.C. § 15301 et seq.

Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. —

See § 16-3-101(a), (b)(xi).

§ 22-2-122. State and federal share of qualified election expenses; election readiness account.

  1. There is created the election readiness account. The account shall consist of federal funds received by the state of Wyoming from the federal election assistance commission’s 2018 Help America Vote Act (HAVA) election security fund and any state appropriations authorized by the legislature. Funds in the account shall be subject to appropriation. Notwithstanding W.S. 9-2-1008 and 9-4-207, earnings from the funds in the account shall be credited to the account and shall not lapse at the end of any fiscal period.
  2. Funds in the account shall only be used for replacement and maintenance of voting systems and other ongoing election costs as allowed by the Help America Vote Act (HAVA). Disbursements and expenditures from the account shall be made at the discretion of the secretary of state in consultation with the county clerks.
  3. Commencing in 2019, and annually thereafter, the secretary of state shall document disbursements and expenditures from the account. No later than November 15 of each year, the secretary of state shall report any disbursements and expenditures from the account to the joint appropriations committee, the joint corporations, elections and political subdivisions interim committee and the governor.

History.

2019 ch. 9, § 1, effective February 14, 2019.

Effective date. — Laws 2019, ch. 9, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved February 14, 2019.

Cross references. —

As to registration, see art. 6, § 12, Wyo. Const.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

25 Am. Jur. 2d Elections §§ 178 to 194.

State voting rights of residents of military establishments, 34 ALR2d 1193.

Right of married women to use maiden surname, 67 ALR3d 1266.

Voting rights of persons mentally incapacitated, 80 ALR3d 1116.

Validity of college or university regulation of political or voter registration activity in student housing facilities, 39 ALR4th 1137.

Validity, construction and application of 42 U.S.C. § 1973i(c) making it federal offense with respect to federal elections to give false information in registering or voting or to pay or accept payment for registering or voting, 23 ALR Fed 463.

29 C.J.S. Elections §§ 47 to 72.

§ 22-3-101. When required; prior registration in effect.

  1. Registration is required before a person may vote.
    1. through (iii) Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.
  2. Any voter legally registered prior to May 25, 1973, is considered registered under the Election Code enacted in 1973.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-17; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, §§ 2, 5.

Cross references. —

For constitutional provision as to registration of voters, see art. 6, § 12, Wyo. Const.

§ 22-3-102. Qualifications; temporary registration.

  1. A person may register to vote not less than fourteen (14) days before an election, at any election specified in W.S. 22-2-101(a)(i) through (viii) or as provided by W.S. 22-3-117, who satisfies the following qualifications:
    1. He is a citizen of the United States;
    2. He will be at least eighteen (18) years of age on the day of the next general election provided he shall not be permitted to vote until he has attained the age of eighteen (18);
    3. He is a bona fide resident of Wyoming as determined in accordance with W.S. 22-1-102(a)(xxx);
    4. He is not currently adjudicated mentally incompetent;
    5. He has not been convicted of a felony, or if convicted has had his civil or voting rights restored.
  2. Repealed by Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 4.
  3. Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.
  4. An absent uniformed services or an overseas citizen voter who is qualified to register by mail, to request an absentee ballot, and to vote in Wyoming is entitled to register by mail annually using the Federal Postcard Application for the purpose of voting in any election during the calendar year for which the voter registered. The voter’s name shall not appear on the permanent official registry list until the voter has registered as provided in W.S. 22-3-103 and 22-3-104.
  5. The secretary of state is authorized to provide for the verification of certain voter registration data in accordance with the following:
    1. The secretary of state and the director of the department of transportation shall enter into an agreement to match voter registration data with information maintained by the department regarding driver’s licenses, in order to verify the information provided on applications for voter registration;
    2. The secretary of state and the attorney general shall enter into an agreement to compare data in the voter registration system with information maintained by the division of criminal investigation regarding state felony convictions in order to deny voter registration to, and remove from voter registration lists, individuals who are not qualified electors;
    3. The secretary of state and the director of the department of health shall enter into an agreement to match information in the voter registration system with death records in the office of vital records services within the department of health in order to remove names of deceased individuals from voter registration lists;
    4. The secretary of state, the state board of parole and the department of corrections shall enter into an agreement to match information in the voter registration system with records regarding restoration of voting rights maintained by the state board of parole or the department of corrections in order to verify voter qualifications;
    5. The secretary of state and the supreme court shall enter into an agreement to match information in the voter registration system with other records in order to generate jury lists.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-18; 1993, ch. 172, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, §§ 2, 5; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2; 2003, ch. 132, § 1; 2004, ch. 94, §§ 2, 4; 2009, ch. 100, § 2, ch. 139, § 1; 2013 ch. 28, § 1, effective July 1, 2013; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014; 2015 ch. 163, § 1, effective January 1, 2016; 2020 ch. 100, § 1, effective July 1, 2020.

Cross references. —

As to qualifications of electors, see art. 6, § 2, Wyo. Const.

As to when residence not lost by reason of absence, see art. 6, § 7, Wyo. Const.

The 2004 amendment repealed former (b), pertaining to absentee ballots, and added (d) and (e).

The 2009 amendments. —

The first 2009 amendment, by ch. 100, § 2, effective July 1, 2009, in (a)(ii) inserted “general” preceding “election” and added “provided he shall not be permitted to vote until he has attained the age of eighteen (18)” thereafter, and added (e)(v).

The second 2009 amendment, by ch. 139, § 1, effective July 1, 2009, inserted “and effective January 1, 2011 fourteen (14) days” preceding “before an election” in (a).

While neither of the amendments gave effect to the other, all have been given effect in this section as set out above.

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, in (a) deleted “thirty (30) days, and effective January 1, 2011” following “not less than;” and in (d) deleted “or as many as the next two (2) federal election cycles” following “one (1) election”, and substituted “election” for “elections” following “special federal,” and made stylistic changes.

The 2014 amendment, in the first sentence of (d), inserted “cycle,” and deleted “but thereafter the voter's name shall be removed from the temporary registration list which shall be maintained as a segregated part of the voter registration list.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2015 amendment. effective January 1, 2016, in (e)(iv), substituted “state, the state board” for “state and the state board”, inserted “and the department of corrections” and inserted “or the department of corrections”.

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (d) substituted “by mail annually using” for “by mail using” and “voting in any election during the calendar year for which the voter registered” for “voting in one (1) election cycle, including a primary, general or special federal election.”

Cited in

Cloud v. State, 2014 WY 113, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 130 (Sept. 10, 2014).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Residence or domicile of teacher for purpose of voting, 98 ALR2d 488; 44 ALR3d 797.

Residence of students for voting purposes, 44 ALR3d 797.

§ 22-3-103. Furnishing of oath forms; contents thereof.

  1. The county clerk shall furnish voter registration oath forms to registry agents which forms shall require the following voter information from the applicant:
    1. His full legal name;
    2. His current residence address or if living temporarily in another state or nation, his last residence address in Wyoming;
    3. His postal address if different from his residence address;
    4. His date of birth;
    5. Acceptable identification as defined pursuant to W.S. 22-1-102(a)(xxxix);
    6. Either:
      1. The applicant’s Wyoming driver’s license number, or if the applicant has no current, valid Wyoming driver’s license, a statement to that effect and the last four (4) digits of the applicant’s social security number, or if the applicant has neither, a statement to that effect; or
      2. A tribal identification card issued by the governing body of the Eastern Shoshone tribe of Wyoming, the Northern Arapaho tribe of Wyoming or other federally recognized Indian tribe that contains the applicant’s Wyoming driver’s license number, if the applicant has a Wyoming driver’s license, and the last four (4) digits of the applicant’s social security number.
    7. His political party affiliation, if any.
    8. Repealed by Laws 2010, ch. 3, § 3.
  2. Following the provision of the information required in subsection (a) of this section, the form shall require the applicant’s signature in full below the following oath:
  3. Persons in the uniformed services and overseas citizens, as specified in W.S. 22-3-117, shall swear or affirm to the oath under the penalty of perjury. The oath does not require the signature of an oath-taking officer.

I, , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I am a citizen of the United States; that I am a bona fide resident of the state of Wyoming and this county; that if registered in another county or state, I hereby request that my registration be withdrawn; that I will be at least eighteen (18) years of age on or before the next election; that I am not currently adjudicated a mentally incompetent person, that I have not been convicted of a felony, or if I have been convicted of a felony, I have had my civil or voting rights restored by a competent authority; and that the voter registration information contained herein is true and accurate to my best knowledge and belief. (Signature in full of applicant) Subscribed and affirmed or sworn to before me by this day of , (year). (Signature and title of registry agent or person authorized to administer oaths)

Click to view

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-19; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1985, ch. 143, § 1; ch. 204, § 1; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2003, ch. 132, § 1; 2004, ch. 94, § 2; 2005, ch. 110, § 1; 2008, ch. 115, § 1; 2010, ch. 3, §§ 2, 3; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014; 2015 ch. 76, § 1, effective July 1, 2015; 2020 ch. 56, § 1, effective March 12, 2020.

The 2004 amendment, in (a), substituted “political party and the number of my current, valid Wyoming driver's license is . . . . . , or I have no valid Wyoming driver's license and the last four digits of my social security number are . . . . . , or I have no valid Wyoming driver's license or social security number” for “political party and my social security number (optional) is . . . . . ”; and in (b) substituted “uniformed services” for “military.”

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2004.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, rewrote the section, specifying the information required of the registrant in (a); and simplifying the form and recasting it as (b).

The 2008 amendment, inserted “legal” in (a)(i).

Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

The 2010 amendment, effective July 1, 2010, repealed former (a)(viii) which read: “The date he became a resident of the county.” and made a related change.

The 2020 amendment, added the introductory language of (a)(vi); designated former (a)(vi) as (a)(vi)(A), substituted “The applicant’s” for “His,” “if the applicant” for “if he” twice, “four (4) digits of the applicant’s social” for “four 4) digits of his social,” and made a related change; and added (a)(vi)(B).

Laws 2020, ch. 56, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 11, 2020.

The 2014 amendment, in the form in (b), inserted “if registered in another county or state, I hereby request that my registration be withdrawn; that,” and deleted “that I am not . . . . . now registered in another county or state.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, in the first sentence in (c), substituted “shall swear” for “may swear.”

Editor's notes. —

Former subsection (b) has been redesignated as subsection (c) at the direction of the legislative service office.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity of governmental requirement of oath as applied to voters, 18 ALR2d 268.

§ 22-3-104. Methods of verification; signing oath; time for proving eligibility; registration locations.

  1. and (b) Repealed by Laws 2004, ch. 94 § 4.
  2. Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.
  3. An applicant may only register to vote  in person or by mail at which time he shall provide the information  required by W.S. 22-3-103(a) and sign the registration oath as required by W.S. 22-3-103(b).
    1. through (iii) Repealed  by Laws 2005, ch. 110, § 2.
  4. Repealed by Laws 2005, ch. 110, § 2.
  5. A person shall be registered to vote as  follows:
    1. Repealed by Laws 2014, ch. 108, §  2.
    2. Registration is effective:
      1. At the polls for the purpose of voting.  Upon verification of the information, the voter shall continue to  be registered. Upon failure of verification, the voter’s registration  shall be revoked in accordance with W.S. 22-3-105;
      2. For registration, other than at the polls,  after the voter registration information has been entered onto the  voter registration system and verified.
  6. On election day, applicants attempting  to register who lack the proof required under this section shall be  offered provisional ballots in accordance with W.S. 22-15-105 and permitted until the close of business on the day  following the election to present documentation to the county clerk  establishing their eligibility to register and to vote in the precinct.
  7. An applicant may register to vote in person:
    1. In his proper polling place at any election  specified in W.S. 22-2-101(a)(i) through (viii); or
    2. In the office of the county clerk or city  clerk in the principal office building of the county or city in the  presence of the registry agent.
  8. A county or city clerk may establish and  maintain registration facilities in a public area owned or occupied  by a political subdivision or governmental institution, agency or  entity, after giving not less than two (2) days notice by publication  in a newspaper of general circulation in the county and by posting  such notice in such clerk’s office. The requirements of subsection  (h) of this section regarding the place of registration shall not  apply to a person registering in accordance with this subsection.

History:

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-20; 1993, ch. 172, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, §§ 2, 5; 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2; 2004, ch. 94, §§ 2, 4; 2005, ch. 110, §§ 1, 2; 2008, ch. 115, § 1; 2014 ch. 108, §§ 1, 2, effective March 10, 2014.

The 2004 amendment, by ch. 94, §§ 2 and 4, repealed former (a) and (b), pertaining to signing, subscribing and delivering the registration oath, added (d) through (h), redesignated former (d) as (j), and made stylistic changes.

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2004.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, rewrote (d), deleting the specific registration requirements and instead referring the registrant to W.S. 23-3-103, and rewrote (f), modifying duties of election officials; and repealed former (e), which provided that any person authorized to administer oaths would be considered a registry agent for the purposes of registering by mail.

The 2008 amendment, in the first sentence of (j), substituted “area” for “building”, deleted “and on the front door of such public building” at the end.

Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

The 2014 amendment, repealed former (f)(i) which read: “Registration before the secretary of state has certified that the voter registration system is operational is effective upon receipt and acceptance by the county clerk or election judge of the completed and signed registration oath subscribed by the registry agent or by a person authorized to administer oaths if the voter is registering by mail”; and in (f)(ii), deleted “after the secretary of state has certified that the voter registration system is operational.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 10, 2014.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (i) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

For article, "Wyoming Election Law: Proposals for Reform”, see12 Wyo. L. Rev. 29 (2012).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

What is “public place” within requirement of posting of election notices, 90 ALR2d 1210.

§ 22-3-105. Investigation of voter qualifications; striking names from registry; criteria; notice; appeal.

  1. The county clerk may investigate the qualifications of any voter registration, when he has reasonable cause to believe that the voter may be unqualified. The county clerk shall, after a thorough investigation, strike from the voter registration lists the name of any person who is not qualified to be registered.
  2. Among the criteria the county clerk may use in determining the qualifications of any person to be registered are the following:
    1. Location of dwelling of registrant and family;
    2. Occupation and location of employment;
    3. Location of vehicle registration;
    4. Wyoming driver’s license or tribal identification card that meets the requirements of W.S. 22-3-103(a)(vi)(B);
    5. Property owned;
    6. Any other residency qualifications either provided by law or deemed reasonable by the clerk to render a judicious determination.
  3. The clerk shall give immediate written notice by certified return receipt mail to any person who is denied registration.
  4. Any person who is denied registration has the right to appeal to a circuit court within the county or to the district court within five (5) days of the date of the notification. The appellant shall not be required to obtain legal counsel for any such appeal.
  5. The court shall hear and decide any such appeal within five (5) days from the date the appeal is received.
  6. The provisions of the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act are not applicable to voter registration appeals.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-21; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 2000, ch. 24, § 4; 2004, ch. 42, § 1; 2005, ch. 110, § 1; 2020 ch. 56, § 1, effective March 12, 2020.

The 2004 amendment in (d) deleted “justice of the peace” following “right to appeal to a.”

Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 3, 2004.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, in (a), substituted “voter registration lists” for “registry lists.”

The 2020 amendment, in the introductory language of (b) substituted “the county clerk” for “he”; and in (b)(iv), substituted “Wyoming driver's license or tribal identification card that meets the requirements of W.S. 22-3-103(a)(vi)(B)” for “Driver's license.”

Laws 2020, ch. 56, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 11, 2020.
