Cross references. —

As to computing time in which to appeal, see § 22-2-110.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Exclusion or inclusion of terminal Sunday or holiday in computing time for taking or perfecting appeal from decision of electoral board, 61 ALR2d 482.

§ 22-3-106. Request for voter registration withdrawal; form.

If a voter registration applicant affirms that he is registered in another county or state, the registry agent shall require that the applicant make a written withdrawal of voter registration from another county or state on the Wyoming registration application.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-22; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2005, ch. 110, § 1; 2010, ch. 3, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, in the second sentence, substituted “cause notice to be sent” for “mail the form.”

The 2010 amendment, effective July 1, 2010, substituted “make a written withdrawal of voter registration from another county or state on the Wyoming registration application” for “complete and sign a ‘Request for Voter Registration Withdrawal’ form,” and deleted the former second sentence, introductory clause and the ‘Request for Voter Registration Withdrawal’ form.

§ 22-3-107. Information registry agent may enter on registration form.

The registry agent may determine and enter on a voter registration oath form the voting district number, polling precinct number, school district number, house district number and senate district number after the applicant signs the form.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-23; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-3-108. Official registry list information.

  1. The official registry list shall contain at least the following information as to each registered elector:
    1. Name in full;
    2. Residence by street number and name, if any;
    3. Voting district and precinct numbers;
    4. Party affiliation, if declared;
    5. House and senate district numbers;
    6. Date of birth; and
    7. The elector’s Wyoming driver’s license number, or if the elector has no Wyoming driver’s license, one (1) of the following unique identifying numbers:
      1. The last four (4) digits of the elector’s social security number, or if the elector also has no social security number;
      2. A unique identifying number generated by the state.
  2. The official registry list may contain the following information as to each registered elector:
    1. Repealed by Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 4.
    2. County of residence;
    3. Date of registration;
    4. Repealed by Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 4.
    5. Name of municipal corporation of residence, if any;
    6. Number of school district of residence;
    7. Mailing address;
    8. Gender; and
    9. Telephone number, if any.
  3. The county clerk may maintain within the election records the social security numbers of registered electors for identification purposes.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-24; Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2004, ch. 94, §§ 2, 4.

The 2004 amendment, by ch. 94, §§ 2 and 4, added (a)(vi) and (vii); repealed former (b)(i), pertaining to social security number, and former (b)(iv), pertaining to date of birth, and added (b)(viii) and (ix); in (c) deleted “which information shall not be a part of the public record” at the end; and made stylistic changes.

Laws 2004, ch. 94, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2004.

§ 22-3-109. Certification and transmittal of poll lists; posting of registry lists.

  1. Not less than ten (10) days before any election, the county clerk shall certify and transmit to the officer in charge of each election at his request the necessary poll lists for the precincts or areas involved in the election. Not less than ten (10) days prior to the primary and general elections the county clerks shall upon request deliver up to three (3) poll lists for each precinct in the county to the county chairman of each political party in the respective counties.
  2. The county clerk shall publicly post in a prominent place at the county courthouse one (1) copy of the registry list for each precinct.

History:

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-25; Laws 1977, ch. 186, § 2; 1978, ch. 38, § 2; 2005, ch. 110, § 1; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, in (a), twice substituted “poll list” for “registry list,” and substituted “deliver” for“ mail”; and in (b), substituted “registry list” for “list.”

The 2014 amendment, in the last sentence of (a), inserted “upon request,” inserted “up to,” and deleted “copies of the.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

§ 22-3-110. Expense of preparing poll lists.

The expense of preparing poll lists required by law to be provided by the county clerk in combined statewide political subdivision elections, shall be shared on an equitable basis by the governmental entities participating in the election. The expense of preparing other poll lists shall be paid by the entity holding the election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-26; 2005, ch. 110, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, twice substituted “poll lists” for “registry lists.”

§ 22-3-111. Preparation and contents of pollbooks.

  1. The county clerk shall prepare the necessary pollbooks for statewide and political subdivision elections held on the same date. The pollbooks shall contain the poll lists.
  2. Pollbooks shall be prepared for special district elections by the officials in charge of such elections. The county clerk shall furnish poll lists as required and requested by such officials.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-27; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2005, ch. 110, § 1; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, substituted “poll lists” for “registry lists” in (a) and (b).

The 2015 amendment, rewrote (a), which formerly read: “The county clerk shall prepare the necessary pollbooks for each precinct for statewide and political subdivision elections held on the same date. The precinct pollbooks shall contain the poll lists, the oaths of judges of election, certificate of ballots, and a tally sheet if ballots are hand counted. On the cover of the pollbook shall be printed the words ‘Pollbook’, the election and date of the election, the voting district and precinct numbers.”

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

§ 22-3-112. Pollbook distribution; entering information.

Before the polls open, the county clerk shall distribute the pollbooks to the judges of election in the respective polling places. The judges of election shall enter in pollbooks all information required by law.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-28; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

The 2015 amendment, in the first sentence, substituted “pollbooks” for “precinct pollbooks” and “polling places” for “precincts.”

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

§ 22-3-113. Disposition of pollbooks after polls close.

  1. After the polls are closed, judges of the election shall make printed pollbooks agree and shall return one (1) pollbook to the county clerk.
  2. When electronic pollbooks are used, they shall be returned to the county clerk.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957 § 22.1-29; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 2005, ch. 110, § 1; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, deleted “and one (1) copy of the registry list, which may be one and the same” after the first reference to “poll list,” and substituted “poll list” or a variant for “pollbook” or a variant throughout.

The 2015 amendment, designated the existing provisions as (a); rewrote (a); and added (b).

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

§ 22-3-114. Notification by registered elector of name or address change.

A registered elector who changes his name or changes his residence from one address to another within the same county shall notify the county clerk of the change, including in the notification the name, address, precinct and social security number (optional) under which registered and the nature of the change.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-30; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2.

Referendum petitions. —

It was error for a city clerk to reject signatures on a municipal referendum petition of voters whose addresses stated on the petition differed from addresses in the county clerk's voter registration list because one could lawfully move to a different address within the city without updating his or her address and still be a legally qualified elector registered in the city. City of Casper v. Holloway, 2015 WY 93, 354 P.3d 65, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (Wyo. 2015).

It was error for a city clerk to reject signatures on a municipal referendum petition of voters who moved within the city without notifying the county clerk because this did not automatically disqualify the voters, as (1) Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-3-115(a) stated the criteria for cancelling a voter's registration, and, (2) under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-3-116, a registration could not be cancelled automatically. City of Casper v. Holloway, 2015 WY 93, 354 P.3d 65, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (Wyo. 2015).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Right of married woman to use maiden surname, 67 ALR3d 1266.

§ 22-3-115. Grounds for cancellation of registration.

  1. A registered elector’s registration shall be cancelled for any one (1) of the following reasons:
    1. Failure to vote in any general election;
    2. Death;
    3. Removal of residence from the county or state more than thirty (30) days prior to an election;
    4. Disqualification to vote;
    5. Receipt of notification that the elector has registered to vote in another jurisdiction;
    6. Upon written request of the elector.
  2. A registered elector’s registration shall not be cancelled if the elector in any general election requested an absentee ballot which was rejected.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-31; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Referendum petitions. —

It was error for a city clerk to reject signatures on a municipal referendum petition of voters who moved within the city without notifying the county clerk because this did not automatically disqualify the voters, as (1) Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-3-115(a) stated the criteria for cancelling a voter's registration, and, (2) under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-3-116, a registration could not be cancelled automatically. City of Casper v. Holloway, 2015 WY 93, 354 P.3d 65, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (Wyo. 2015).

It was error for a city clerk to reject signatures on a municipal referendum petition of voters whose addresses stated on the petition differed from addresses in the county clerk's voter registration list because one could lawfully move to a different address within the city without updating his or her address and still be a legally qualified elector registered in the city. City of Casper v. Holloway, 2015 WY 93, 354 P.3d 65, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (Wyo. 2015).

Cross references. —

As to persons excluded from franchise, see art. 6, § 6, Wyo. Const.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

What constitutes “conviction” within constitutional provisions disfranchising one convicted of crime, 36 ALR2d 1238.

Effect of conviction under federal law, or law of another state or country, on right to vote, 39 ALR3d 303.

§ 22-3-116. Notice of intent to cancel registration.

When the county clerk has information that a registration should be cancelled, he shall mail a notice of intent to cancel to the elector at his address on the registry list stating the reason for cancellation. The notice shall state that cancellation shall occur within twenty (20) days unless the elector asks that his name remain on the registry list. A copy of the notice of cancellation shall be retained by the county clerk for three (3) years. A notice is not required if the clerk has received a receipt of notification that the elector has registered to vote in another jurisdiction or if the elector requested cancellation in writing.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251,§ 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-32; Laws 1974, ch. 24,§ 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Referendum petitions. —

It was error for a city clerk to reject signatures on a municipal referendum petition of voters who moved within the city without notifying the county clerk because this did not automatically disqualify the voters, as (1) Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-3-115(a) stated the criteria for cancelling a voter's registration, and, (2) under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-3-116, a registration could not be cancelled automatically. City of Casper v. Holloway, 2015 WY 93, 354 P.3d 65, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (Wyo. 2015).

§ 22-3-117. Absentee registration generally; use of federal postcard.

  1. Notwithstanding any other section or provision in this chapter, any citizen of the United States who is a resident of Wyoming may apply for registration by providing the information required by W.S. 22-3-103(a) and acceptable identification to and completing and subscribing, the form of voter registration oath prescribed by W.S. 22-3-103(b) before any person authorized by law to administer oaths. Each county clerk shall furnish the voter registration oath forms. The applicant shall mail or return the completed voter registration oath form to the county clerk in the county in which the applicant resides. In order to vote in the next election, the application must be received in the county clerk’s office before the close of registration for that election, or:
    1. Be received by mail or email and processed by the county clerk during the closed period described in W.S. 22-3-102(a) if it is accompanied by an absentee ballot request for elections where a voter may register at the polls;
    2. Be made at the county clerk’s office during the closed period described in W.S. 22-3-102(a) if the voter simultaneously votes at the county clerk’s office; or
    3. Be made and processed at the absentee polling place during the closed period described in W.S. 22-3-102(a) if the voter simultaneously votes at the absentee polling place established for that purpose pursuant to W.S. 22-9-125.
  2. Under the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act, 42 U.S.C. 1973ff (2002) the following persons shall be allowed to simultaneously register and make application for an absentee ballot through the use of the Federal Postcard Application (FPCA), provided those persons are residents of this state or in the case of overseas citizens, they were last domiciled in Wyoming immediately prior to their departure from the United States and are not registered to vote in any other jurisdiction:
    1. Members of the uniformed services and their spouses and dependents residing with them;
    2. Overseas citizens and their spouses and dependents residing with them;
    3. Citizens temporarily residing outside of the United States, and their spouses and dependents residing with them; and
    4. Any other person to whom federal law requires this privilege be extended.
  3. Annual registration through the Federal Postcard Application constitutes temporary registration for the purpose of voting in any election during the calendar year for which the voter registered, and the registration of such a registrant shall be maintained as provided in W.S. 22-3-102(d). The Federal Postcard Application shall be accepted if completed and signed by the applicant under penalty of perjury.
  4. If any person specified in subsection (b) of this section desires permanent registration, that person shall provide the information required by W.S. 22-3-103(a) and subscribe to the voter registration oath prescribed by W.S. 22-3-103(b). The oath shall be self-administered under penalty of perjury and notwithstanding W.S. 22-3-104 does not require the signature of an oath-taking official.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-33; Laws 1979, ch. 133, § 2; 1985, ch. 143, § 1; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2; 2004, ch. 94, § 2; 2005, ch. 110, § 1; 2009, ch. 139, § 1; 2013 ch. 28, § 1, effective July 1, 2013; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014; 2020 ch. 100, § 1, effective July 1, 2020.

The 2004 amendment, in (b), substituted “Uniformed and Overseas Absentee Voting Act, 42 U.S.C. 1973ff (2002)” for “Military and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act, 42 U.S.C. 1973ff (1986) or any subsequent federal laws of similar purpose,” in (b)(i) substituted “uniformed services” for “armed forces and merchant marine,” and in (b)(iii) deleted “and the District of Columbia” following “United States”; in (c) rewrote the first sentence which formerly read: “Registration through the Federal Postcard Application constitutes temporary registration for the current election year only and the registration of such a registrant shall not be entered on the permanent registration records of the county clerk”; in (d) inserted “notwithstanding W.S. 22-3-104” following “under penalty of perjury and”; and made stylistic changes.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, in (a) and (d) inserted “provide the information required by W.S. 22-3-103(a) and” or a variant, and substituted “W.S. 22-3-103(b)” for “W.S. 22-3-103”; and additionally in (a) deleted “which person is considered a registry agent for this purpose” following “administer oaths.”

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in (a), added designation (a)(i) and substituted “Be received by mail and processed by the county clerk during the closed period described in W.S. 22-3-102(a) if it is accompanied” for “Be accompanied”; and added (a)(ii) and (a)(iii).

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, deleted “or as many as the next two (2) federal election cycles” following “one (1) election,” substituted “election” for “elections” following “special federal,” and made stylistic changes in (c).

The 2014 amendment, inserted “cycle” in (c).

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (a)(i) substituted “by mail or email” for “by mail”; and in (c) substituted “Annual registration” for “Registration” and “voting in any election during the calendar year for which the voter registered” for “voting in one (1) election cycle, including a primary, general or special federal election.”

§ 22-3-118. Proof of identity.

  1. Unless a voter is challenged pursuant to W.S. 22-15-101 through 22-15-109, no identification shall be required when:
    1. Voting by absentee ballot after having registered in person; or
    2. Voting by absentee ballot after having registered by mail and having submitted a copy of the person’s acceptable identification, as set forth in W.S. 22-1-102(a)(xxxix)(A), at the time of registration.
  2. and (c) Repealed by Laws 2020, ch. 100, § 2.
  3. Voters who are challenged and are unable to provide the required proof of identity shall be offered provisional ballots in accordance with W.S. 22-15-105 and permitted until the close of business on the day following the election to present documentation to the county clerk establishing their eligibility to vote.
  4. The provisions of this section shall not apply to elections conducted pursuant to chapter 29 of this Election Code.
  5. Repealed by Laws 2020, ch. 100, § 2.

History.

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 1; 2020 ch. 100, §§ 1, 2, effective July 1, 2020; 2021 ch. 114, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (a)(ii) substituted “having submitted a copy of the person's acceptable identification, as set forth in W.S. 22-1-102(a)(xxxix), at the time of registration” for “having previously voted in a Wyoming federal election”; repealed (b) and (c), which read “(b) Prior to voting, when a voter has registered by mail and is voting in person in his first Wyoming federal election, he shall provide: (i) A current, valid photo identification; or (ii) A copy of a current utility bill, bank statement, paycheck, government check or other government document which shows his name and address. (c) When a voter has registered by mail and he is voting by mail in his first Wyoming federal election, he shall submit with his absentee ballot: (i) A copy of a current, valid photo identification; or (ii) A copy of a current utility bill, bank statement, government check, paycheck, or other government document which shows his name and address.”; in (d) substituted “who are challenged and are unable” for “who are unable,” “proof of identity” for “proof under the applicable provisions of subsections (b) and (c) of this section,” and “to vote” for “to vote in the precinct”; and repealed (f), which read “As used in this section “Wyoming federal election” means a primary election, general election or a special election for federal office held in this state.”

The 2021 amendment, effective July 1, 2021, in (a)(i) and (a)(ii), deleted "in person or" following "Voting," substituted "absentee ballot" for "mail"; and added "(A)" following "W.S. 22-1-102(a)(xxxix)" in (a)(ii).

Effective dates. —

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2004.

Am Jur 2d and C.J.S. references

Constitutionality of Requiring Presentation of Photographic Identification in Order to Vote. 27 A.L.R.6th 541.

Chapter 4 Political Parties

  • Article 1. Major Political Parties
  • Article 2. Formation
  • Article 3. Minor Political Parties
  • Article 4. Formation of New Provisional Parties

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

25 Am. Jur. 2d Elections §§ 195 to 202.

29 C.J.S. Elections §§ 148 to 177.

Article 1. Major Political Parties

  • § 22-4-101.  Application; composition, election and qualifications of county central committees; certificate of election.
  • § 22-4-102.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-4-103.  County central committee vacancies.
  • § 22-4-104.  County central committee organizational meeting; notice of meetings.
  • § 22-4-105.  County central committee odd year meeting; notice; election of chairman, state committeeman and committeewoman.
  • § 22-4-106.  County convention.
  • § 22-4-107.  County convention delegates.
  • § 22-4-108.  Delegates and alternates to state convention; county platform.
  • § 22-4-109.  Notice to state chairman of state committeeman and committeewoman.
  • § 22-4-110.  Composition of state central committee.
  • § 22-4-111.  State central committee organizational meeting; notice.
  • § 22-4-112.  State committeeman or committeewoman vacancies.
  • § 22-4-113.  Delegation of functions to subcommittees.
  • § 22-4-114.  Representation by proxy; qualifications.
  • § 22-4-115.  Date of party state convention.
  • § 22-4-116.  Calling of state convention; contents of notice.
  • § 22-4-117.  State convention members.
  • § 22-4-118.  State convention powers and duties.
  • § 22-4-119.  Certification and filing of rules and bylaws.
  • § 22-4-120.  Certification of presidential elector nominees and party officers.

§ 22-4-101. Application; composition, election and qualifications of county central committees; certificate of election.

  1. This article is applicable only to “major political parties”.
  2. The county central committee of each political party consists of precinct committeemen and committeewomen elected in the county at the regular biennial primary election. Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, each political party in each precinct shall elect one (1) committeeman and one (1) committeewoman for each two hundred fifty (250) votes or major fraction thereof cast for the party’s candidate for representative in congress in the last general election, but provided that no precinct shall be entitled to less than one (1) precinct committeeman and precinct committeewoman. Precinct committeemen and committeewomen shall be electors registered in the party and resident in the precinct. If a precinct boundary line is changed for any reason, the county commissioners shall determine the number of precinct committeemen and committeewomen to which the affected precinct is entitled.
  3. In any general election year in which a new plan of legislative districts is required, the number of precinct committeemen and committeewomen shall be one (1) committeeman and one (1) committeewoman for each two hundred fifty (250) votes or major fraction thereof of voters registered in that political party at the time election districts are adopted by the county commissioners as provided in W.S. 22-7-101, provided that no precinct shall be entitled to less than one (1) precinct committeeman and precinct committeewoman.
  4. No later than forty-five (45) days after the date of the primary election, the county canvassing board or a canvassing board appointed by the county clerk consisting of two (2) electors and the county clerk, shall provide to each county chairman the certified election results for precinct committeemen and committeewomen and a list of persons who received write-in votes for precinct committeemen or committeewomen.
  5. The term of office for all precinct committeemen and committeewomen shall be two (2) years and shall begin on the first Monday in January of the year following their election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-34; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1996, ch. 93, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2012, ch. 9, § 1; 2015 ch. 154, § 1, effective July 1, 2015; 2020 ch. 92, § 1, effective July 1, 2020.

The 2012 amendment, inserted “Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section” in (b); and adding (c).

Laws 2012, ch. 9 § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 6, 2012.

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, in (b), deleted the former next-to-last sentence, which read: “The county clerk shall issue a certificate of election to the precinct committeemen and committeewomen elected and concurrently notify the county central committee chairman. The certificate shall state the term of office which shall begin on the day the primary election is canvassed and shall expire on the date the next regular biennial primary election is canvassed”; and added (d) and (e).

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (a) deleted “Except for the term beginning after the canvass of the 2014 primary election” at the beginning and the last sentence, which read “The term for committeemen and committeewomen elected at the 2014 primary election shall end on the first Monday in January of 2017.”

§ 22-4-102. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, related to the procedure for breaking a tie vote for precinct committeeman or committeewoman.

§ 22-4-103. County central committee vacancies.

A vacancy in the county central committee shall occur in the case of death, resignation, failure of a qualified candidate to be elected to a precinct committeeman or committeewoman position, or removal of residence from the precinct. A vacancy shall be filled by the county central committee by election of a registered elector resident in the precinct in which the vacancy exists and registered in the party or as provided by the party bylaws.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-36; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-4-104. County central committee organizational meeting; notice of meetings.

The county central committee shall meet and organize under the direction of the county chairman at the time and place determined by the county chairman within thirty (30) days after the term of its members begins. The county chairman shall also publish a notice of all meetings of the county central committee in a newspaper of general county circulation not less than two (2) days prior to a meeting.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-37; 1996, ch. 93, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2015 ch. 154, § 1, effective July 1, 2015; 2020 ch. 92, § 1, effective July 1, 2020.

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, in the first sentence, substituted “received the certified election results of all members elected to the committee” for “received notice from the county clerk that all of its members have been certified elected.”

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, substituted “after the term of its members begins” for “after the county chairman has received the certified election results of all members elected to the committee.”

§ 22-4-105. County central committee odd year meeting; notice; election of chairman, state committeeman and committeewoman.

The county central committee shall meet at the county seat each odd-numbered year at a time and place determined by the county chairman. The county chairman shall publish notice of the meeting in a newspaper of general circulation within the county not less than ten (10) days before this meeting. At the meeting, the county central committee shall elect the chairman of the county central committee, one (1) state committeeman and one (1) state committeewoman and other offices as provided by the party bylaws. A state political party may provide in its rules for the election of additional state committeemen and additional state committeewomen. Neither the chairman, state committeeman or state committeewoman need be members of the county central committee.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-38; Laws 1983, ch. 183, § 2; 1996, ch. 93, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 47, § 1.

§ 22-4-106. County convention.

The county convention of each political party shall meet in even-numbered years.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-39; Laws 1983, ch. 183, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1996, ch. 93, § 1; 1999, ch. 202, § 1; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 47, § 1.

§ 22-4-107. County convention delegates.

Delegates to the county convention of a political party are the members of the county central committee, unless a political party provides in its rules for an alternate method of selecting such delegates.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-40.

§ 22-4-108. Delegates and alternates to state convention; county platform.

The county convention shall elect from electors resident in the county and registered in the party delegates and alternates to the state convention as apportioned by the rules of the party. The county convention may also adopt a county platform.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-41.

§ 22-4-109. Notice to state chairman of state committeeman and committeewoman.

The county chairman shall immediately notify the state chairman in writing of the names and addresses of persons elected to the offices of state committeeman and committeewoman.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-42.

§ 22-4-110. Composition of state central committee.

The state central committee consists of state committeemen and committeewomen and county chairmen elected at the odd-numbered year meeting of the county central committees, and of any other party officials provided by the bylaws of the party.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-43; Laws 1983, ch. 183, § 2; 1996, ch. 93, § 1; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 47, § 1.

§ 22-4-111. State central committee organizational meeting; notice.

The state central committee shall hold an organizational meeting in odd-numbered years, at which it shall elect from electors registered in the party a chairman, secretary and other officers as provided in the rules of the party. The state chairman shall mail notice of the time and place of this meeting to each member of the committee not later than ten (10) days before the meeting.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-44; Laws 1983, ch. 183, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 47, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-4-112. State committeeman or committeewoman vacancies.

A vacancy in the office of state committeeman or committeewoman occurring by death, resignation or removal of residence from the county shall be filled by the county central committee of the county in which the vacancy occurs within thirty (30) days of such vacancy.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-45.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-4-113. Delegation of functions to subcommittees.

The state and county central committees may delegate any lawful function to a subcommittee by majority resolution consistent with party rules, except election of its officers.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-46.

§ 22-4-114. Representation by proxy; qualifications.

A member of a political committee or subcommittee may be represented at any meeting of the committee or subcommittee by written proxy. A person holding a proxy must be a resident of the same political subdivision as the member he represents. No person shall be allowed to vote more than two (2) proxies.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-47.

§ 22-4-115. Date of party state convention.

Each political party shall hold a state convention in even-numbered years.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-48; Laws 1983, ch. 183, § 2; 1996, ch. 93, § 1; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 47, § 1.

§ 22-4-116. Calling of state convention; contents of notice.

The state chairman shall call a state convention by filing notice in the office of the secretary of state and of each county clerk not later than twenty (20) days before the convention. The notice shall state the total number of delegates and alternates, and the number of delegates to which each county is entitled.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-49.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-4-117. State convention members.

Members of the state convention are the delegates or their alternates chosen by the county conventions, and the delegates or their alternates chosen at large by the youth organizations of the political parties in accordance with rules of their respective party.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-50; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

§ 22-4-118. State convention powers and duties.

  1. The state convention has the following powers and duties:
    1. To nominate electors of president and vice-president of the United States;
    2. To elect national committeemen and committeewomen;
    3. To adopt a platform;
    4. To select delegates and alternates to national nominating conventions;
    5. To formulate or change the rules governing the internal organizations of the party which rules must include:
      1. The time, place, manner of election and terms of office of party officers not provided by statute;
      2. The method of apportioning delegates and alternates to the state convention to each county;
      3. The method of selecting delegates and alternates to the national convention;
      4. The name, powers and duties of any standing committee of the state central committee and the state convention;
      5. Rules of conduct for county and state conventions;
      6. Powers and duties delegated to county and state committees.
    6. To conduct such other business as it deems necessary or proper.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-51.

Cross references. —

As to election of presidential and vice-presidential electors, see §§ 22-19-101 to 22-19-109.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Power to make party nominations. —

Legislature has never recognized any power in political committees to make party nominations, except as delegated to it either by party convention or legislature. State ex rel. Copenhaver v. Jack, 60 Wyo. 405, 153 P.2d 149, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1944).

Statutes did not authorize state central committee to nominate candidate for office of secretary of state to fill unexpired term of one who died 26 days before general election date. State ex rel. Copenhaver v. Jack, 60 Wyo. 405, 153 P.2d 149, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1944).

§ 22-4-119. Certification and filing of rules and bylaws.

  1. The county party chairman and party secretary shall certify all rules and bylaws promulgated, revoked or amended by the county central committee and file them with the county clerk within thirty (30) days after the adjournment of the county central committee meeting.
  2. The state party chairman and party secretary shall certify all rules and bylaws promulgated, revoked or amended by the state convention and file them with the secretary of state within thirty (30) days after the adjournment of the state convention.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-52; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-4-120. Certification of presidential elector nominees and party officers.

The state party chairman and party secretary shall certify the names of nominees for presidential electors and the names of the state and county party officers elected or appointed to the secretary of state immediately after their selection.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-53; 1996, ch. 93, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to election of presidential and vice-presidential electors, see §§ 22-19-101 to 22-19-109.

Article 2. Formation

  • § 22-4-201.  [Renumbered.]
  • §§ 22-4-202 through 22-4-204.  [Renumbered.]
  • §§ 22-4-205 through 22-4-208.  [Repealed.]

§ 22-4-201. [Renumbered.]

Renumbered by Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 3.

Cross references. —

As to form and validity of petition, see § 22-4-402.

§§ 22-4-202 through 22-4-204. [Renumbered.]

Renumbered by Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 4.

Cross references. —

As to circulation, signing and verification of petition, see §§ 22-4-403 through 22-4-405.

§§ 22-4-205 through 22-4-208. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

These sections, which derived from Laws 1984, ch. 40, § 1, related to the effect of a valid petition, the application for nomination or election, vacancies in nomination and filing a vacancy in office.

Article 3. Minor Political Parties

  • § 22-4-301.  Application of article.
  • § 22-4-302.  Composition and qualifications of minor party offices.
  • § 22-4-303.  Nomination of candidates.
  • § 22-4-304.  Certification of candidates; fees.
  • § 22-4-305.  Certification and filing of rules and bylaws.
  • § 22-4-306.  Certification of presidential elector nominees and party officers.
  • § 22-4-307.  Calling of state convention, contents of notice.

Constitutionality of former provisions governing minor party ballot access. —

The former provisions of the Wyoming Election Code governing minor party ballot access were unduly burdensome and, hence, unconstitutional. Blomquist v. Thomson, 591 F. Supp. 768, 1984 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 19379 (D. Wyo.), rev'd, 739 F.2d 525, 1984 U.S. App. LEXIS 20277 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1984) (decided under pre-1984 version of former § 22-1-102(g) and prior to enactment of former § 22-4-201 et seq.).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, construction, and application of state statutes governing “minor political parties”, 120 ALR 5th 1.

§ 22-4-301. Application of article.

This article is applicable only to minor political parties.

History.

Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-4-302. Composition and qualifications of minor party offices.

Each minor party shall provide for a sufficient number of officers to govern the party and shall have at least a state party chairman and a state party secretary. Each officer shall be a registered elector in the party. Officers shall be elected or appointed in accordance with party rules and bylaws.

History.

Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 1.

§ 22-4-303. Nomination of candidates.

Minor parties may nominate candidates to be placed on the general election ballot only by party convention. Under no circumstances shall a minor political party nominate by the primary election process.

History.

Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 1.

§ 22-4-304. Certification of candidates; fees.

  1. The chairman and secretary of the state political convention shall certify to the secretary of state the names of its party’s nominees for United States senator, United States representative, all elective state offices and legislative offices.
  2. The chairman and secretary of the state or county political convention shall certify to the county clerk the names of its party’s nominees for elected county offices and office of the district attorney.
  3. The names certified to the secretary of state or the county clerk shall be filed no later than the day before the primary election.
  4. Persons certified as nominees shall be members of that party, as shown by their affidavits of registration, at the time their names are certified to the secretary of state or the county clerk.
  5. Each certification made under this section shall be accompanied by the same application and fee required for the same office of a candidate seeking nomination by primary election. A certification not accompanied by the application and fee is not valid.

History:

Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 1; 1996, ch. 93, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014.

The 2014 amendment, in (a), inserted “and” preceding “legislative,” and deleted “and office of district attorney” at the end; and in (b), added “and office of the district attorney” at the end.

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 10, 2014.

§ 22-4-305. Certification and filing of rules and bylaws.

The state party chairman and state party secretary shall certify all rules and bylaws promulgated, revoked or amended by the state convention and file them with the secretary of state within thirty (30) days after the adjournment of the state convention.

History.

Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 1.

§ 22-4-306. Certification of presidential elector nominees and party officers.

The state party chairman and state party secretary shall certify the names of nominees for presidential electors and the name of the state and county party officers elected to the secretary of state immediately after the state convention.

History.

Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-4-307. Calling of state convention, contents of notice.

The state chairman shall call a state convention by filing notice in the office of the secretary of state and of each county clerk not later than twenty (20) days before the convention. The notice shall state the eligibility requirements for voting at the convention.

History.

Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 1.

Article 4. Formation of New Provisional Parties

  • § 22-4-401.  Application of article.
  • § 22-4-402.  Petition; form; validity.
  • § 22-4-403.  Circulation of petition; requirements.
  • § 22-4-404.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-4-405.  Verification of signatures on petition.
  • § 22-4-406.  Officers and nominating procedures.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

29 C.J.S. Elections §§ 148 to 153.

§ 22-4-401. Application of article.

This article is applicable only to provisional parties.

History.

Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-4-402. Petition; form; validity.

  1. Any group of persons desiring to form a new political party within this state shall file a petition with the secretary of state not later than June 1 in any general election year in which the party seeks to qualify for the general election ballot.
  2. The petition shall be approved by the secretary of state prior to circulation and shall conform in substance to the following:
  3. The name of the party printed on the petition shall consist of not more than two (2) words and shall not be identical to, nor similar to, the name of any existing qualified political party as determined by the secretary of state, nor to the word “independent”.
  4. To be valid, a petition shall contain the names and signatures of registered electors equal in number to not less than two percent (2%) of the total number of votes cast for the office of United States house of representatives in the last general election.
  5. The petition shall be circulated no earlier than April 1 of the year preceding the general election.

PETITION FOR FORMATIONOF A POLITICAL PARTY I know the contents of this petition including the names of the provisional party officers and request that the party be printed on the ballot for the next general election. I am a registered elector for the next primary and general election. (This statement shall appear at the head of each petition page.) PROVISIONAL PARTY OFFICERSNAME ADDRESS CHAIRPERSON TREASURER PETITIONERS (Signature) (Printed Name) (Residence) (Date) 1. 2. VERIFICATION BY CIRCULATORS I, , do hereby certify that I am a circulator of this petition, and I solely and personally circulated this petition, that all the signatures appearing herein were made in my presence from (month) (day), (year) through (month) (day), (year), and to the best of my knowledge and belief such signatures are those of the persons whose names they purport to be. (signature) (residence address)

Click to view

History.


Laws 1984, ch. 40, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 22-4-201; Laws 1985, ch. 204, § 1; 1991, ch. 243, § 3; 1997, ch. 37, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2019 ch. 186, § 1, effective July 1, 2019.

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, in (d), substituted "representatives" for "representative."

Independent candidate and new political party failed to show likelihood of success on merits in challenge to statutory signature and deadline requirements. See Populist Party v. Herschler, 746 F.2d 656, 1984 U.S. App. LEXIS 17718 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1984).

§ 22-4-403. Circulation of petition; requirements.

Copies of the petition may be circulated for signatures, but each separate page shall contain the information required to be contained in the original petition. An elector signing the petition shall also list his name, residence and the date after his signature, as provided on the petition form in W.S. 22-4-402(b).

History.


Laws 1984, ch. 40, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 22-4-202; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 4.

Editor's notes. —

Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 4, renumbered this section, which was former § 22-4-202, effective July 1, 1991.

§ 22-4-404. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 11, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1984, ch. 40, § 1, related to signing more than one petition to form a new political party.

§ 22-4-405. Verification of signatures on petition.

The secretary of state shall determine from the official list of registered electors whether sufficient valid signatures have been obtained on petitions filed with the secretary of state’s office.

History.


Laws 1984, ch. 40, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 22-4-204; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 4.

Editor's notes. —

Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 4, renumbered this section, which was former § 22-4-204, effective July 1, 1991.

§ 22-4-406. Officers and nominating procedures.

A provisional party shall be subject to W.S. 22-4-302 through 22-4-307. Under no circumstances shall a provisional party nominate by the primary election process.

History.

Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Chapter 5 Nominations

  • Article 1. General Provisions
  • Article 2. Nomination by Primary Election
  • Article 3. Nomination by Petition
  • Article 4. Vacancies in Nomination
  • Article 5. Valid Write-In Candidates

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

25 Am. Jur. 2d Elections §§ 207 to 277.

Solicitation or receipt of funds by public officer or employee for political campaign expenses or similar purposes as bribery, 55 ALR2d 1137.

Right to seek nomination, or to become candidate, for more than 1 office in same election, 94 ALR2d 557.

29 C.J.S. Elections §§ 89 to 148.

Article 1. General Provisions

  • § 22-5-101.  How candidates nominated.
  • § 22-5-102.  Eligibility to be a candidate for state legislature; residency.
  • § 22-5-103.  Limits on ballot access; state offices.
  • § 22-5-104.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-5-105.  Scope of limitations.
  • § 22-5-106.  Severability.

§ 22-5-101. How candidates nominated.

Nominations of candidates for all offices filled at a general election, except school and community college district offices and special district offices, may be made by primary election, by petition for nomination as an independent candidate as provided in W.S. 22-5-301 through 22-5-308 or by convention as provided in W.S. 22-4-303 and 22-4-406.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-54; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

Stated in

Blomquist v. Thomson, 591 F. Supp. 768, 1984 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 19379 (D. Wyo. 1984).

§ 22-5-102. Eligibility to be a candidate for state legislature; residency.

  1. For the purpose of meeting residency requirements of the Wyoming constitution, a person shall not be a candidate for the state legislature from a legislative district unless he has been a resident of that legislative district for at least one (1) year next preceding his election. In any general election year in which a plan of legislative districts is required but has not been enacted into law at least one (1) year prior to the applicable filing periods, a person may be a candidate for the state legislature from a legislative district if he:
    1. Is a resident of the legislative district on the date he files an application under W.S. 22-5-204 or a petition under W.S. 22-5-301; and
    2. Has been a resident of a county for at least one (1) year next preceding his election in which any portion of that legislative district is located.

History.

Laws 1992, ch. 1, § 4; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 1, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to terms and qualifications of the members of the legislative department, see art. 3, § 2, Wyo. Const.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 22-5-103. Limits on ballot access; state offices.

  1. Notwithstanding any other provision of Wyoming law, the secretary of state or other authorized official shall not certify the name of any person as the nominee or candidate for the office sought, nor shall that person be elected nor serve in that office if the following will occur:
    1. The person, by the end of the current term of office will have served, or but for resignation, would have served eight (8) or more years in any sixteen (16) year period in the office for which the candidate is seeking nomination or election, except, that any time served in that particular office prior to January 1, 1993, shall not be counted for purposes of this term limit. This provision shall apply to the office of governor.
    2. and (iii) Repealed by Laws 2005, ch. 241, § 1.

History.


1992 Initiative No. 1, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 22-5-102; Laws 1995, ch. 12, § 1; 2005, ch. 241, § 1; 2015 ch. 76, § 1, effective July 1, 2015.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, repealed (a)(ii) and (a)(iii), pertaining to term limits for persons who had served, or but for resignation would have served, 12 or more years in a 24-year period.

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, in (a)(i), substituted “office of governor” for “offices of governor, secretary of state, state auditor, state treasurer, and state superintendent of public instruction.”

Editor's notes. —

This section was enacted by initiative, approved by the voters on November 3, 1992, certified by the secretary of state on November 12, 1992, and effective February 10, 1993.

1992 Initiative No. 1, § 2, provides:

This section was enacted as § 22-5-102. As there already was a § 22-5-102, this section has been renumbered as § 22-5-103.

Laws 1995, ch. 12, § 2, provides: “The intent of this act is to permit state representatives to serve the same number of years as state senators while maintaining term limits.”

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Constitutionality. —

Wyo. Const. art. 1, § 3 prohibited the passage of any law conditioning political rights and privileges upon a circumstance or condition other than those enumerated. Because Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-5-103 conditioned the right to hold the office of Secretary of State on incumbency, not an enumerated condition, it was unconstitutional. Maxfield v. State, 2013 WY 14, 294 P.3d 895, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 2013).

Term limit law, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-5-103, as it applies to candidates for the state legislature, whether adopted by initiative or legislative action, is unconstitutional and unenforceable because it violates art. 1, § 3 and art. 3, §§ 2 and 52(g), Wyo. Const. No law, whether enacted by the legislature through the legislative process or by the people through the initiative process, may condition political rights and privileges upon a circumstance or condition such as incumbency. Cathcart v. Meyer, 2004 WY 49, 88 P.3d 1050, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 62 (Wyo. 2004).

§ 22-5-104. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2005, ch. 241, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from 1992 Initiative No. 1, § 1, provided term limits for federal offices.

Laws 2005, ch. 241, § 2, makes the act effective July 1, 2005.

§ 22-5-105. Scope of limitations.

The term limits and ballot access restrictions set forth above shall apply only to the specific office referenced in which the person previously served. It is not the intent that this act [§§ 22-5-103 through 22-5-106] preclude or prohibit a person from seeking nomination or election to any other office for which the referenced term limit or ballot access restriction is not applicable.

History.


1992 Initiative No. 1, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 22-5-104.

Editor's notes. —

See note under the same heading at § 22-5-103.

This section was enacted as § 22-5-104. As there already was a § 22-5-104, this section has been renumbered as § 22-5-105.

§ 22-5-106. Severability.

If any part of this measure [§§ 22-5-103 through 22-5-106] or the application to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity shall not affect other provisions or application, which reasonably can be given effect without the invalid provision or applications.

History.


1992 Initiative No. 1, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 22-5-105.

Editor's notes. —

See note under the same heading at § 22-5-103.

This section was enacted as § 22-5-105. As there already was a § 22-5-105, this section has been renumbered as § 22-5-106.

Article 2. Nomination by Primary Election

  • § 22-5-201.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-5-202.  Major political party participation; separate ballots; same time.
  • § 22-5-203.  Nonpartisan judicial offices; separate ballot; same time.
  • § 22-5-204.  Application for nomination or election; party registration; form.
  • § 22-5-205.  Nomination application form for nonpartisan office.
  • § 22-5-206.  Where nomination applications to be filed.
  • § 22-5-207.  Furnishing of application forms.
  • § 22-5-208.  Filing fees; exception.
  • § 22-5-209.  Time for filing nomination applications; certified list.
  • §§ 22-5-210 and 22-5-211.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-5-212.  When declaration of party affiliation required.
  • § 22-5-213.  Entry in pollbook.
  • § 22-5-214.  Change in party affiliation.
  • § 22-5-215.  Nomination of partisan candidates and write-in candidates.
  • § 22-5-216.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-5-217.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-5-218.  Election of major party precinct committeemen and committeewomen.
  • § 22-5-219.  Further action by nominees or elect not required; exception.
  • § 22-5-220.  Withdrawal of nomination application restricted.

Applied in

Blomquist v. Thomson, 591 F. Supp. 768, 1984 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 19379 (D. Wyo. 1984).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

26 Am. Jur. 2d Elections §§ 203 to 264.

29 C.J.S. Elections §§ 178 to 259.

§ 22-5-201. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, related to the date of primary elections.

§ 22-5-202. Major political party participation; separate ballots; same time.

Major political parties shall participate in the primary election and each shall have a separate party ballot. The primary election of major political parties shall be held at the same time and at the same polling places and shall be conducted by the same election officials.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-56; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

§ 22-5-203. Nonpartisan judicial offices; separate ballot; same time.

  1. Repealed by Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 2; ch. 94, § 4.
  2. A separate ballot shall be used for the nonpartisan primary election which shall be held at the same time and at the same polling places and shall be conducted by the same election officials as the partisan primary election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-57; Laws 1979, ch. 133, § 2; 2004, ch. 42, § 2; ch. 94, § 4.

The 2004 amendments. —

The first 2004 amendment by ch. 42, § 2, repealed former (a), which read: “Candidates for the nonpartisan office of justice of the peace shall be nominated only by nonpartisan primary election.”

Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 3 makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 3, 2004.

The second 2004 amendment by ch. 94, § 4, also repealed former (a).

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2004.

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

§ 22-5-204. Application for nomination or election; party registration; form.

  1. Repealed by Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 5.
  2. An eligible person seeking nomination or election for a partisan office shall:
    1. Meet all applicable qualifications to be elected to office which are set forth in the United States and Wyoming constitutions;
    2. Be registered in the party whose nomination he seeks; and
    3. File an application in substantially the following form:
  3. A nomination application that is required to be filed with the secretary of state may be electronically filed as provided under W.S. 9-2-2501 if the application is accompanied by the proper filing fee.

APPLICATION FOR NOMINATION OR ELECTION BY PARTY PRIMARY State of Wyoming County of ss I, , swear or affirm that I was born on , (year), that I have been a resident of the state of Wyoming since , and that I am a registered voter of Election District No. , in Precinct No. , residing at , in County of , (if for the office of state senator or representative) in Senate (House) District , state of Wyoming, and registered as a member of party, (if for the office of governor) and that I resided at the physical residential addresses listed below during the past five (5) years, and I hereby request that my name be printed upon the official party ballot at the next primary election as a candidate for the office of , and hereby declare that if nominated and elected, I will qualify for the office. (If for the office of United States senator or representative in congress) I have not, at any time when knowingly seeking nomination or election to this office, claimed or been currently claiming any residence or received the benefits of residency from any other state, excluding the benefits of residency related to or incidental from maintaining a residence at or near the United States capital. (If for the office of governor) I have resided at the following physical residential addresses during the past five (5) years: (Residence) (Date) 1. 2. Dated the day of , (year). (Signature)

Click to view

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-58; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 5; 1992, ch. 1, § 5; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 1999, ch. 49, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 47, § 1; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014; 2019 ch. 4, § 1, effective February 13, 2019; 2021 ch. 167, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2014 amendment, deleted “(Residence Address)” at the end of the form in (b).

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2019 amendment, in (b), added “(i) Meet all applicable qualifications to be elected to office which are set forth in the United States and Wyoming constitutions;”; in (ii) added a semi-colon after “seeks” and deleted “shall”; in (iii) added “(if for the office of governor) and that I resided at the physical residential addresses listed below during the past five (5) years,” and added “(If for the office of governor) I have resided at the following physical residential addresses during the past five (5) years:”.

Laws 2019, ch. 4, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved February 13, 2019.

The 2021 amendment, effective July 1, 2021, added "(If for the office of United States senator or representative in congress) I have not, at any time when knowingly seeking nomination or election to this office, claimed or been currently claiming any residence or received the benefits of residency from any other state, excluding the benefits of residency related to or incidental from maintaining a residence at or near the United States capital" in (b)(iii).

Provisions mandatory. —

The provisions of a statute known as the “Australian Ballot Law,” requiring certificates of nominations of candidates for office to be made and filed to entitle the names of such candidates to be printed on the official ballot, are mandatory. State ex rel. Bennett v. Barber, 4 Wyo. 56, 32 P. 14, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1892).

Substantial compliance. —

Certificate of nomination and affidavits of officers of the convention thereto which are intelligible, and sufficient to convey to the mind of the inquirer the information required by such instruments, though defective in form, are not void in absence of any provision indicating an intent by the legislature that statute prescribing what certificate should contain, and how it should be verified, is so mandatory that a defect incapable of affecting the regular and orderly conduct or result of an election should invalidate it. State ex rel. Bennett v. Barber, 4 Wyo. 56, 32 P. 14, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1892).

Certificate of nomination is not fatally defective because it fails to show for what house of representatives the nomination was made, since it would seem that there could be no misunderstanding in regard thereto after the same was filed in the office of the clerk of the proper county. State ex rel. Bennett v. Barber, 4 Wyo. 56, 32 P. 14, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1892).

Withdrawal. —

One who files with secretary of state request that his name be placed on primary ballot as candidate for secretary of state has right to withdraw his name, and upon secretary of state refusing to recognize and make such withdrawal, mandamus will issue to compel him to do so. State ex rel. Rogers v. Hunt, 53 Wyo. 267, 81 P.2d 883, 1938 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1938).

Stated in

Murphy v. State Canvassing Bd., 12 P.3d 677, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 205 (Wyo. 2000).

Cited in

United States v. Tarver, 642 F. Supp. 1109, 1986 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 20838 (D. Wyo. 1986).

§ 22-5-205. Nomination application form for nonpartisan office.

  1. An eligible person seeking nomination for a nonpartisan office must file an application in substantially the following form:
  2. A nomination application that is required to be filed with the secretary of state may be electronically filed as provided under W.S. 9-2-2501 if the application is accompanied by the proper filing fee.

APPLICATION FOR NOMINATION BY NONPARTISAN PRIMARY State of Wyoming County of ss I, , swear or affirm that I was born on , that I have been a resident of the State of Wyoming since , and that I am a registered voter of County, residing at , and that I am eligible to be elected to such office, and I hereby request that my name be printed upon the official nonpartisan ballot at the next primary election as a candidate for the office indicated below as follows: (Name of office) I am seeking (1) the regular term or (2) the unexpired term which terminates on the day of , (year). Dated this day of , (year). Signature

Click to view

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-60; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1979, ch. 133, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 1999, ch. 49, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 47, § 1; 2004, ch. 42, 1; ch. 94, § 2.

The 2004 amendments. —

The first 2004 amendment, by ch. 42, § 1, in (a) substituted “(Name of office)” for “Justice of the peace.”

Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 3, 2004.

The second 2004 amendment, by ch. 94 § 2, in (a) also substituted “(Name of office)” for “Justice of the peace.”

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2004.

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

§ 22-5-206. Where nomination applications to be filed.

  1. Nomination applications for United States senators and representatives in congress, state offices, members of the legislature, circuit court judges, and state district court judges shall be filed in the office of the secretary of state.
  2. Applications for other offices that are to appear on the ballot in the county, including district attorneys, shall be filed in the office of the county clerk of the county in which the person filing for nomination resides.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-61; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2001, ch. 116, § 1; 2020 ch. 100, § 1, effective July 1, 2020.

Filing in new county. —

Nomination papers by a candidate for precinct committeeman where precinct is in a new county in process of organization should be filed with the provisional clerk of that county. Dillman v. State, 20 Wyo. 404, 125 P. 367, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 1912).

Cited in

Murphy v. State Canvassing Bd., 12 P.3d 677, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 205 (Wyo. 2000).

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (b) substituted “Applications for other offices that are to appear on the ballot in the county” for “Other applications.”

§ 22-5-207. Furnishing of application forms.

The secretary of state and county clerks shall provide the application form required to be filed in their respective offices.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-62; Laws 2001, ch. 116, § 1.

§ 22-5-208. Filing fees; exception.

  1. Applications shall be accompanied by the following fees:
    1. One hundred dollars ($100.00) for the offices of state senator, state representative, district attorney and for the offices to be voted for by electors wholly within a county;
    2. Three hundred dollars ($300.00) for offices to be voted for by electors of the entire state except as provided in paragraph (iii) of this subsection;
    3. Seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for any federal office voted for by electors of the entire state.
  2. No application is valid unless the fee is paid.
  3. A filing fee shall not be required of candidates for special district director, school district trustee, community college trustee, precinct committeeman or precinct committeewoman.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-63; Laws 1992, ch. 1, § 5; 1993, ch. 146, § 2; 2008, ch. 115, § 1; 2021 ch. 51, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2008 amendment, rewrote (c) which read: “A filing fee shall not be required of candidates for precinct committeeman and committeewomen.”

Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

The 2021 amendment, effective July 1, 2021, substituted "One hundred dollars ($100.00)" for "Twenty-five dollars ($25.00)" in (a)(i); in (a)(ii), substituted "Three hundred dollars ($300.00)" for "Two hundred dollars ($200.00)," added "except as provided in paragraph (iii) of this subsection"; and added (a)(iii).

Cited in

Murphy v. State Canvassing Bd., 12 P.3d 677, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 205 (Wyo. 2000).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity and effect of statutes exacting filing fees from candidates for public office, 89 ALR2d 864.

§ 22-5-209. Time for filing nomination applications; certified list.

An application for nomination shall be filed not more than ninety-six (96) days and not later than eighty-one (81) days next preceding the primary election. Not later than sixty-eight (68) days before a primary election the secretary of state shall transmit to each county clerk a certified list of persons whose applications have been filed in the office of the secretary of state stating as to each his name, age, address, office sought and party affiliation.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-64; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1979, ch. 133, § 2; 1990, ch. 42, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to computation of time, see § 22-2-210.

Day upon which computation begins must be “before” or “next preceding” day of election. State ex rel. Johnson v. Gage, 373 P.2d 958, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 98 (Wyo. 1962).

And election day not considered. —

Any reasonable interpretation of the meaning of “next” could not possibly mean to include the day of election as a day to be considered in the computation. State ex rel. Johnson v. Gage, 373 P.2d 958, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 98 (Wyo. 1962).

Application held not timely. —

A nomination application filed on July 12 for an election on August 21 was not timely. State ex rel. Johnson v. Gage, 373 P.2d 958, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 98 (Wyo. 1962).

Mandamus not granted to compel acceptance of untimely application. —

Where the application to be a candidate was filed less than 40 (now 74) days next preceding the primary election, it was not timely filed; and mandamus to compel acceptance of the application could not be granted. State ex rel. Johnson v. Thomson, 499 P.2d 590, 1972 Wyo. LEXIS 267 (Wyo. 1972).

Secretary of state's duty. —

Secretary of state, in certifying nominations to the county clerks, may respect the designation of a political party or principle mentioned in a certificate of nomination by electors where the certificate is signed, sworn to and presented by the state chairman of such party, in absence of any other nomination by such party for the same office; and he is not required to add to or disregard description, found in the certificate, indicating the manner in which the nomination was made, in the absence of any law limiting party nominations. State ex rel. Blydenburg v. Burdick, 6 Wyo. 448, 46 P. 854, 1896 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 1896).

Where two nominees of the convention of the People's Party declined and substitutes were nominated by certificate of 100 electors, as permitted by Laws 1890, ch. 80, § 88, the certificate being signed, sworn to and presented by the state chairman of the party, the secretary of state was not required to place some such word as “Independent,” or “Electors,” after the names of such substitutes, to indicate that they were nominated by certificate, there being no other nomination by that party for the same office. State ex rel. Blydenburg v. Burdick, 6 Wyo. 448, 46 P. 854, 1896 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 1896).

§§ 22-5-210 and 22-5-211. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

These sections, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, related to distribution of necessary supplies for an election and the procedure for conducting elections.

§ 22-5-212. When declaration of party affiliation required.

An elector requesting a major party ballot must declare his party affiliation, or sign an application for change of affiliation before he may receive a party ballot. An elector may vote only the nonpartisan ballot and if so, is not required to declare his party affiliation. Requesting a partisan primary election ballot constitutes a declaration of party affiliation. A change in declaration of party affiliation shall be entered on the poll list by the election judge.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-67; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 2005, ch. 110, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, deleted “and the registry list, which may be one and the same” following “poll list”, and substituted “election judge” for “county clerk.”

Stated in

Murphy v. State Canvassing Bd., 12 P.3d 677, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 205 (Wyo. 2000).

§ 22-5-213. Entry in pollbook.

The judges of election shall check or enter in the pollbook the name of each elector voting in the primary election and his party affiliation, if declared. An elector voting only a nonpartisan ballot shall be entered in the pollbook as an unaffiliated voter.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-68; 2010, ch. 3, § 2.

The 2010 amendment, effective July 1, 2010, substituted “an unaffiliated” for “a nonpartisan.”

§ 22-5-214. Change in party affiliation.

An elector may change his party affiliation by completing an application signed before a notarial officer or election official, and filing it with the county clerk not less than fourteen (14) days before the primary election or at the polls on the day of the primary or general election, or when requesting an absentee ballot.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S 1957, § 22.1-69; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2; 2008, ch. 20, § 2; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014; 2015 ch. 76, § 1, effective July 1, 2015.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

The 2008 amendment, effective July 1, 2008, substituted “notarial officer” for “notary.”

The 2014 amendment, substituted “fourteen (14)” for “thirty (30)”.

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, substituted “not less than” for “not later than.”

§ 22-5-215. Nomination of partisan candidates and write-in candidates.

On each party ballot the candidate or candidates equal in number to the number to be elected to each office who receive the largest number of votes shall be nominated and shall be entitled to have their names printed on the ballot for the next general election. A write-in candidate shall not be nominated and shall not be entitled to have his name printed on the ballot for the next general election unless he received at least twenty-five (25) write-in votes in the primary election and is a registered voter in the political party for which he was nominated on the day of the primary election. An unsuccessful candidate for office at a primary election whose name is printed on any party ballot may not accept nomination for the same office at the next general election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-70; Laws 1989, ch. 25, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 47, § 1; 2020 ch. 100, § 1, effective July 1, 2020.

Write-in candidate. —

A person who was defeated in a primary election as a candidate of one party, but who simultaneously received sufficient write-in votes in the separate primary election of the other party, has the right to appear on the general election ballot since the Election Code does not specifically prohibit such a result. Murphy v. State Canvassing Bd., 12 P.3d 677, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 205 (Wyo. 2000).

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, substituted “write-in votes in the primary election and is a registered voter in the political party for which he was nominated on the day of the primary election” for “write-in votes.”

§ 22-5-216. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2011, ch. 38, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, W.S. 1957, § 22.1-71, Laws 1981, ch. 159, § 1, 1998, ch. 100, § 2, 2007, ch. 39, § 1, related to nomination of nonpartisan candidates.

§ 22-5-217. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1977, ch. 186, § 1, provided that the candidates who receive the largest number of votes for each office are elected.

§ 22-5-218. Election of major party precinct committeemen and committeewomen.

The candidates equal in number to the number of offices to be filled receiving the greatest number of votes on each party ballot for the offices of major party precinct committeeman and committeewoman shall be deemed elected.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-72; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

§ 22-5-219. Further action by nominees or elect not required; exception.

  1. Candidates nominated and major party precinct committeemen and committeewomen elected at a primary election shall be deemed nominated or elected without further action. In addition, each write-in candidate nominated at a primary election shall comply with the provisions of W.S. 22-16-106.
  2. Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-73; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1977, ch. 186, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, §§ 2, 5; 2005, ch. 100, § 1; 2011, ch. 38, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, in (a), deleted “with the exception of the filing requirements of W.S. 22-25-106” at the end of the first sentence.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (a), deleted “or elected” following “candidate nominated” in the second sentence.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

For amount of filing fees, see § 22-5-208.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Elections: validity of state or local legislative ban on write-in votes, 69 ALR4th 948.

§ 22-5-220. Withdrawal of nomination application restricted.

A candidate may withdraw a nomination application prior to the primary election only by filing a written withdrawal in the filing office in which he filed his application for nomination.
