If a candidate withdraws after the party ballots are finalized and approved for printing by a county clerk in any county where the candidate’s name will appear on the party ballot, the county clerk shall not be required to remove the candidate’s name from the party ballot, but shall post a notice at each polling place announcing that the named candidate has withdrawn from nomination for the office designated.

History.

Laws 2009, ch. 100, § 1.

Effective dates. —

Laws 2009, ch. 100, § 4, makes the act effective July 1, 2009.

Article 3. Nomination by Petition

  • § 22-5-301.  Independent partisan candidates; form.
  • § 22-5-302.  Unsuccessful primary candidates precluded.
  • § 22-5-303.  Restrictions on sponsors of independent candidates.
  • § 22-5-304.  Qualifications and number of signers required.
  • § 22-5-305.  When petitions may be circulated; use of copies; requirements.
  • § 22-5-306.  Where petitions to be filed; fee.
  • § 22-5-307.  Time for filing independent petitions.
  • § 22-5-308.  Determining validity of petitions.

Applied in

Blomquist v. Thomson, 591 F. Supp. 768, 1984 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 19379 (D. Wyo. 1984).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

25 Am. Jur. 2d Elections §§ 247 to 254.

29 C.J.S. Elections § 106.

§ 22-5-301. Independent partisan candidates; form.

  1. Independent candidates for partisan public offices may be nominated by filing a signed petition in substantially the following form:
  2. The petition shall be approved by the appropriate filing office prior to circulation.

PETITION FOR NOMINATION I, , swear or affirm that I was born on , (year), that I have been a resident of the State of Wyoming since , and that I am a registered voter of Election District No. , in Precinct No., County of, residing at , (if for the office of state senator or representative, commissioner or other district office) in Senate (House) (Commissioner or other) District , State of Wyoming, (if for the office of governor) and that I resided at the physical residential addresses listed below during the past five (5) years, and having obtained the number of signatures required by law for nomination by petition, I hereby request that my name be printed on the official ballot at the next general election as an independent candidate for the office of and declare that if nominated and elected, I will qualify for the office. (If for the office of United States senator or representative in congress) I have not, at any time when knowingly seeking nomination or election to this office, claimed or been currently claiming any residence or received the benefits of residency from any other state, excluding the benefits of residency related to or incidental from maintaining a residence at or near the United States capital. (If for the office of governor) I have resided at the following physical residential addresses during the past five (5) years: (Residence) (Date) 1. 2. Dated the day of , (year). (Signature) The eligible, registered electors supporting my nomination, and numbering not less than the number required under W.S. 22-5-304, are as follows: (Signature) (Printed Name) (Residence) (Date) 1. 2. VERIFICATION BY CIRCULATORS I, , do hereby certify that I am a circulator of this petition, and I solely and personally circulated this petition, that all the signatures appearing herein were made in my presence from (month) (day), (year) through (month) (day), (year), and to the best of my knowledge and belief such signatures are those of the persons whose names they purport to be. (Signature)

Click to view

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-74; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1979, ch. 133, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1992, ch. 1, § 5; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 47, § 1; 2011, ch. 38, § 1; 2013 ch. 28, § 1, effective July 1, 2013; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014; 2019 ch. 4, § 1, effective February 13, 2019; 2021 ch. 167, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (a), inserted “commissioner or other district office” and “(Commissioner or other)” in the form, and substituted “the number required under W.S. 22-5-304” for “two percent (2%) of the total number of votes cast for Representative in Congress at the last general election in the political subdivision for which this petition is filed” in the second paragraph.

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, added (b).

The 2014 amendment, deleted “(Residence Address)” at the end of the form in (b).

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2021 amendment , effective July 1, 2021, added "(If for the office of United States senator or representative in congress) I have not, at any time when knowingly seeking nomination or election to this office, claimed or been currently claiming any residence or received the benefits of residency from any other state, excluding the benefits of residency related to or incidental from maintaining a residence at or near the United States capital" in (a).

Independent candidate and new political party failed to show likelihood of success on merits in challenge to statutory signature and deadline requirements. See Populist Party v. Herschler, 746 F.2d 656, 1984 U.S. App. LEXIS 17718 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1984).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Right of signer of petition to withdraw therefrom or revoke withdrawal, and time therefor, 27 ALR2d 604.

§ 22-5-302. Unsuccessful primary candidates precluded.

An unsuccessful candidate for office at a primary election, whose name is printed on any party ballot, may not seek nomination by petition for the same office at the next general election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-75; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 47, § 1.

§ 22-5-303. Restrictions on sponsors of independent candidates.

The name of a political group sponsoring an independent candidate shall not contain the name or any derivation of the name of any political party recognized under Wyoming law.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-76; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

§ 22-5-304. Qualifications and number of signers required.

  1. For a statewide partisan office, a petition shall be signed by registered electors, resident in the state and eligible to vote for the petitioner, numbering not less than two percent (2%) of the total number of votes cast for representative in congress in the last general election for the entire state.
  2. For a countywide partisan office, a petition shall be signed by registered electors, resident in the county and eligible to vote for the petitioner, numbering not less than two percent (2%) of the total number of votes cast for representative in congress in the last general election for the entire county.
  3. For a district partisan election, a petition shall be signed by registered electors, resident in the district and eligible to vote for the petitioner, numbering not less than two percent (2%) of the total number of votes cast for the office in that particular district in the last general election. If a district’s boundaries have changed since the last general election, then the required number of petition signatures shall not be less than two percent (2%) of the number of registered voters in the current district boundaries at the close of day on the day immediately preceding the primary election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-77; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1992, ch. 1, § 5; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2011, ch. 38, § 1.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (a), inserted “For a statewide partisan office,” and substituted “state” for “legislative district or other district or political subdivision in which the petitioner will be a candidate,” “the petitioner” for “him,” and “entire state” for “political subdivision or legislative district for which the petition is filed”; and added (b) and (c).

§ 22-5-305. When petitions may be circulated; use of copies; requirements.

  1. A petition shall be circulated for signatures only during the calendar year in which the election for the office sought is to be held.
  2. Copies of the petition may be circulated for signatures, but each separate page shall contain the information required to be contained in the original petition for nomination.
  3. An elector signing a petition must also print on the petition:
    1. The elector’s first and last name;
    2. The date of signing the petition; and
    3. The elector’s physical residential address.
  4. The signature of an elector who has signed a petition in accordance with this section shall only count once per candidate toward the number of signatures required under W.S. 22-5-304.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-78; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014; 2018 ch. 118, § 1, effective March 14, 2018.

The 2014 amendment, in (c), substituted “print on the petition” for “write,” substituted “his residence” for “the residence,” and deleted “after his signature.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2018 amendment, rewrote the existing language in (c), which read: “An elector signing a petition must also print on the petition his name, date and his residence address” and redesignated it as the present introductory language of (c) and (c)(i) through (c)(iii); and rewrote (d), which read: “The name of one (1) voter signed to more than one (1) petition for nomination to the same office shall not be counted on more than one (1) petition.”

Laws 2018, ch. 118, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 14, 2018.

§ 22-5-306. Where petitions to be filed; fee.

  1. Petitions for nomination of independent candidates shall be filed in the office prescribed for nomination by primary election for such office.
  2. Petitions must be accompanied by the same fee required for the same office of candidates seeking nomination by primary election. A petition not accompanied by the fee is not valid.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-79.

Cross references. —

For amount of filing fees, see § 22-5-208.

§ 22-5-307. Time for filing independent petitions.

Petitions filed with the secretary of state and with the county clerk shall be filed not less than seventy (70) days before a general election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-80; Laws 1985, ch. 204, § 1; 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

Independent candidate and new political party failed to show likelihood of success on merits in challenge to statutory signature and deadline requirements. See Populist Party v. Herschler, 746 F.2d 656, 1984 U.S. App. LEXIS 17718 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1984).

§ 22-5-308. Determining validity of petitions.

The secretary of state, or county clerk shall determine from the official list of registered electors whether sufficient valid signatures have been obtained on petitions filed in his office.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-81; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2.

Article 4. Vacancies in Nomination

  • § 22-5-401.  Vacancies in nomination for major parties; procedure for filing generally.
  • § 22-5-402.  Procedure after ballots and labels printed.
  • § 22-5-403.  Vacancies in nomination for minor and provisional parties; withdrawal restricted.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

26 Am. Jur. 2d Elections §§ 214, 215.

29 C.J.S. Elections §§ 182 to 184.

§ 22-5-401. Vacancies in nomination for major parties; procedure for filing generally.

  1. The vacancy in nomination which occurs if a major party candidate, between primary and general elections, dies, is disqualified to hold the office for which nominated, or files a withdrawal or rejection of nomination with the office where the candidate filed for nomination for election, shall be filled by certificate filed with the office which shall state:
    1. The cause of vacancy and name of the former nominee;
    2. The name, age, place of residence, post office address and qualifications of the successor nominee; and
    3. The office and term for which nominated.
  2. The certificate shall be prepared and filed by:
    1. The state central committee of the political party of the former nominee for a partisan office to be voted for by the electors of the entire state;
    2. The county central committee of the political party of the former nominee for a partisan office to be voted for by the electors of a county or a subdivision thereof, except as provided in paragraph (iv) of this subsection;
    3. Repealed by Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 2; ch. 94, § 4.
    4. For nominees for the state legislature, the state central committee of the political party of the former nominee for a partisan office shall:
      1. Notify the precinct committeemen and committeewomen for that party for each precinct within the legislative district of the vacancy and arrange a meeting of those precinct committeemen and committeewomen at which a successor nominee shall be selected by them. The state central committee of each party may delegate the authority to call a meeting under this subparagraph;
      2. Prepare and file the certificate required under subsection (a) of this section.
  3. Repealed by Laws 1985, ch. 204, § 2.
  4. Notwithstanding subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the vacancy in nomination created by failure of the qualified write-in nominee to accept nomination shall remain vacant.
  5. A candidate may withdraw only by filing a written withdrawal in the filing office in which he filed his application for nomination. If a candidate withdraws after the ballots are finalized and approved for printing by a county clerk in any county where the candidate’s name will appear on the ballot, the county clerk shall not be required to remove the candidate’s name from the ballot, but shall post a notice at each polling place announcing that the named candidate is not the party’s nominee for the office designated.
    1. through (iii) Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-82; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1979, ch. 133, § 2; 1985, ch. 204, §§ 1, 2; 1989, ch. 25, § 1; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1992, ch. 1, § 5; 1998, ch. 100, §§ 2, 5; 2001, ch. 116, § 1; 2004, ch. 42, § 4; ch. 94, § 4.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

As to filling vacancies in nomination for presidential elector, see § 22-19-105.

As to filling vacancies in nomination for municipal office, see § 22-23-308.

The 2004 amendments. —

The first 2004 amendment, by ch. 42, § 2, repealed former (b)(iii), which read: “The county bar association for the office of justice of the peace.”

Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 3, 2004.

The second 2004 amendment, by ch. 94, § 4, also repealed former (b)(iii), which read: “The county bar association for the office of justice of the peace.”

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 3, 2004.

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

Nomination by state central committee unauthorized. —

Statutes did not authorize state central committee to nominate candidate for office of secretary of state to fill unexpired term of one who died 26 days before general election date. State ex rel. Copenhaver v. Jack, 60 Wyo. 405, 153 P.2d 149, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1944).

Legislature has never recognized any power in political committees to make party nominations, except as delegated to it either by party convention or legislature. State ex rel. Copenhaver v. Jack, 60 Wyo. 405, 153 P.2d 149, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1944).

Nominee of different parties. —

Statute does not authorize printing of the name of one person as candidate for presidential elector in more than one place on the ticket, though nominated by two or more parties. State ex rel. Blydenburg v. Burdick, 6 Wyo. 448, 46 P. 854, 1896 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 1896).

Where one of three persons nominated by the Democratic state convention as presidential elector declined and the vacancy was filled by nomination by the state committee of one who had been previously nominated by the People's Party, there was no authority for printing such person's name in more than 1 place on the ticket or for taking it out of the group of People's Party candidates, it being proper to place the words “Democrat and People's” after his name to show he was the nominee of both parties. State ex rel. Blydenburg v. Burdick, 6 Wyo. 448, 46 P. 854, 1896 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 1896).

§ 22-5-402. Procedure after ballots and labels printed.

  1. If any major, minor or provisional party vacancy is filled after official ballots are finalized and approved for printing by a county clerk in any county where the candidate’s name will appear on the ballot, the county clerk shall not be required to add the new candidate’s name to the ballot.
    1. through (iii) Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-83; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, §§ 2, 5.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 22-5-403. Vacancies in nomination for minor and provisional parties; withdrawal restricted.

  1. Any vacancy in nomination which occurs if a minor or provisional party certified candidate dies, is disqualified to hold the office for which nominated or files a withdrawal or rejection of nomination may be filled by a certification from the state party chairman and state party secretary.
  2. A candidate may withdraw only by filing a written withdrawal in the filing office in which he filed his application for nomination. If a candidate withdraws after the ballots are finalized and approved for printing by a county clerk in any county where the candidate’s name will appear on the ballot, the county clerk shall not be required to remove the candidate’s name from the ballot, but shall post a notice at each polling place announcing that the named candidate is not the party’s nominee for the office designated.
    1. through (iii) Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

History.

Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, §§ 2, 5.

Article 5. Valid Write-In Candidates

  • § 22-5-501.  Qualifying as a write-in candidate. [Repealed]

§ 22-5-501. Qualifying as a write-in candidate. [Repealed]

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

26 Am. Jur. 2d Elections §§ 312 to 347.

29 C.J.S. Elections §§ 260 to 307.

§ 22-6-101. Certification of candidates nominated; printing of names.

Not less than sixty (60) days before each general election the secretary of state shall transmit to each county clerk under party headings a certified list of the name and address of each person nominated by primary election as indicated by the state canvass, the name of each person nominated by provisional or minor party convention, the name of each independent candidate qualifying for nomination by petition, and the office sought. The names of these candidates shall be printed on the official ballot of the general election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-84; Laws 1985, ch. 204, § 1; 1990, ch. 42, § 1; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 2008, ch. 115, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

The 2008 amendment, substituted “transmit to each county clerk under party headings a certified list of” for “certify to each county clerk under party headings” in the first sentence.

Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

Stated in

Populist Party v. Herschler, 746 F.2d 656, 1984 U.S. App. LEXIS 17718 (10th Cir. 1984).

§ 22-6-102. County clerk to print ballots; exception.

  1. The county clerk shall print official ballots for his county, for all primary, general and special elections.
  2. All other ballots shall be provided by the official responsible for conducting the election.

History:

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-85; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014.

The 2014 amendment, in the first sentence of (a), deleted “and ballot labels where necessary,” deleted “and,” and inserted “and special”; and deleted the last sentence of (a) which read: “For use on voting machines the county clerk shall print ballot labels in black ink on white material containing the names of candidates or other words required by law.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

Cited in

State ex rel. Willis v. Larson, 539 P.2d 352, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 157 (Wyo. 1975).

§ 22-6-103. Official ballots.

  1. The official ballot shall contain the name of every candidate and every ballot proposition lawfully entitled to appear on the ballot. Only official ballots shall be cast at any election.
  2. The official absentee ballot shall be in the form prescribed by law for the official ballot.

History:

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-86; Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 2; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014.

The 2004 amendment added (b), redesignating the existing provision as (a).

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2004.

The 2014 amendment , deleted “or a reasonable printed reproduction of the prescribed frm for electronic ballots” at the end of (b).

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

§ 22-6-104. Sample ballots; printing, distribution, posting.

The officer providing the official ballot shall also print sample ballots which shall be identical to the official ballot except that it shall contain the words “SAMPLE” in large clear letters and may be printed on paper of a different color than the official ballot. The officer shall distribute copies of the sample ballot to each polling place prior to opening of the polls. The judges of election shall post at least one (1) copy of the sample in the polling place during the election. The county clerk shall have the samples available in his office for the public.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-87; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

The 2014 amendment, in the first sentence, deleted “or voting machine label,” deleted “or voting machine facsimile,” substituted “SAMPLE” for “SAMPLE BALLOT,” and deleted “or label”; in the second sentence, deleted “or voting machine facsimile”; and in the third sentence, substituted “one (1) copy” for “three (3) copies,” and deleted “and around.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2015 amendment, in the second sentence, substituted “polling place” for “precinct.”

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

§ 22-6-105. Sample ballots; publication.

The officer providing the official ballots shall publish sample ballots at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the district in which each primary and general election is held within two (2) weeks prior to the election. This notice shall also state that the names of candidates will be rotated on the official ballots and will not always appear in the order indicated in the sample ballots.

History:

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-88; Laws 1979, ch. 133, § 2; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014.

The 2014 amendment, in the first sentence, deleted “paper,” and deleted “and voting machine facsimiles.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 10, 2014.

§ 22-6-106. Replacement of lost ballots.

Official ballots not delivered to a polling place or lost, stolen or destroyed shall be replaced immediately by the official providing the ballot. Judges of election receiving replacement ballots shall sign a receipt therefor in which they shall state under oath, before each other, that the original ballots were not delivered to the precinct or have been lost, stolen or destroyed.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-89; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

The 2014 amendment, deleted “or ballot labels” in the first sentence.

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2015 amendment, substituted “polling place” for “precinct.”

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

§ 22-6-107. Time for possession of ballots and labels.

  1. Official ballots for primary and general elections shall be in the county clerk’s possession forty-five (45) days before the election. If a clerk is unable to obtain ballots on time, the secretary of state shall provide by rule and regulation for the clerk to obtain and use substitute ballots.
  2. Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, county clerks shall make official absentee ballots for primary and general elections available to voters with rights under the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act, 42 U.S.C. 1973ff, and future acts amendatory or supplemental thereto, forty-five (45) days before the election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-90; Laws 1985, ch. 204, § 1; 1990, ch. 42, § 1; 2007, ch. 39, § 1; 2011, ch. 15, § 1; 2020 ch. 100, § 1, effective July 1, 2020.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, added the last sentence.

The 2011 amendment, in (a), added the designation, deleted “and labels” following “Official ballots”; and added (b).

Laws 2011, ch. 15 § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved February 17, 2011.

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (a) substituted “forty-five (45) days” for “forty (40) days.”

Stated in

Populist Party v. Herschler, 746 F.2d 656, 1984 U.S. App. LEXIS 17718 (10th Cir. 1984).

§ 22-6-108. Errors or omissions; posting.

  1. The official responsible for preparing the ballot shall correct errors or omissions as soon as possible.
  2. The official shall post a copy of each ballot in his office not later than the day when the official must have the ballot in his possession.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-91; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

Mandamus. —

In mandamus to state canvassing board where it is alleged relator's name was unlawfully printed upon official ballots, court is obliged to consider incidentally, but not finally, every question affecting propriety of its issuing peremptory writ, without relator's ultimate right to office being determined. State ex rel. Bennett v. Barber, 4 Wyo. 56, 32 P. 14, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1892).

§ 22-6-109. Elector's petition alleging error or omission.

  1. Not later than three (3) days after the ballot is posted an elector may file a notarized affidavit with the county clerk alleging that an error or omission exists in any official ballot to be voted within the county. The county clerk shall, if the affidavit has merit, correct the error or omission as soon as possible.
  2. Not earlier than three (3) days and not more than six (6) days after filing the notarized affidavit with the county clerk, if the clerk fails to correct the alleged error or omission, the elector may file a petition in district court alleging that an error or omission exists in any official ballot to be voted within the county. The court shall, as soon as practical, order the ballot corrected or dismiss the petition.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-92; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Cited in

Karn v. Hayes, 530 P.2d 156, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 121 (Wyo. 1975).

§ 22-6-110. Ballot propositions.

A ballot proposition shall be printed as nearly as possible in the manner and form prescribed by law for a constitutional amendment.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-93.

Cross references. —

As to amendments to constitution, see art. 20, § 1, Wyo. Const., and §§ 22-20-101 to 22-20-109.

§ 22-6-111. Only name of candidate on ballot; exception.

A candidate may use the name on the ballot by which he is generally known. Professional titles and degrees shall not appear on the ballot. If in the opinion of the officer with whom the application for nomination or election is filed the names of two (2) or more candidates for any office to be voted on at the same election are the same or so similar as to confuse the electors as to the candidates’ identity, the occupation and residence address of each of these candidates shall be printed under the candidate’s name on the ballot.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-94.

§ 22-6-112. Name to appear only once; exception.

  1. No candidate’s name shall appear on the partisan ballot more than once, except that of a candidate for the office of precinct committeeman or committeewoman, who may also seek the office of president or vice president of the United States or another office on the same partisan primary ballot.
  2. No candidate’s name shall appear on the general election ballot more than once, except that a candidate for a partisan office may also seek the office of president or vice president of the United States or a nonpartisan office on the same general election ballot in accordance with W.S. 22-2-116.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-95; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 2020 ch. 100, § 1, effective July 1, 2020.

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, designated the undesignated paragraph as (a) and substituted “seek the office of president or vice president of the United States or another office” for “seek another office”; and added (b).

§ 22-6-113. More than 1 ballot on machine.

More than one (1) ballot may appear on a voting machine but if several ballots are placed on a machine they shall be clearly separated to prevent confusion.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-96.

§ 22-6-114. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, related to the prohibition against certain parties, groups or organizations appearing on the election ballot.

§ 22-6-115. Specifications for paper ballots; arrangements on voting machines.

Official paper ballots shall be uniform in size, printed in black ink on good quality paper through which printing cannot be read. Ballots shall be white except as otherwise provided. On a voting machine each column or row containing the titles of offices and candidates for office shall be arranged to indicate clearly the office for which a candidate is running.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-98.

§ 22-6-116. Printing type size of party and candidate names.

On official ballots the political party name or title shall be printed in capital letters not less than one-eighth (1/8) inch nor more than one-fourth (1/4) of an inch in height. The names of all candidates shall be printed in the same size letters not less than one-eighth (1/8) inch nor more than one-fourth (1/4) of an inch in height. The name of each political party shall be printed in the same type size as that of every other political party.

History:

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-99; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1997, ch. 40, § 1; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014.

The 2014 amendment , in the first sentence, deleted “and ballot labels.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 10, 2014.

§ 22-6-117. Order of listing offices in partisan elections.

  1. The major party primary and general partisan election ballots shall contain the offices to be voted on in the following order:
    1. President and vice-president of the United States, or electors therefor, or as otherwise required by an act of congress;
    2. United States senator;
    3. Representative in congress;
    4. Candidates for governor, secretary of state, state auditor, state treasurer, and superintendent of public instruction;
    5. Repealed by Laws 1992, ch. 1, § 7.
    6. Candidates for state senate;
    7. Candidates for state house of representatives;
    8. Repealed by Laws 2014, ch. 108, §  2.
    9. Candidates for county commissioner, coroner, district attorney, county attorney, sheriff, clerk, treasurer, assessor, and clerk of the district court;
    10. Repealed by Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 2.
    11. Candidates for precinct offices.

History:

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-100; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1992, ch. 1, §§ 5, 7; 2008, ch. 115, § 2; 2014 ch. 108, §§ 1, 2, effective March 10, 2014.

The 2008 amendment, repealed (a)(x) which read: “Candidates for offices of county subdivisions.”

Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

The 2014 amendment, in (a)(ix), inserted “district attorney, county”; and repealed former (a)(viii), which read: “Candidates for district attorney.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 10, 2014.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 22-6-118. Primary ballot colors.

  1. The primary ballot of political parties shall be printed on the following colored paper or on paper with the following color demarcation as provided by rule and regulation of the secretary of state:
    1. Republican party — White;
    2. Democratic party — Blue;
    3. Repealed by Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 5.
    4. Additional major parties — A different color for each major party.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-101; Laws 1991, ch. 243, §§ 2, 5; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2007, ch. 39, § 1.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, added “or on paper with the following color demarcation as provided by rule and regulation of the secretary of state” in the introductory language in (a).

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 22-6-119. Format of primary ballot.

  1. The primary ballot of each major political party shall be printed in substantial compliance with this format:
    1. Across the top shall be printed “Official Primary Election Ballot” followed by the name of the major political party;
    2. On the first line shall be printed the county in which the ballot is used, the date of the election and blank lines for entry of the election district and precinct;
    3. On the second line shall be printed the following instructions: “To vote for a person whose name is printed on the ballot, mark the square immediately adjacent to the name of the person for whom you desire to vote. To vote for a person whose name is not printed on the ballot, write the person’s name in the blank space provided for that purpose and mark the square immediately adjacent to the name of the person.”;
    4. Candidates for the different offices shall be arranged in separate groups. At the top of each group shall appear the title of the office. Adjacent to the title of the office shall be printed “Vote for one” or if more than one (1) are to be voted for, “Vote for not more than”, then the appropriate words and figures designating the proper number to be elected;
    5. Below the list of candidates in each group shall be printed blank lines for write-in candidates equal in number to the number of candidates to be voted for;
    6. Adjacent to the name of each candidate and blank line shall be printed a square for marking the vote. No square shall appear at the top of a column;
    7. and (viii) Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-102; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, §§ 2, 5; 2007, ch. 39, § 1; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014; 2021 ch. 145, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, in (a), substituted “adjacent to” for “to the right of” in (i) and (vi); and substituted “Adjacent to the title of the office” for “On the same line and to the right.”

The 2014 amendment, deleted “Partisan” in (a)(i).

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2021 amendment , effective July 1, 2021, in the second sentence of (a)(iii), substituted "the person's" for "his."

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears on the printed acts.

§ 22-6-120. Format of general election ballot.

  1. The general election ballot shall be printed in substantial compliance with this format:
    1. Across the top shall be printed “Official General Election Ballot”;
    2. On the first line shall be printed the name of the county in which the ballot is used, the date of the election, and blank lines for entry of the election district and precinct number;
    3. On the second line shall be printed the same instructions as prescribed for primary elections in W.S. 22-6-119;
    4. The designation of offices and the applicable term of office shall be printed preceding the names of candidates for the office;
    5. and (vi) Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.
    6. The names of partisan party candidates, if candidates have filed, and independent candidates, if candidates have filed, shall be printed in a separate column or columns, row or rows, and the name of the party represented or the word “Independent” shall be printed directly above the candidate’s name or at the end of the row. If there are a number of candidates representing a party, or independents, the county clerk at his discretion may designate a separate vertical column or columns, or row or rows to said candidates and print the name of said party or the word “Independent” at the top of the column or beginning of the row;
    7. Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.
    8. For offices to which more than one (1) person is to be elected, the names of candidates in each column running for the office shall be offset or staggered to prevent two (2) names from appearing directly opposite each other;
    9. Below the names of candidates for each office shall be printed blank lines for write-in candidates equal in number to the number of persons to be elected;
    10. Adjacent to the name of each candidate, except those running for the office of president and vice-president of the United States and their electors, and adjacent to each blank line for write-in candidates, shall be printed a square for marking the vote. A single square shall be printed to indicate the vote for candidates for the office of president and vice-president of the United States. No square shall appear at the top of a column;
    11. Adjacent to the description of any office to be filled by more than one (1) candidate shall be printed “Vote For Not More Than”, then the appropriate words and figures designating the proper number to be elected;
    12. Vertical columns containing the names of candidates shall be separated by a blank line one-twelfth inch wide;
    13. The official statement of the ballot proposition shall commence on the next line;
    14. Adjacent to the final line of such statement shall be printed two (2) squares on the same line. Above the first square shall be printed the word “For” and above the second square shall be printed the word “Against”;
    15. Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

History:

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-103; Laws 1977, ch. 186, § 2; 1983, ch. 107, § 1; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, §§ 2, 5; 2007, ch. 39, § 1; 2008, ch. 115, § 1; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, in (a), substituted “Adjacent to” for “to the right of” in (xi) and (xii) and made a similar change in (xv).

The 2008 amendment, in (a)(vii), added “if candidates have filed” in the first sentence, added “or row or rows” in the last sentence, added “or beginning of the row” at the end.

Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

The 2014 amendment, effective July 1, 2014, in the introductory paragraph of (a), deleted “partisan”; and in (a)(i), deleted “Partisan.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 22-6-121. Political party ballot position on general election ballot; order of candidates' names.

  1. Political party position shall be determined on the general election ballot according to the number of votes received by each party within the county for the office of representative in congress at the last preceding general election. The party receiving the highest number of votes shall appear first following the names of the offices to be voted for and other parties shall follow in the order of their respective numbers of such votes. The order of any provisional parties will be drawn by the secretary of state. Any independent candidates shall appear following the last party and shall be listed in alphabetical order, subject to rotation. When more than one (1) candidate is to be elected to a particular office, the names of candidates shall be printed in alphabetical order, subject to rotation, on all ballots for electronic and machine voting systems as defined by W.S. 22-1-102.
    1. through (iii) Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-104; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, §§ 2, 5; 2007, ch. 39, § 1.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, inserted the second to last sentence in (a).

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 22-6-122. Rotation of candidates’ names; equal lines on voting machines.

The names of candidates for each office shall be rotated on all ballots by precinct for all elections. In each county the name of each candidate shall appear substantially an equal number of times at the top, at the bottom, and in each intermediate place. In a voting machine polling place, if candidates for the same office occupy more than one (1) line on the voting machine, the number of names appearing on each line shall be as nearly equal as possible.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-105; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

The 2015 amendment, in the last sentence, substituted “polling place” for “precinct.”

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

§ 22-6-123. Nonpartisan election ballots and ballot propositions.

Primary and general election ballots for nonpartisan offices and ballot propositions shall be printed on yellow paper or paper with yellow demarcation as provided by rule and regulation of the secretary of state, separate from partisan ballots. They shall contain no political party designations, but otherwise shall conform to the same general requirements for official partisan ballots except as otherwise specifically provided.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-106; Laws 1981, ch. 159, § 1; 2007, ch. 39, § 1.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, inserted “or paper with yellow demarcation as provided by rule and regulation of the secretary of state.”

§ 22-6-124. Ballot propositions format.

Following all offices on nonpartisan ballots, ballot propositions shall be printed in the order prescribed by law. The name and official number, if any, of each ballot proposition shall be printed adjacent to the proposition in large letters. Nonpartisan ballots shall contain the same instructions as prescribed for partisan primary election ballots in W.S. 22-6-119. If the ballot contains a proposed constitutional amendment or other ballot proposition, the instructions shall also include the following: “To vote for or against a proposed constitutional amendment, initiative or referendum, or other ballot proposition, mark the square printed adjacent to the proposition marked ‘For’ or ‘Against’.”

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-107; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 2007, ch. 39, § 1.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, substituted “adjacent to the proposition” for “at the left margin” in the second sentence, and substituted “adjacent to” for “to the right of” in the last sentence.

§ 22-6-125. Order of offices and ballot propositions on nonpartisan ballots.

  1. The nonpartisan ballot shall contain the offices and ballot propositions to be voted on in the following order:
    1. Retention of justices of the supreme court;
    2. Retention of district court judges;
    3. Retention of circuit court judges;
    4. Retention of magistrates;
    5. Repealed by Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 2; ch. 94, § 4.
    6. Candidates for municipal offices;
    7. Candidates for community college trustees;
    8. Candidates for school board trustees;
    9. Candidates for special district directors;
    10. Candidates for other offices of county subdivisions;
    11. Constitutional amendments;
    12. Initiative propositions;
    13. Referendum propositions;
    14. Other ballot propositions.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-108; Laws 1979, ch. 133, § 2; 2000, ch. 24, § 4; 2004, ch. 42, § 2; ch. 94, § 4; 2008, ch. 115, § 1.

The 2004 amendments. —

The first 2004 amendment, by ch. 42, § 2, repealed former (a)(v), which read: “Justice of the peace;”.

Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 3, 2004.

The second 2004 amendment, by ch. 94, § 4, also repealed former (a)(v).

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2004.

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

The 2008 amendment, inserted present (a)(vi) through (a)(x) and redesignated the remaining subsections accordingly.

Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 22-6-126. Form of nonpartisan ballots.

  1. The official nonpartisan ballot for a general election shall be printed in substantially the following form:
  2. The official nonpartisan ballot for a primary election shall be so identified in the title and shall omit all references to justices of the supreme court, judges of the district court and circuit court judges but otherwise shall be in the same form as the general election nonpartisan ballot.

OFFICIAL NONPARTISAN ELECTION BALLOT GENERAL ELECTION County of , Election District , Precinct Date (here print instructions) CANDIDATES FOR PUBLIC OFFICE For Justice(s) of the Supreme Court (Here designate the particular term, such as “regular eight (8) year term”, or the “unexpired term of years”). Shall Justice John Roe be retained in office? Yes No • • Shall Justice Richard Roe be retained in office? Yes No • • For Judge(s) of the District Court of the Judicial District (Here designate the particular term, such as “regular six (6) year term”, or the “unexpired term of years”). Shall Judge Jane Roe be retained in office? Yes No • • Shall Judge Richard Roe be retained in office? Yes No • • For Circuit Court Judge (Here designate the particular term, such as “regular four- year term”, or the “unexpired term of years”). Shall Judge John Doe be retained in office? Yes No • • Shall Judge Richard Roe be retained in office? Yes No • • For Magistrate (Here designate the particular term, such as “regular four (4) year term”, or the “unexpired term of years”). Shall Magistrate John Doe be retained in office? Yes No • • Shall Magistrate Richard Roe be retained in office? Yes No • • Align all designations of office to correspond on the ballot with the listing of names of candidates for the proper office and term. BALLOT PROPOSITIONS Proposed Constitutional Amendment Letter A: For Against (Ballot Statement) • • Proposed Initiative Proposition Number One: For Against (Ballot Statement) • • Proposed Referendum Proposition Number One: For Against (Ballot Statement) • • Other Ballot Propositions: For Against (Ballot Statement For Each Proposition) • •

Click to view

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-109; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1979, ch. 133, § 2; 1995, ch. 115, § 1; 2000, ch. 24, § 4; 2004, ch. 42, § 1; ch. 94, § 2.

The 2004 amendments. —

The first 2004 amendment, by ch. 42, § 1, in (a), deleted the provisions pertaining to the justice of the peace.

Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 3, 2004.

The second 2004 amendment, by ch. 94, § 2, also deleted the provisions pertaining to the justice of the peace.

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2004.

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

Law reviews. —

For article, “Ousting the Judge: Campaign Politics in the 1984 Wyoming Judicial Retention Elections,” see XXIV Land & Water L. Rev. 371 (1989).

§ 22-6-127. Rotation of names on nonpartisan ballots.

  1. The names of candidates for each nonpartisan office shall be rotated on the ballot in the same manner as required by law for candidates for partisan office.
  2. Rotation is not necessary if the number of candidates is equal to or less than the number of seats up for election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-110; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

§ 22-6-128. Ballots for other elections.

At the county clerk’s discretion, separate ballots for bond, school and community college districts, and special district elections may be required and shall be provided by the authority responsible for holding the election. Ballots shall conform as nearly as possible to general requirements specified by law for the general election ballot, except as otherwise specifically provided.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-111; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to bond elections, see §§ 22-21-101 to 22-21-112.

As to school elections, see §§ 22-22-101 to 22-22-304.

§ 22-6-129. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which was derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-112; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2, related to the number of ballots to be provided.

Chapter 7 Election Districts and Precincts

  • § 22-7-101.  Election districts.
  • § 22-7-102.  Change in precinct boundary.
  • § 22-7-103.  Establishing or altering election districts or precincts; designation of special precincts.
  • § 22-7-104.  Procedure following resolution altering precinct area.
  • § 22-7-105.  Election district number to precede precinct number.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

25 Am. Jur. 2d Elections §§ 8 to 85.

29 C.J.S. Elections §§ 73 to 101.

§ 22-7-101. Election districts.

The board of county commissioners with the advice or recommendation of the county clerk, no later than its first meeting in May in every general election year shall divide the county into not more than thirty (30) election districts. Each district shall be designated by number. Election districts shall be changed only at this designated meeting.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-113; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 2001, ch. 29, § 1; 2012, ch. 9, § 1.

The 2012 amendment, substituted “May” for “April” in the first sentence.

Laws 2012, ch. 9 § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 6, 2012.

§ 22-7-102. Change in precinct boundary.

  1. A precinct boundary shall not be changed unless a notice describing all proposed changes is posted on the county’s official website in the manner provided in W.S. 18-3-516(f) and published once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the designated official newspaper of the county. The board shall also mail by certified mail return receipt requested copy of this notice to the county chairman of each political party in the county not later than fifteen (15) days before the meeting at which the proposed changes will be discussed. A proposed change in a precinct boundary may be finalized by the board only at the designated meeting. Each precinct shall be designated by number.
  2. However, changes to municipal precinct boundaries due to the annexation of any territory shall be effective upon the date provided in the ordinance.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-114; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 2014 ch. 93, § 1, effective July 1, 2014.

The 2014 amendment, in (a), substituted “changes is posted on the county's official website in the manner provided in W.S. 18-3-516(f) and published once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the designated official newspaper of the county” for “changes is published once a week for three (3) consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the county” in the first sentence.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-7-103. Establishing or altering election districts or precincts; designation of special precincts.

  1. In establishing or altering election districts or voting precincts, the board of county commissioners shall be guided by the interests and convenience of the greatest number of electors involved. Election districts and voting precincts shall coincide with the boundary of a municipality or ward therein and school and community college trustee residence areas and shall not cross municipal boundaries except in cases where the board of county commissioners finds, and specifies in the minutes of its meeting the reasons why it is not practical to conform the boundaries of the election district or precinct to the municipal boundary.
  2. For elections other than the primary and general election, the county commissioners may designate different precincts than those used in the general election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-115; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

§ 22-7-104. Procedure following resolution altering precinct area.

Within five (5) days after the adoption of a resolution dividing or consolidating a precinct, or changing a precinct boundary, the county clerk shall send a certified copy of the resolution to the secretary of state and to the county chairman of each political party and notify by mail all registered electors receiving a new precinct number.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-116; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-7-105. Election district number to precede precinct number.

Whenever they are both referred to, the election district number shall precede the voting precinct number.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-117.

Chapter 8 Judges of Election and Counting Boards

  • § 22-8-101.  Notice of election officials needed; county chairmen to submit list of names; municipal clerks list of names appointment.
  • § 22-8-102.  Qualifications.
  • § 22-8-103.  Terms.
  • § 22-8-104.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-8-105.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-8-106.  Number of judges in each polling place.
  • § 22-8-107.  Absentee ballot counting boards.
  • § 22-8-108.  Appointment, composition and authority of counting boards; when judges to count.
  • § 22-8-109.  Party representation.
  • § 22-8-110.  Notice of appointment.
  • § 22-8-111.  Acceptance of appointment.
  • § 22-8-112.  Filling vacancies.
  • § 22-8-113.  Training schools; generally and payment for attending.
  • § 22-8-114.  Training schools; mileage payment and certificate.
  • § 22-8-115.  Oath for election officials.
  • § 22-8-116.  Compensation.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

25 Am. Jur. 2d Elections §§ 86 to 99.

29 C.J.S. Elections §§ 102 to 126.

§ 22-8-101. Notice of election officials needed; county chairmen to submit list of names; municipal clerks list of names appointment.

  1. Not later than the third Tuesday of April in each general election year, each county clerk shall notify the county chairmen of the major and minor political parties in the county of the number of election judges and counting board members and alternates needed for the ensuing two (2) year term.
  2. Not later than the third Tuesday of May in each general election year the county chairman of each major and minor political party in each county may certify to the county clerk a list of registered electors residing in the county and affiliated with the party, and a list of persons who are at least sixteen (16) years of age who otherwise meet all requirements for qualification as an elector, who are willing to serve as a judge of election or as a member of a counting board.
  3. Not later than the third Tuesday of May in each general election year municipal clerks may submit to the county clerk a list of registered electors, and a list of persons who are at least sixteen (16) years of age who otherwise meet all requirements for qualification as an elector, residing in the municipality they represent who are willing to serve as a judge of election or as a member of a counting board.
  4. Not later than June 30, the county clerk on each general election year shall appoint judges of election and counting boards and alternates from lists submitted by the county chairmen of the major and minor political parties.
  5. If the list of nominees for judges of election and members of counting boards provided by the county chairman is insufficient, the county clerk shall consider the list submitted by the municipal clerks and may appoint any elector otherwise qualified to be a judge of election or a member of a counting board.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-118; Laws 1985, ch. 119, § 1; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2005, ch. 104, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, inserted “and a list of persons who are at least sixteen (16) years of age who otherwise meet all requirements for qualification as an elector” in (b) and (c).

§ 22-8-102. Qualifications.

Except as otherwise provided by this section, judges of election and members of counting boards shall be registered electors and shall be physically, morally and mentally competent to perform their duties. The county clerk may appoint persons who are at least sixteen (16) years of age to serve as judges of election or members of counting boards if such persons meet all other requirements for qualification of an elector. A judge of election shall not be a member of a counting board at the same election except as provided by W.S. 22-8-108(d).

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-119; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2; 2005, ch. 104, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, added the exception at the beginning and inserted the second sentence.

§ 22-8-103. Terms.

Judges of election and members of counting boards serve for two (2) years or until their successors are appointed.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-120.

§ 22-8-104. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1985, ch. 119, § 2.

Cross references. —

For present provisions as to certification of a list of registered electors willing to serve as election officials, see § 22-8-101.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, related to providing of lists by county chairmen of political parties.

§ 22-8-105. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, authorized the county clerk to appoint an elector qualified to be judge of election or member of a counting board where the list of nominees for such was insufficient.

§ 22-8-106. Number of judges in each polling place.

At least three (3) judges shall be appointed for each polling place. Additional judges may be appointed in a polling place as determined necessary by the county clerk.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-123; Laws 1990, ch. 42, § 1; 2005, ch. 104, § 1; 2007, ch. 39, § 1; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, added the last sentence.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, deleted the last sentence, which read: “No more than one (1) person under the age of eighteen (18) may be appointed as an election judge for each precinct.”

The 2015 amendment, substituted “polling place” for “precinct” twice.

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

§ 22-8-107. Absentee ballot counting boards.

If the alternate procedure for counting absentee ballots described in W.S. 22-9-125 is used, at least three (3) judges shall be appointed as an absentee ballot counting board in the same manner as other election judges are appointed. These judges shall determine legality of absentee ballots and count absentee ballots or in the case of electronic voting systems, the ballots shall be counted at the designated counting center.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-124; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1985, ch. 119, § 1; 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

§ 22-8-108. Appointment, composition and authority of counting boards; when judges to count.

  1. The county clerk shall appoint a counting board for each paper ballot polling place casting more than three hundred (300) votes at the last general election, and may appoint a counting board in such a polling place in which one hundred fifty (150) or more such votes were cast at such election. A counting board shall have three (3) members or more to facilitate the counting of votes. No more than one (1) person under the age of eighteen (18) may be appointed as to each counting board.
  2. A counting board shall be appointed for each designated counting center in each county using an electronic voting system. The board shall consist of at least seven (7) members who shall be the county clerk or his designated deputy, and three (3) members of each major political party appointed by the county clerk. Additional members may be appointed by the county clerk if deemed necessary by the county clerk but equal major party membership shall be assured. No more than one (1) person under the age of eighteen (18) may be appointed as to each counting board.
  3. The counting board in a paper ballot polling place has no authority to act until polls are declared closed. A counting board in an electronic voting system counting center may commence preparing absentee ballots for counting at any time on the day of the election.
  4. For a polling place where a counting board need not be appointed, the judges of election shall count the votes.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 51, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-125; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1990, ch. 42, § 1; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2005, ch. 104, § 1; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, added the last sentence in (a) and (b).

The 2015 amendment, substituted “polling place” for “precinct” in (a), (c), and (d).

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

§ 22-8-109. Party representation.

Judges and members of counting boards shall be divided between the participating political parties as nearly equal as possible.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-126; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

§ 22-8-110. Notice of appointment.

The county clerk shall immediately mail a notice of appointment to each person selected to serve as a judge of election or a member of a counting board or alternate. The notice shall also state that attendance at the training school for election officials is required unless similar training is otherwise completed to the satisfaction of the county clerk.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-127; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2.

§ 22-8-111. Acceptance of appointment.

With each notice of appointment delivered by the county clerk there shall be a form for acceptance of the appointment or notice that each appointee shall be required to notify the county clerk of acceptance. The county clerk shall state the date by which the appointee shall be required to notify the clerk of acceptance. Failure of an appointee to notify the county clerk of acceptance within the time allotted by the county clerk results in a vacancy.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-128; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2015 ch. 76, § 1, effective July 1, 2015.

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, rewrote the section, which read: “With each notice of appointment mailed by the county clerk there shall be a form for acceptance of the appointment. Each appointee shall file his acceptance with the county clerk within twelve (12) days after the acceptance form is mailed by the county clerk. Failure of an appointee to file an acceptance within twelve (12) days results in a vacancy.”

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-8-112. Filling vacancies.

  1. Any vacancy occurring prior to an election day shall be filled by the county clerk from the list of alternates. If no alternates exist, any elector who is qualified may be appointed. Any expedient method of notice of appointment to the county clerk and to the appointee may be used. Vacancies may be filled temporarily or for the term.
  2. If a judge is not present when polls open, or is unable to complete his duties, the vacancy shall be filled by a registered elector appointed by those judges present at the precinct polling place when the vacancy occurs and approved by the county clerk. If a member of a counting board is not present when the polls close, or is unable to complete his duties, the vacancy shall be filled by a registered elector appointed by those members of the counting board who are present.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-129; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2; 2008, ch. 115, § 1.

The 2008 amendment, added “and approved by the county clerk” in (b).

Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

§ 22-8-113. Training schools; generally and payment for attending.

Not later than four (4) days before the primary and general election, the county clerk under the direction of the secretary of state shall conduct a training school for judges of election and members of counting boards to provide instruction in the performance of their duties. The training school, which is also open to the public, shall be held at the times and places announced by the county clerk, and the secretary of state shall prescribe the minimum curriculum for the school. Additional schools may be held at the discretion of the county clerk. Unless training is otherwise provided to the satisfaction of the county clerk, all judges of election and members of counting boards are obligated to attend at least one (1) such school. All judges and members of the counting board shall be paid not less than ten dollars ($10.00) as determined by the board of county commissioners for attending a school.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-130; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2008, ch. 115, § 1; 2013 ch. 31, § 1, effective July 1, 2013.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

The 2008 amendment, substituted “secretary of state shall conduct” for “secretary of state and the county attorney shall conduct” in the first sentence.

Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, substituted “ten dollars ($10.00)” for “five dollars ($5.00) nor more than twenty five dollars ($25.00)” in the last sentence.

§ 22-8-114. Training schools; mileage payment and certificate.

Judges of election and members of counting boards and their alternates will be paid mileage in excess of five (5) miles at the rate authorized for county employees for attendance at training schools. The county clerk shall issue a certificate to all election officials and alternates who attend the school. This certificate expires two (2) years from the date of issue.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-131; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

§ 22-8-115. Oath for election officials.

  1. An election official shall subscribe to this oath in writing before entering upon his duties at each election:
  2. The oath shall be taken before the county clerk, his deputy or a previously sworn judge of election.

“I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will impartially and to the best of my knowledge and ability perform the duties of my office. I will studiously endeavor to prevent all frauds, deceit and abuse in the application of the election laws of this state.”

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-132; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to oath of office generally, see art. 6, § 20, Wyo. Const.

§ 22-8-116. Compensation.

Judges of election and members of counting boards shall be compensated for services at a rate to be determined by the board of county commissioners at the June meeting and stated on the notice sent to each nominee. The rate shall be not less than the state minimum wage. Compensation shall begin one (1) hour before a member assumes his duties. The election official who delivers the returns shall receive additional compensation for necessary travel beyond ten (10) miles at the rate authorized for county employees. If a flat rate is paid, said sum shall not be less than the state hourly minimum wage multiplied by the number of hours the polls are open plus one (1) hour.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-133; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to reimbursement of county employees for necessary travel, see § 18-3-110.

As to minimum wage, see § 27-4-202.

Chapter 9 Absentee Voting

  • § 22-9-101.  Duty to assist absent electors to vote.
  • § 22-9-102.  Who may vote by absentee ballot.
  • § 22-9-103.  Where to apply.
  • § 22-9-104.  How to apply; information required.
  • § 22-9-105.  Application.
  • § 22-9-106.  Qualified absentee voter; written notification if rejected.
  • § 22-9-107.  Delivering ballots to qualified applicants.
  • § 22-9-108.  Absentee ballot record; information to be entered.
  • § 22-9-109.  Form of absentee ballot.
  • § 22-9-110.  Form of absentee ballot envelopes; distribution.
  • § 22-9-111.  Affidavit to be printed on inner envelope; attestation.
  • § 22-9-112.  Instructions on outer envelope.
  • § 22-9-113.  Completing and return of ballot.
  • § 22-9-114.  Receipt by clerk; generally.
  • § 22-9-115.  Receipt by clerk; handling procedure.
  • § 22-9-116.  Duplicate precinct lists; generally.
  • § 22-9-117.  Duplicate precinct lists; handling procedure.
  • § 22-9-118.  Delivery of absentee ballots and duplicate list to precincts.
  • § 22-9-119.  Late absentee ballots.
  • § 22-9-120.  Receipt of absentee ballots and lists by judges.
  • § 22-9-121.  Examination of absentee ballot affidavit; rejection; voting ballots.
  • § 22-9-122.  Return of inner ballot envelopes.
  • § 22-9-123.  Multiple voting prohibited.
  • § 22-9-124.  Violations.
  • § 22-9-125.  Alternate procedures for collecting and counting absentee ballots.

Cross references. —

As to when residence not lost by reason of absence for purpose of voting, see art. 6, § 7, Wyo. Const.

For provision that soldiers stationed in state are not to be considered residents for purpose of voting, see art. 6, § 8, Wyo. Const.

For constitutional provisions as to absent voter ballots, see art. 6, § 22, Wyo. Const.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

26 Am. Jur. 2d Elections §§ 331 to 339.

Validity, construction and effect of absentee voters' laws, 97 ALR2d 218.

29 C.J.S. Elections § 216.

§ 22-9-101. Duty to assist absent electors to vote.

The state and county selective service boards, all military organizations, the adjutant general, citizens and officers of this state are charged with the duty of cooperation with election officials and absent electors to assist absent qualified electors to vote in all elections.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-134.

§ 22-9-102. Who may vote by absentee ballot.

  1. Any qualified elector may vote by absentee ballot.
  2. A qualified elector who leaves the state with the intent to make his residence elsewhere may vote by absentee ballot in Wyoming until he has met the residency requirement in his new state of residence.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-135; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-9-103. Where to apply.

Applications for an absentee ballot for any election to which this Election Code applies shall be made to the appropriate county clerk.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-136; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 3.

§ 22-9-104. How to apply; information required.

  1. A qualified elector may apply for an absentee ballot either in person, in writing, or by telephone, by furnishing the following information:
    1. Name in full, social security number (optional), date of birth, and current Wyoming residence address by street, city, county, and zip code or last Wyoming residence address and month and year of leaving Wyoming to live temporarily in another state or nation, if applicable;
    2. The election for which the absentee ballot is requested;
    3. If a primary election, the political party ballot if desired;
    4. Repealed by Laws 2020, ch. 100, § 2.
    5. If not obtained in person by the elector, the address to which the absentee ballot is to be mailed or the name of the individual the elector designates in writing to deliver the ballot to the elector.
  2. If the foregoing information is received other than in writing, the clerk receiving the same shall reduce it to writing.
  3. Request for a ballot may be made on behalf of an absentee qualified elector if the prescribed information is furnished.
  4. No organization or person on behalf of an organization shall obtain an absentee ballot for an elector.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-137; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2005, ch. 110, § 1; 2020 ch. 100, § 2, effective July 1, 2020.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, rewrote (a)(i), to allow for furnishing either current or last Wyoming residence address.

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, repealed (a)(iv), which read “A statement that applicant is entitled to vote in the election.”

§ 22-9-105. Application.

A qualified elector may apply for an absentee ballot at anytime during the calendar year in which the election is held, but not on the day of the election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-138; Laws 1985, ch. 143, § 1; 1990, ch. 42, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-9-106. Qualified absentee voter; written notification if rejected.

The clerk shall mark each completed absentee ballot application with the date of receipt. The clerk shall then determine if the applicant is properly qualified to vote. If the applicant is not entitled to vote, the clerk shall not issue a ballot to him and shall mark the application “rejected” and file it in a file separate from applications which are accepted. If an application is rejected, the clerk shall immediately notify the applicant in writing of the reason for rejection.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-139; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 2005, ch. 110, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, substituted “date” for “date and time.”

§ 22-9-107. Delivering ballots to qualified applicants.
