  • § 22-15-101.  Right to vote may be challenged.
  • §§ 22-15-102 and 22-15-103.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-15-104.  Grounds for challenge.
  • § 22-15-105.  Challenged person may vote; generally.
  • § 22-15-106.  Where name not on poll list.
  • § 22-15-107.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-15-108.  Duty of judges to challenge.
  • § 22-15-109.  Poll watchers; certification; qualification; authority; removal.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

26 Am. Jur. 2d Elections §§ 381 to 443.

29 C.J.S. Elections §§ 401 to 539.

§ 22-15-101. Right to vote may be challenged.

Registration is evidence of a person’s right to vote at any election, but this right may be challenged at the polls in the manner prescribed by law.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-215.

When person offering to vote at an election is challenged, he is required to take the prescribed oath that he is a qualified voter and also to deliver to the judges of election an affidavit of two qualified electors of that precinct stating that the person offering to vote is qualified. Pratley v. State, 17 Wyo. 371, 99 P. 1116, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1909).

§§ 22-15-102 and 22-15-103. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

These sections, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, provided for the certification of qualified challengers and restrictions on challengers.

§ 22-15-104. Grounds for challenge.

  1. A person offering to vote may be challenged for the following reasons:
    1. Not a qualified elector;
    2. Not entitled to vote in the precinct;
    3. Name does not appear on poll list and the person cannot meet the requirements to register at the polls;
    4. Not the person he represents himself to be;
    5. Has already voted;
    6. For in person voting, failure to present acceptable identification immediately before voting at the polling place or absentee polling place.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-218; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2005, ch. 110, § 1; 2021 ch. 114, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, in (a)(iii), substituted “poll list and the person cannot meet the requirements to register at the polls” for “registry of electors.”

The 2021 amendment, effective July 1, 2021, added (a)(vi).

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 22-15-105. Challenged person may vote; generally.

  1. If a person offering to vote is challenged, and the challenge is not resolved in accordance with W.S. 22-15-106, an election judge shall offer the voter a ballot clearly marked “provisional” and which cannot be automatically tabulated.
  2. A person challenged on any ground may vote by provisional ballot, if he subscribes this oath in writing before a judge of election:
  3. The oath required by this section shall be printed on the provisional ballot envelope.
  4. A challenged voter may present information and documentation of his eligibility to register at the election or to vote to the county clerk until the close of business on the day following the election. Any information presented shall be considered by the canvassing board in determining the voter’s eligibility to register at the election or to vote and whether to open and count his provisional ballot. The provisional ballot shall be counted only after the voter has, by presenting documentation required under this code to the county clerk, established he had previously registered and is a qualified elector or he was eligible to register at the election and is a qualified elector.

“I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I am the person I represent myself to be and that I am a qualified elector entitled to vote in this precinct at this election and that this is the only ballot I have or will vote in this election.”.

Signature of voter Signature of judge Precinct and District No.

Click to view

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-219; Laws 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2; 2004, ch. 94, § 2.

The 2004 amendment, in (b), deleted “except not being registered to vote” following “A person challenged on any ground”; and rewrote (d) to allow a challenged voter to have a provisional ballot counted only after presenting documentation of his eligibility to register.

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2004.

§ 22-15-106. Where name not on poll list.

A person challenged on the ground that his name does not appear on the poll list may vote if a judge of election obtains verification from the county clerk that the person is entitled to vote in that election within that county.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-220; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2; 2005, ch. 110, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, substituted “poll list” for “registry list.”

§ 22-15-107. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 3.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, related to pollbook requirements for challenged voters.

§ 22-15-108. Duty of judges to challenge.

It is the duty of the judges to challenge electors whenever existence of legal grounds for doing so is known or apparent to the judges.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-222.

§ 22-15-109. Poll watchers; certification; qualification; authority; removal.

  1. The county chairman of each political party may certify poll watchers prior to the day of the election to serve in each polling place. Not more than one (1) poll watcher from each political party may serve simultaneously unless the chief judge determines that one (1) additional poll watcher from each political party may be accommodated in the polling place without disrupting the polling process.
  2. A poll watcher shall belong to the political party he represents and shall be a registered elector residing in the county. A poll watcher shall serve only at the polling place designated on the certificate. A poll watcher is authorized to observe voter turn out and registration and may make written memoranda but shall not challenge voters, conduct electioneering activities or disrupt the polling process.
  3. The chief judge may remove a poll watcher from the polling place for disturbing the polling place, or for any other violation of the Election Code.

History.

Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 1; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

The 2015 amendment, substituted “polling place” for “precinct” in the first sentence in (a) and (b); and substituted “polling place” for “polling premises” in the second sentence in (a) and in (c).

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

Chapter 16 Canvass and Recount

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

26 Am. Jur. 2d Elections §§ 370 to 404.

29 C.J.S. Elections §§ 119, 228, 235 to 239.

§ 22-16-101. County canvassing board; compensation.

The county canvassing board is the county clerk and two (2) electors of different political parties resident in the county appointed by the county clerk. The two (2) electors shall receive the same compensation as election judges. All canvassing board members shall take an oath of office.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-223; 2011, ch. 38, § 1; 2013 ch. 31, § 1, effective July 1, 2013.

Cross references. —

As to compensation of election judges, see § 22-8-116.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, substituted “county clerk” for “board of county commissioners” at the end of the first sentence.

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, added the last sentence.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Injunction against canvassing of votes and declaring result of election, 1 ALR2d 588.

§ 22-16-102. Abstract of vote; returns not filed.

  1. The county clerk shall prepare an abstract of the vote of all precincts in the county following a county primary, special or general election. The abstract shall contain all items required in W.S. 22-16-103(c)(viii).
  2. The county clerk shall send a messenger to obtain returns not filed in his office within a reasonable length of time.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-224; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

The 2015 amendment, added the second sentence in (a).

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

Authority in making abstracts of votes. —

In making abstracts of votes shown by precinct returns, canvassing board held not authorized to examine and recount the ballots or to go behind the entry made in the pollbooks showing the result of the count by the judges and clerks, or to examine and pass on the sufficiency of the affidavits of challenged or unregistered voters or those of voters in precincts where prior registration is not required or to do more than determine the genuineness of the returns. Pratley v. State, 17 Wyo. 371, 99 P. 1116, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1909).

No control by mandamus. —

Where return of vote of certain county, sent by the clerk thereof to state canvassing board, contained two abstracts of votes cast in such counties for members of the house of representatives, one made by the clerk, and the other by two justices of the peace whom he called to his assistance in canvassing the vote, the clerk's certificate to the return stating “that the foregoing is a full, true and correct copy of the abstract of the returns of all votes cast in said county for members of the state legislature,” the decision by such board as to which abstract was the official and legal return was not exercise of a judicial discretion, which the supreme court cannot control by mandamus. State ex rel. Bennett v. Barber, 4 Wyo. 56, 32 P. 14, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1892).

§ 22-16-103. County canvass procedures.

  1. Prior to the county canvass, the county clerk shall:
    1. Examine the poll books, tally sheets, precinct certifications and oaths of election officials;
    2. Summarize the number of votes cast in each precinct for every candidate appearing on the ballot and the total votes cast for write-in candidates, and upon each ballot proposition;
    3. Count write-in votes by candidate if the total vote for write-in candidates may affect the result of an election. For offices elected from districts involving more than one (1) county, the secretary of state shall direct the county clerks to count write-in votes by candidate if on the basis of unofficial returns it appears the total write-in votes may affect the result of an election.
  2. Repealed by Laws 2002, ch. 18, § 3.
  3. The county canvassing board shall:
    1. Meet as soon as all returns have been received and abstracted, but if any provisional ballots have been cast in the county, not before the time has passed for provisional voters to document their eligibility to register or to vote. The board shall meet at a time and place designated by the county clerk, but no later than the first Friday following the election;
    2. Perform or review a reconciliation of the ballots by precinct;
    3. Review and determine the eligibility of provisional voters to register at the election if not previously registered and to vote and determine whether their provisional ballots may be opened and counted. The canvassing board shall meet in executive session when necessary to protect the confidentiality of ballots and of a voter’s confidential personally identifiable information;
    4. Count and tabulate the votes on the provisional ballots which were determined to have been cast by qualified electors;
    5. Review and certify the abstracts after the validity of provisional ballots have been determined and discrepancies and ties have been resolved;
    6. Review and certify successful write-in candidates after determination of the number of votes for candidates and verification of candidate qualification;
    7. Cause minutes of the meeting to be taken, signed by the canvassing board and filed with the county clerk;
    8. Ensure abstracts contain the following information:
      1. For primary elections, the total ballots cast by party, including unaffiliated votes;
      2. The number of electors voting in person and by absentee ballot by precinct at the election;
      3. The full name of each of the following receiving votes:
        1. Candidates printed on the ballot;
        2. Write-in candidates, if the candidate  received a sufficient number of votes; and
        3. Nominated or elected write-in candidates.
      4. The offices receiving votes;
      5. The number of votes cast for each of the following receiving votes:
        1. Candidates printed on the ballot;
        2. Write-in candidates, if the candidate  received a sufficient number of votes;
        3. Nominated or elected write-in candidates;
        4. The number of overvotes; and
        5. The number of undervotes.
      6. The official designation or number of each ballot proposition and the number of votes for and against it stated in figures; and
      7. The number of provisional ballots cast.
  4. The precinct returns of the municipal primary election shall be canvassed by the county canvassing board, which shall certify the results of such in writing to the county clerk and municipal clerk.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-225; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1996, ch. 93, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2001, ch. 116, § 1; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 18, §§ 2, 3; 2004, ch. 94, § 2; 2008, ch. 115, § 1; 2010, ch. 3, § 2; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015; 2018 ch. 118, § 1, effective March 14, 2018.

The 2004 amendment, rewrote (c)(i), (iii), and (iv), pertaining to the procedure for determining the elgibility and validity of provisional ballots.

Laws 2004, ch. 94, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2004.

The 2008 amendment, substituted “taken” for “recorded” in (c)(vi).

Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

The 2010 amendment, effective July 1, 2010, added (c)(vi) and redesignated former (c)(vi) as (c)(vii).

The 2015 amendment, added (c)(viii).

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

The 2018 amendment, in (c)(viii)(C)(II) and (c)(viii)(E)(II), substituted “Write-in candidates, if the candidate received a sufficient number of votes” for “Valid write-in candidates.”

Laws 2018, ch. 118, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 14, 2018.

§ 22-16-104. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 3.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, related to a meeting of the county canvassing board.

§ 22-16-105. Tie votes.

A tie vote shall be decided at an open meeting by lots cast by the county canvassing board or other authority holding the election, except in elections for members of the state legislature, which shall be determined as provided in W.S. 22-16-119.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-227; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-16-106. Write-in candidates.

  1. Each write-in candidate nominated at a primary election, who has not previously filed an application for nomination shall accept nomination by filing an application for nomination and paying the filing fee in the office in which he would have been required to file an application for nomination to that office.
  2. The chief election officer shall notify a write-in candidate who has been nominated at a primary election within forty-eight (48) hours after the canvassing board meets. Notification may be delivered by United States postal service or other generally accepted mail delivery method to the last known address of the write-in candidate, email or other electronic means that provide actual notice to the write-in candidate, or service as provided under the Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure. Each notification provided under this section shall inform the write-in candidate that failure to timely respond will result in forfeiture of nomination. Failure of the successful write-in candidate to accept the nomination in the manner prescribed in subsection (a) of this section within five (5) days after delivery, attempted delivery or service under the Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure, as computed pursuant to W.S. 22-2-110, results in the successful write-in candidate not appearing on the general election ballot, but does not result in a vacancy which can be filled.
  3. Any person may request to have the votes cast for any write-in candidate, whose votes did not affect the election, counted by filing a request together with an administrative fee, set by rule and regulation, with the appropriate election officers not later than two (2) days after the election in which the write-in votes occurred.
  4. A write-in candidate elected to public office at a general or special election may decline election before taking the oath of office by filing written notice with the county clerk where the candidate resides and the secretary of state. Notice provided under this subsection shall immediately create a vacancy in the office which shall be filled in the manner prescribed in W.S. 22-18-101 through 22-18-112.

History.

Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 1; 2001, ch. 116, § 1; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2; 2008, ch. 115, § 1; 2011, ch. 38, § 1; 2015 ch. 76, § 1, effective July 1, 2015; 2018 ch. 118, § 1, effective March 14, 2018; 2020 ch. 100, § 1, effective July 1, 2020.

The 2008 amendment, in (b), substituted “provided” for “accepted” in the first sentence, added “as computed pursuant to W.S. 22-2-110” in the last sentence.

Laws 2008, ch. 115, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (a), deleted “or elected” following “nominated”; in (b), substituted “a write-in candidate who has” for “write-in candidates who have” in the first sentence, and inserted the present third sentence; and in (c), inserted “together with an administrative fee, set by rule and regulation.”

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, in the last sentence, inserted “after delivery, attempted delivery or service under the Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure,” and deleted “of proof of service or attempted delivery” preceding “results in.”

The 2018 amendment, in (a), substituted “for nomination shall accept nomination” for “accepts” following “filed an application” and inserted “nomination to” preceding “that office”; in (b), in the first sentence, substituted “nominated at a primary election” for “for election,” and in the third sentence inserted “in the manner prescribed in subsection (a) of this section”; and added (d).

Laws 2018, ch. 118, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 14, 2018.

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (b) substituted “may be delivered” for “may be made,” “or other generally accepted mail delivery method to” for “any generally accepted business document delivery method evidenced by receipt of delivery or attempted delivery at,” and “write-in candidate, email or other electronic means that provide actual notice to the write-in candidate, or service” for “write-in candidate or service.”

Editor's notes. —

Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 1, effective January 1, 1999, enacted a new § 22-16-106, and § 3 renumbered former § 22-16-106 as § 22-16-107.

§ 22-16-107. Certified results.

The certified results of the county canvass shall be posted in the office of the county clerk and copies made available to interested persons.

History.


Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-228; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-106; 1998, ch. 100, § 4.

§ 22-16-108. Results furnished secretary of state.

Immediately upon completion of the county canvass, the county clerk shall notify the secretary of state of the election results. A copy of the county abstract, after being certified by the county canvassing boards, shall immediately be delivered by the county clerk to the secretary of state. The secretary of state shall provide procedures for such transmittal and notification through rule and regulation.

History.


Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-229; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-107; 1998, ch. 100, § 3; 2007, ch. 39, § 1.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, added the third sentence.

§ 22-16-109. Recounts.

  1. The county canvassing board shall make a recount of precinct votes if it appears to the board that a recount is required due to irregularities in that precinct.
  2. There shall be a recount made of all the votes cast for any office in which the difference in number of votes cast for the winning candidate receiving the least number of votes and the number of votes cast for the losing candidate receiving the greatest number of votes is less than one percent (1%) of the number of votes cast for the winning candidate receiving the least number of votes cast for that office. This recount shall be made in the entire district in which the candidates are standing for election.
  3. There shall be a recount made of all the votes cast for any office if a losing candidate requests one under provision of W.S. 22-16-110. This recount shall be made in the entire district in which the candidate is standing for election.

History.


Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-230; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1996, ch. 93, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-108; 1998, ch. 100, § 3.

Integrity of ballots must be securely protected and proved.—

In order for the recount of the ballots to overcome the returns of the election officials the contestant must prove that the ballots are those voted at the election and that they are in the same condition as they were when cast. The integrity of the ballots must be securely protected. In an election contest, it must be proved that they were so preserved that there was no reasonable opportunity for tampering with them. Wilson v. Burridge, 346 P.2d 282, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 51 (Wyo. 1959).

Same ballots and same number must be recounted. —

In order that a recount of votes may prevail over the count by the clerks and judges of the election, it must appear that the same ballots and the same number of ballots were counted in the recount as were cast in the election. Wilson v. Burridge, 346 P.2d 282, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 51 (Wyo. 1959).

§ 22-16-110. How candidate may obtain recount; where affidavit filed.

  1. A candidate may obtain a recount of votes for the office he is seeking by making and filing an affidavit alleging that fraud or error occurred in counting, returning or canvassing the votes cast in any part of the district in which he is standing for election. The affidavit shall be filed in the same office the candidate filed his application for nomination:
    1. Not later than two (2) days after the county canvass has been completed if the office is certified by the county canvassing board;
    2. Not later than two (2) days after the state canvass has been completed if the office is certified by the state canvassing board.

History.


Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-231; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1992, ch. 1, § 5; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-109; 1998, ch. 100, § 4.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 22-16-111. Recount of ballot proposition.

  1. A recount of votes of a ballot proposition may be obtained in one (1) of the following manners:
    1. A recount will be made if the proposition receives a number of votes, greater or lesser, within one percent (1%) of the number of votes required for passage. The one percent (1%) variance shall be calculated based upon the total number of votes cast on the proposition, except for constitutional amendments in which case the variance shall be calculated based upon the total number of votes cast in the election;
    2. A recount will be made if requested in an affidavit signed by twenty-five (25) electors registered in a district voting on the question. The affidavit shall be filed with the county clerk not later than two (2) days after the county canvass has been completed for propositions voted on in one (1) county, and with the secretary of state not later than two (2) days after the state canvass has been completed for propositions voted on in more than one (1) county. The affidavit shall be accompanied by a deposit of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
  2. The county in which the recount is taken shall pay the costs of the recount if the recount is required by subsection (a)(i) of this section; and the signers of the affidavit referred to in subsection (a)(ii) of this section shall be jointly and severally liable for the costs of the recount requested by them up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) per county recounted if the results of the election are not changed by the recount.
  3. The result of the recount shall be the official result of the election.

History.


Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-231.1; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-110; 1998, ch. 100, § 4.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-16-112. Precincts to be recounted; recount official result.

  1. The number of precincts to be recounted shall be as follows:
    1. If the recount is requested by a candidate, all precincts in which that candidate was voted upon for that office shall be recounted;
    2. If the recount is required by W.S. 22-16-109(b), all precincts in which that candidate was voted upon for that office shall be recounted;
    3. If the recount is initiated by the state or county canvassing board because of possible irregularities in the counting of votes in a precinct, the recount shall be made in the precincts designated by the canvassing board initiating the recount.
  2. If the recount indicates a different vote, the result of the recount shall be the official result.
  3. In no event shall a county clerk certify the recount results later than seventy-two (72) hours after the recount is requested.

History.


Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-232; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1992, ch. 1, § 5; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-111; 1998, ch. 100, § 3; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2.

§ 22-16-113. Recount deposit; expense of recount.

  1. An affidavit requesting a recount must be accompanied by the following deposit:
    1. If the difference in number of votes cast as calculated pursuant to W.S. 22-16-109(b) is one percent (1%) or greater but less than five percent (5%), five hundred dollars ($500.00);
    2. If the difference in number of votes cast as calculated pursuant to W.S. 22-16-109(b) is five percent (5%) or greater, three thousand dollars ($3,000.00).
  2. If the recount shows sufficient error to change the result of the election, the county in which the recount is taken shall pay expenses of the recount and the deposit shall be returned. Otherwise the applicant or applicants seeking the recount shall be liable for the actual cost of conducting the recount up to a maximum of the amount deposited under subsection (a) of this section, per county recounted. Every county clerk shall issue a complete accounting of all costs of the recount to the candidate requesting the recount, and shall refund any surplus to the candidate.
  3. If the recount is initiated by the county canvassing board or required by W.S. 22-16-109(b), the cost of the recount shall be paid by the county in which the recount is taken regardless of the result of the recount.

History.


Laws 1973, ch. 251,§ 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-233; Laws 1975, ch. 185,§ 2; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-112; 1998, ch. 100, § 3; 2017 ch. 77, § 1, effective July 1, 2017.

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, redesignated the former paragraph as (a), (b), and (c); in (a), substituted “the following deposit” for “a deposit of one hundred dollars ($100.00)” and added (a)(i) and (a)(ii); and in (b), substituted “the amount deposited under subsection (a) of this section” for “five hundred dollars ($500.00)” in the second sentence.

§ 22-16-114. Certificates of election or nomination after recount.

When the time within which to request a recount has expired without one being requested, or when a recount has been completed, the county clerk shall immediately prepare and mail certificates of election or nomination to each candidate nominated or elected to a county or precinct office.

History.


Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-234; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-113; 1998, ch. 100, § 4; 2005, ch. 100, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, deleted the last sentence which read, “A candidate shall file his statement of campaign receipts and expenditures when required before receiving a certificate of election or nomination or a vacancy will be declared to exist.”

§ 22-16-115. State canvassing board.

The state canvassing board is the governor, secretary of state, state auditor and state treasurer.

History.


Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-235; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-114; 1998, ch. 100, § 4.

Purpose. —

The object and legislative intent in establishing a state canvassing board is to have such board canvass the vote cast for state officers generally, whether specified in the act or not. In re Moore, 4 Wyo. 98, 31 P. 980, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1893).

Canvass of state board is based on the abstracts of returns. State ex rel. Sammon v. Chatterton, 12 Wyo. 168, 73 P. 961, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Wyo. 1903).

Certificate of election. —

The fact that certificate of election issued to a district judge on his election at a general election recited that he was elected for unexpired term of judge who had resigned cannot operate to shorten the term fixed by the constitution and laws of the state. State ex rel. Burdick v. Schnitger, 17 Wyo. 65, 96 P. 238, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1908).

Conflicting abstracts of vote. —

Where the canvassing board transmitted to the state canvassing board two abstracts of the votes of the county, one made by the clerk and one made by two justices of the peace against the clerk's protests, both duly certified, the abstract of the two justices constituted the official and legal returns of such county, which had to be canvassed by the state board. State ex rel. Bennett v. Barber, 4 Wyo. 56, 32 P. 14, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1892).

Cited in

Gorin v. Karpan, 775 F. Supp. 1430, 1991 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 14885 (D. Wyo. 1991).

§ 22-16-116. Statewide abstract; discrepancies with county abstracts.

From the unofficial tabulations delivered directly to his office, the secretary of state shall tabulate a statewide abstract by counties of votes for president and vice-president, state officers, justice of the supreme court, United States senator, representative in congress, district court judges, circuit court judges, members of the state legislature and the votes for and against ballot propositions voted on by electors of a district larger than a county. The unofficial tabulation shall then be reconciled to the official abstracts of the county canvassing boards and the secretary of state shall prepare the state abstract from the official county abstracts.

History:


Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-236; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-115; 1998, ch. 100, § 3; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014.

The 2014 amendment , inserted “circuit court judges” in the first sentence.

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

§ 22-16-117. Content of state abstract.

The state abstract of an election shall indicate by county the number of ballots cast by each political party, if known, the total votes cast for each candidate, the names of all write-in candidates receiving a sufficient number of votes to affect the result of the election and the number of votes for each, and the number of votes received for and against each ballot proposition.

History.


Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-237; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-116; 1998, ch. 100, § 3.

§ 22-16-118. Meeting of state canvassing board.

The state canvassing board shall meet no later than the second Wednesday following the election. The secretary of state shall send a messenger to obtain official county abstracts not filed in a reasonable length of time. The canvassing board shall meet at the time and place set by the secretary of state. The board shall review the state abstracts prepared by the secretary of state, compare them with the tabulation and materials prepared by the secretary of state, resolve any tie votes, and certify the abstract as the official state canvass.

History.


Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-238; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1977, ch. 186, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-117; 1998, ch. 100, § 4.

Cited in

Gorin v. Karpan, 775 F. Supp. 1430, 1991 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 14885 (D. Wyo. 1991).

§ 22-16-119. Tie vote in state abstract.

A tie vote for an office contained in the state abstract shall be resolved at an open meeting by lots cast by the state canvassing board.

History.


Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-239; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-118; 1998, ch. 100, § 4.

§ 22-16-120. Filing of state abstract.

When the canvass by the state canvassing board is completed and certified, the secretary of state shall file the official state abstract in his office with the minutes of the state canvassing board meeting signed by the members of the state canvassing board. The secretary of state shall cause a copy of the official state canvass to be posted in the office of the secretary of state and shall make additional copies available to the public.

History.


Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-240; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-119; 1998, ch. 100, § 3.

§ 22-16-121. Certificates of nomination and election following state or county canvass.

  1. When the state canvass is concluded, the secretary of state shall issue a certificate of nomination to each candidate nominated at a primary election and certify the names of nominees as provided in W.S. 22-6-101. When the county canvass is concluded, the county clerk shall issue a certificate of nomination to each candidate nominated at a primary election or by petition.
  2. The governor shall issue a certificate of election to a candidate duly elected to an office to be filled by electors of the state, district court judges, circuit court judges and members of the state legislature. The county clerk shall issue a certificate of election to each candidate duly elected to a county or precinct office in the county and to members elected to boards of trustees of special districts, school or community college districts and city or town councils.

History:


Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-241; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1981, ch. 159, § 1; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-120; 1998, ch. 100, § 3; 2005, ch. 100, § 1; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, at the end of all sentences in (a) and (b), deleted “provided the candidate has complied with W.S. 22-25-106.”

The 2014 amendment, in the first sentence of (b), inserted “circuit court judges”; in the last sentence of (b), substituted “special districts” for “hospital.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

§ 22-16-122. Election declared null and void; special election.

  1. If a canvassing board is unable to determine which candidate has been elected or nominated, the canvassing board shall declare any part of the election results to be null and void as to that office and the county clerk shall call a special election to make a decision. For purposes of this section, a canvassing board shall be unable to determine which candidate is nominated or elected if:
    1. A material error in the conduct of the election has occurred; and
    2. The error involves a number of votes that is equal to or greater than the number of votes separating the winning and losing candidates.
  2. The canvassing board shall determine which precincts will be involved in the special election. If the candidates’ office is voted on across county lines, the canvassing board of all counties involved shall meet to determine the criteria for the special election.
  3. If only certain precincts are allowed to vote in the special election, the votes received in the special election shall be added to the unofficial results not declared null and void for that office from the initial primary, general election or other special election.
  4. In a contest involving multiple candidates, all of the candidates’ names shall be placed on the ballot in the special election.
  5. Any candidate may appeal the decision of the canvassing board to call or not to call a special election in the same manner as he would contest an election under this act. However, the appeal shall be filed in the district court no later than the first Monday following the meeting of the canvassing board where the decision being appealed was made.
  6. The special election shall be held if necessary no later than the third Tuesday after the primary, general or other special election and may be held by a special mail ballot election as provided in W.S. 22-16-123. The special election shall be conducted by the county clerk as nearly as possible in the manner of a primary or general election, except only those registered in the precinct at the close of polls on the election day of the primary, general or other special election in question shall be permitted to vote in the special election. If the election is held as a special mail ballot election, the election shall be held as provided in W.S. 22-16-123.
  7. Not more than fourteen (14) nor less than five (5) days before the special election the county clerk shall publish at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the county a proclamation setting forth the date of the election, the offices to be filled at the election including the terms of the offices, the number of persons required by law to fill the offices, the requirements for filing statements of campaign contributions and expenditures, and any other pertinent information.
  8. A court ordered election may be held by special mail ballot election as determined by the county clerk or by the secretary of state if the election involves more than one (1) county.

History.


Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-241.1; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 22-16-121; 1998, ch. 100, § 3; 2011, ch. 76, § 2; 2014 ch. 105, § 1, effective March 10, 2014; 2015 ch. 76, § 1, effective July 1, 2015.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

As to contesting elections generally, see §§ 22-17-101 to 22-17-114.

The 2011 amendment, inserted “and may be held by a special mail ballot election as provided in W.S. 22-16-123” in (d) and (e); added the last sentence in (d) and (e); and added (f).

Laws 2011, ch. 76 § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved February 24, 2011.

The 2014 amendment, in (a), inserted “any part of” and “results”; added present (b) and (c); redesignated former (b) through (f) as present (d) through (h); in present (d), substituted “all of the candidates' names shall be” for “no candidate who has clearly won or lost the contest shall be”; in present (e), added the last sentence; in present (f), inserted “general or other special” in the first sentence, deleted the second and third sentences which read: “ Any candidate may appeal the decision of the canvassing board in the same manner as he would contest an election under this act. However, this appeal shall be filed in the district court no later than the first Monday following the meeting of the canvassing board whose decision is being appealed,” in the fourth sentence, substituted “or general election, except only those registered in the precinct at the close of polls on the election day of the primary, general or other special election in question shall be permitted to vote in the special election” for “election, except that registration at the polls shall not be permitted”; in (f), deleted the first which read: “The special election shall be held if necessary on the third Tuesday after the general election and may be held by a special mail ballot election as provided in W.S. 22 16 123,” deleted the next-to-last and last sentences which read: “The special election shall be conducted by the county clerk as nearly as possible in the manner of a general election. If the election is held as a special mail ballot election, the election shall be held as provided in W.S. 22 16 123.”

Laws 2014, ch. 105, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, in (g), substituted “campaign contributions” for “campaign receipts.”

§ 22-16-123. Special mail ballot elections; procedures.

  1. A special mail ballot election, as provided in this section, may be held in response to a determination under W.S. 22-16-122(a).
  2. In a special mail ballot election, official ballots shall be prepared and all other pre-election procedures followed as otherwise provided by law or rules promulgated by the secretary of state, except that special mail ballot packets shall be prepared as follows:
    1. The election official shall mail to each qualified elector entitled to vote in the special mail ballot election as described in W.S. 22-16-122(b) and (c), at the last address appearing in the registration records or to the address given on the absentee ballot application used for the primary, general or other special election ballot, a special mail ballot packet, which shall be marked “DO NOT FORWARD-ADDRESS CORRECTION REQUESTED,” or any other similar statement which is in accordance with United States postal service regulations. Packets shall be mailed not sooner than twenty-one (21) days and not later than fifteen (15) days before an election for elections held in accordance with W.S. 22-16-122. Packets shall be mailed not sooner than forty-five (45) days and not later than forty (40) days before an election for elections held in accordance with W.S. 22-16-122(h) unless the court order provides otherwise;
    2. The ballot shall contain the following warning:
    3. Not sooner than twenty-one (21) days and before 7:00 p.m. on election day for elections held in accordance with W.S. 22-16-122, mail ballots shall be made available at the election official’s office for voters entitled to vote in the election but whose address has changed or who did not receive their ballot in the mail;
    4. A voter may obtain a replacement ballot if the ballot was destroyed, spoiled, lost or for some other reason not received by the voter. In order to obtain a replacement ballot, the voter shall sign a sworn statement specifying the reason for requesting the replacement ballot. The statement shall be presented to the election official no later than 7:00 p.m. on election day. The election official shall keep a record of each replacement ballot issued in accordance with this paragraph. A replacement ballot may be transmitted directly to the applicant at the election official’s office or may be mailed to the voter at the address provided in the application. Replacement ballots may be cast no later than 7:00 p.m. on election day;
    5. Upon receipt of a ballot, the voter shall mark the ballot, sign and complete the return-verification envelope and comply with the instructions provided with the ballot. The voter may return the marked ballot to the election official by United States mail or by depositing the ballot at the office of the election official or the designated depository no later than 7:00 p.m. on election day;
    6. Once the ballot is returned, it shall not be returned to the voter. The election official shall first qualify the submitted ballot by examining the verification envelope and comparing the information on the envelope to the poll list to determine whether the ballot was submitted by a voter who has not previously voted in the election. If the ballot so qualifies and is otherwise valid, the official shall place a number next to the voter’s name in the poll book. The election official shall then open and separate the ballot from the envelope and place the ballot in a ballot box so as to keep the voter’s ballot private;
    7. All deposited ballots shall be counted as provided in this act and rules promulgated by the secretary of state. A special mail ballot shall be valid and counted only if is returned in the return-verification envelope, the affidavit on the envelope is signed by the voter to whom the ballot was issued and the information on the envelope is verified as provided in paragraph (vi) of this subsection. If the election official determines that a voter to whom a replacement ballot has been issued has voted more than once, the official shall only count the first ballot received from that voter;
    8. The election official shall provide a minimum of one (1) polling place on the day of election which may be the election official’s office and shall be open between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m.
  3. If any special mail ballot packet mailed under paragraph (b)(i) of this section to a physical address, not including a post office box, is returned by the postal service, the county clerk shall investigate the validity of the address. If the county clerk determines that the address is not at a location that a voter could inhabit, the county clerk shall remove the address from the registration records until the county clerk receives proof that the address is habitable by a voter.

WARNING

The criminal laws regulating the conduct of elections contained in chapter 26 of the Wyoming Election Code of 1973, as amended, apply with equal force to elections by mail.

History:

Laws 2011, ch. 76, § 1; 2014 ch. 105, § 1, effective March 10, 2014; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014.

The 2014 amendments. —

The first 2014 amendment, by ch. 105, § 1, in (b)(i), inserted “as described in W.S. 22-16-122(b) and (c)” and “or to the address given on the absentee ballot application used for the primary, general or other special election ballot” in the first sentence, substituted “twenty-one (21)” for “twenty-five (25),” “W.S. 22-16-122” for “W.S. 22-16-122(d) or (e),” and “W.S. 22-16-122(h)” for “W.S. 22-16-122(f)” in the second sentence; in (b)(iii), substituted “twenty-one (21) days and before 7:00 p.m.” for “twenty-five (25 and not later than 4:00 p.m.,” W.S. 22-16-122” for “W.S. 22-16-122(f)” and deleted “and for voters allowed by law to register and vote the day of the election”; in (b)(iv), substituted “7:00 p.m.” for “4:00 p.m.” in the third sentence, and “7:00 p.m.” for “5:00 p.m.” in the fifth sentence; and in (b)(v), substituted “7:00 p.m.” for “5:00 p.m.” in the second sentence.

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 10, 2014.

The second 2014 amendment, by ch. 108, § 1, in the introductory language of (b)(ii), deleted “or ballot label” preceding “shall contain”; in the first sentence of (c), deleted “or the secretary of state if the election involves more than one (1) county” preceding “shall investigate”; in the last sentence of (c), deleted “or secretary of state” preceding “determines that,” and deleted “or secretary of state” preceding “receives proof.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 10, 2014.

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

Effective dates. —

Laws 2011, ch. 76, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved February 24 2011.

Chapter 17 Contests

  • § 22-17-101.  Right to contest elections; exception; grounds.
  • § 22-17-102.  Commencement by verified petition; contents.
  • § 22-17-103.  Summons; conduct of suit.
  • § 22-17-104.  Judgment for costs.
  • § 22-17-105.  Ballot propositions contestable; nature of action.
  • § 22-17-106.  Grounds for contesting ballot propositions.
  • § 22-17-107.  Defense of contested ballot proposition.
  • § 22-17-108.  Court judgment in contests.
  • § 22-17-109.  Contesting election of state legislator; generally.
  • § 22-17-110.  Contesting election of state legislator; commencement.
  • § 22-17-111.  Contesting election of state legislator; taking of depositions.
  • § 22-17-112.  Contesting election of state legislator; handling of depositions by secretary of state; additional depositions.
  • § 22-17-113.  Contesting election of state legislator; legislative determination final.
  • § 22-17-114.  Contesting election of president, vice-president or presidential elector.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

26 Am. Jur. 2d Elections §§ 381 to 443.

Admissibility of parol evidence of election officials to impeach election returns, 46 ALR2d 1385.

State court jurisdiction over contest involving primary election for member of congress, 68 ALR2d 1320.

29 C.J.S. Elections §§ 401 to 539.

§ 22-17-101. Right to contest elections; exception; grounds.

  1. A qualified elector may contest the right of a person declared elected to an office in the elector’s county, municipality, district or precinct, other than the office of state legislator, United States president and vice-president and presidential elector, on the following grounds:
    1. Misconduct or material negligence of an election official which affected the result of the election;
    2. The person whose election is contested is not eligible to hold the office;
    3. The person whose election is contested offered to give a bribe to a voter or election official to procure his election;
    4. Illegal votes were counted or legal votes were not counted;
    5. The person whose election is contested violated the provisions of W. S. 22-26-101 through 22-26-121.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-242; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 35, § 2.

Cross references. —

For grounds to contest ballot proposition, see § 22-17-106.

For grounds of contesting election of state legislator, see § 22-17-109.

For provision that the legislature shall pass laws to secure purity of elections and guard against abuse of franchise, see art. 6, § 13, Wyo. Const.

For provision as to election contests, see art. 6, § 14, Wyo. Const.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Presumption in favor of validity of election. —

Every reasonable presumption will be indulged in favor of the validity of an election which has been held under the applicable statutory provision, and the one asserting that the election is irregular must bear the burden of showing that it is otherwise. Reitveld v. Northern Wyo. Community College Dist., 344 P.2d 986, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 55 (Wyo. 1959).

And an election is not to be set aside for mere informalities or irregularities unless they are shown to have affected the result of the election. Reitveld v. Northern Wyo. Community College Dist., 344 P.2d 986, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 55 (Wyo. 1959).

Purging illegal votes. —

Court may purge poll of illegal votes cast without fault of candidates by deducting them proportionately from both candidates according to vote for each. Hamilton v. Marshall, 41 Wyo. 157, 282 P. 1058, 1929 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1929).

Voting after closing hour. —

Irregularity in keeping polls open after closing hour when votes were cast was insufficient ground of contest unless it materially affected result. Hamilton v. Marshall, 41 Wyo. 157, 282 P. 1058, 1929 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1929).

Where it was alleged sufficient votes were cast after voting hours to change result, court in election contest must deduct them proportionately from vote for each candidate. Hamilton v. Marshall, 41 Wyo. 157, 282 P. 1058, 1929 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1929).

Applied in

Karn v. Hayes, 530 P.2d 156, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 121 (Wyo. 1975).

Quoted in

Smith v. Brito, 2007 WY 191, 173 P.3d 351, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 203 (2007).

§ 22-17-102. Commencement by verified petition; contents.

  1. Election contests for all primary election offices and all general election offices other than state legislators, United States president and vice-president and presidential elector, may be commenced by the contestant filing with the clerk of the district court of the county, within fourteen (14) days after the results of the election have been certified by the canvassing board, a verified petition setting forth specifically:
    1. The name of the contestant and that he is a registered elector in the county, district or precinct in which the office is to be exercised;
    2. The name of the person whose election is being contested;
    3. The office;
    4. The grounds for the contest.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-243; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 35, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 22-17-103. Summons; conduct of suit.

Summons shall be issued against the person whose election is being contested and upon the election official responsible for conducting the election. The suit shall be conducted as a civil action and shall be considered for an expedited docket.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-244; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Quoted in

Smith v. Brito, 2007 WY 191, 173 P.3d 351, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 203 (2007).

§ 22-17-104. Judgment for costs.

If the proceedings in an election contest are dismissed for insufficiency, or want of prosecution, or if the election is confirmed by the court, judgment shall be rendered for costs against the party contesting the election and in favor of the party whose election was contested. If the election is annulled and set aside for grounds stated in W.S. 22-17-101(a)(ii), (iii) or (v), judgment for costs shall be rendered against the party whose election was contested and in favor of the party contesting the election. If the election is annulled and set aside for the grounds stated in W.S. 22-17-101(a)(i) or (iv), judgment and costs shall be rendered against the county.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-245; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Annulment of winning candidate's election. —

Where a losing candidate in a town council election successfully challenged the election of the winning candidate who was not a registered voter when he filed his petition, resulting in the annulment of the winning candidate's election but not the voiding of the entire election, an award of costs from the winning candidate to the losing candidate was mandated. Smith v. Brito, 2007 WY 191, 173 P.3d 351, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 203 (Wyo. 2007).

§ 22-17-105. Ballot propositions contestable; nature of action.

A ballot proposition which may by law be submitted to a vote of the people of a county, city or town, district, or other political subdivision may be contested by a petition of five (5) registered electors of the county, city or town, district or other political subdivision filed in the district court of the county not later than fifteen (15) days after the results of the election have been certified by the canvassing board. A ballot proposition contest is a civil action.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-246.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

Cited in

Snell v. Johnson County Sch. Dist. No. 1, 2004 WY 19, 86 P.3d 248, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (2004).

Particular Contests. —

“Proposition” to be placed on the “ballot” under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 18-3-501 (size of county commission) is in fact a “ballot proposition” under Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 22-17-105 and 22-17-106. Rock v. Lankford, 2013 WY 61, 301 P.3d 1075, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2013).

Lawsuit was an election contest governed by Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 22-17-105 and 22-17-106 because it asked the court to (1) declare null and void an election in which voters passed a proposition returning the size of the county commission to three and (2) direct the county clerk to hold an election based on a board composed of five members. The remedy sought would have defeated the public interest in the stability and finality of election results and could only result from a declaration that the special election was void, which was the very essence of an election contest. Rock v. Lankford, 2013 WY 61, 301 P.3d 1075, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2013).

Suit by three challengers to a ballot proposition that returned the size of the county commission to three was dismissed because the challengers failed to bring the contest within the time specified in Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-17-105 and through the five electors required. Rock v. Lankford, 2013 WY 61, 301 P.3d 1075, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2013).

§ 22-17-106. Grounds for contesting ballot propositions.

  1. A ballot proposition may be contested for any of the following reasons:
    1. Misconduct or material negligence of an election official which affected the result of the election;
    2. The election result was influenced by a bribe;
    3. Illegal votes were counted or legal votes were not counted.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-247.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Particular Contests. —

“Proposition” to be placed on the “ballot” under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 18-3-501 (size of county commission) is in fact a “ballot proposition” under Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 22-17-105 and 22-17-106. Rock v. Lankford, 2013 WY 61, 301 P.3d 1075, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2013).

Lawsuit was an election contest governed by Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 22-17-105 and 22-17-106 because it asked the court to (1) declare null and void an election in which voters passed a proposition returning the size of the county commission to three and (2) direct the county clerk to hold an election based on a board composed of five members. The remedy sought would have defeated the public interest in the stability and finality of election results and could only result from a declaration that the special election was void, which was the very essence of an election contest. Rock v. Lankford, 2013 WY 61, 301 P.3d 1075, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2013).

Suit by three challengers to a ballot proposition that returned the size of the county commission to three was dismissed because the challengers failed to bring the contest within the time specified in Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-17-105 and through the five electors required. Rock v. Lankford, 2013 WY 61, 301 P.3d 1075, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2013).

Cited in

Snell v. Johnson County Sch. Dist. No. 1, 2004 WY 19, 86 P.3d 248, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (2004).

§ 22-17-107. Defense of contested ballot proposition.

  1. A contested ballot proposition shall be defended by the following officers:
    1. Statewide proposition — attorney general;
    2. Countywide proposition — county attorney;
    3. Municipal proposition — municipal attorney;
    4. School or community college district or other special district proposition — the appropriate school board, community college board or special district governing body.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-248; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 22-17-108. Court judgment in contests.

A judgment of the court in an election contest shall confirm or annul the election or declare elected a qualified candidate receiving the highest number of legal votes, or declare the result of the election on each contested ballot proposition. The election of a candidate receiving the highest number of legal votes but disqualified for any other legal reason shall be declared null and void and a vacancy will be declared to exist. For offices to be filled by more than one (1) candidate, the election shall not be declared null and void but the qualified candidates receiving the highest number of legal votes shall be declared elected.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-249.

Court errs in directing special election following election with unqualified candidate. —

The district court correctly ruled that a candidate, who had been convicted of a felony in another state and who had not had his rights restored in Wyoming, was unqualified to run for county commissioner. The fact that Wyoming might have treated the candidate's conviction as a misdemeanor had it occurred here, and that the candidate did not lose his civil rights in the state of conviction, did not alter this outcome. However, the court erred in issuing a writ of mandamus directing the holding of a special election, as a judgment annulling the election in which the unqualified candidate's name appeared on the ballot was the appropriate remedy. Mills v. Campbell County Canvassing Bd., 707 P.2d 747, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 588 (Wyo. 1985).

Where a losing candidate in a town council election successfully challenged the election of the winning candidate who was not a registered voter when he filed his petition, the correct remedy was to not void the entire council election but rather to annul the election of the winning candidate and to declare elected the qualified candidate receiving the highest number of legal votes. Smith v. Brito, 2007 WY 191, 173 P.3d 351, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 203 (Wyo. 2007).

Quoted in

Rock v. Lankford, 2013 WY 61, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (May 17, 2013).

§ 22-17-109. Contesting election of state legislator; generally.

The election of a member of the state legislature may be contested by a registered elector of the legislator’s county or district, upon any of the grounds specified by law for the contest of the election of other elected officials. The state senate and house of representatives respectively shall hear and determine contests of the election of their members. Each house is authorized to provide its own rules for resolving contests of its members.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-250.

Cross references. —

For grounds to contest elections generally, see § 22-17-101.

For provision that each house shall be judge of election returns and qualification of members, see art. 3, § 10, Wyo. Const.

§ 22-17-110. Contesting election of state legislator; commencement.

A contest of the election of a member of the state legislature shall be commenced within thirty (30) days after his election has been certified by the state canvassing board by serving him personally or at his mailing address with a notice of intent to contest setting forth the grounds for the contest. A copy of that notice must be filed by the contestant with the secretary of state within thirty (30) days after the contested member’s election has been certified by the state canvassing board.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-251; 1995, ch. 43, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-17-111. Contesting election of state legislator; taking of depositions.

In a contest of the election of a member of the state legislature, depositions may be taken by either party after service of the notice of intent to contest. Depositions shall be taken as in a civil action and the officer taking depositions has the power to compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of papers, objects, and other evidence, by subpoena.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-252.

Cross references. —

As to taking of depositions generally, see Rules 26 to 32, W.R.C.P.

§ 22-17-112. Contesting election of state legislator; handling of depositions by secretary of state; additional depositions.

  1. A copy of a notice to take a deposition with proof of service, and the deposition, shall be sealed and mailed to the secretary of state by the person requesting the deposition with an endorsement showing the names of the contesting parties, the legislative office contested, and the nature of the papers. The secretary of state shall then deliver each such sealed notice for deposition to the presiding officer of the branch of the legislature to which the contest relates on the first day of its session.
  2. Each house of the legislature may take additional depositions and subpoena and examine witnesses.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-253.

§ 22-17-113. Contesting election of state legislator; legislative determination final.

A determination by either house of the legislature of the result of an election contest affecting one (1) of its members is final and conclusive and is not subject to judicial review.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-254.

§ 22-17-114. Contesting election of president, vice-president or presidential elector.

The election of a United States president and vice-president candidate, or presidential elector, shall only be contested, presented to and tried before the Wyoming legislature under joint rules of the house of representatives and senate. Such a contest may be initiated by a Wyoming elector by filing notice with the legislature through the legislative service office no later than five (5) days after the election is certified by the state canvassing board. The contest shall only be brought on the grounds provided by W.S. 22-17-101(a)(i) or (iv). A determination of the contest by the legislature is final and conclusive and is not subject to judicial review.

History.

Laws 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 35, § 1.

Chapter 18 Vacancies

  • § 22-18-101.  When deemed to occur.
  • § 22-18-102.  Determination of existence.
  • § 22-18-103.  Filling vacancy of congressman; generally.
  • § 22-18-104.  Filling vacancy of congressman; procedure.
  • § 22-18-105.  Filling vacancy of congressman; whether filled at general or special election.
  • § 22-18-106.  Filling vacancy of congressman; nominations by state central committees; independent candidates.
  • § 22-18-107.  Filling vacancy of congressman; certification of candidates.
  • § 22-18-108.  Filling vacancy of congressman; party requirements.
  • § 22-18-109.  Conduct of special election; preparation of ballot.
  • § 22-18-110.  Supreme court justices and district court judges.
  • § 22-18-111.  Vacancies in other offices; temporary appointments.
  • § 22-18-112.  Certificate of appointment.

Cross references. —

For provision concerning filling of vacancies generally, see art. 3, § 51, Wyo. Const.

§ 22-18-101. When deemed to occur.

  1. A vacancy shall occur in an elective office if during his term the incumbent either:
    1. Dies;
    2. Resigns;
    3. Is determined by a court having jurisdiction to be mentally incompetent;
    4. Is disqualified from holding office for any reason specified by law;
    5. Is convicted of a felony or constituting a breach of his oath of office;
    6. Refuses to take the oath of office or to give or renew an official bond if required by law; or
    7. Has his election voided by court decision.
  2. A vacancy exists in an elective office, if upon expiration of the term for which a person was elected a successor has not been elected and qualified.
  3. A vacancy exists in an elective office and shall be filled in the same manner as it is filled when a vacancy occurs after the term of office has begun if, after a person has been elected to an office at an election, but before the time for the taking of the oath for that office, the person:
    1. Dies; or
    2. Resigns. A person may resign an office before taking the oath for that office and before the term of office begins in the same manner that he may resign after taking the oath of office.
  4. If a person who has died is elected, a vacancy in office shall occur and the office shall be filled in the same manner as it is filled when a vacancy occurs after the term of office has begun.
  5. This section shall not apply to mayors and council members who are subject to the provisions of W.S. 15-1-107.
  6. In addition to subsections (a) through (c) of this section, a vacancy shall occur:
    1. In the office of a member of the state legislature when the person fails to reside in the legislative district from which he is elected;
    2. In the office of a county assessor, county clerk, county commissioner, county sheriff or county treasurer when the person fails to reside in the county from which he is elected.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-255; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2003, ch. 94, § 1; 2021 ch. 165, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2021 amendment , effective July 1, 2021, added the (f)(i) designation; added (f)(ii); and made related changes.

Applicability. —

Laws 2021, ch. 165, § 2, provides: "The residency requirements of this act shall apply to elected or appointed county officers whose terms commence on or after the effective date of this act."

Acquiescence constituting vacancy. —

Where governor's appointment to public office was invalid because there was no vacancy, but the old officer acquiesced in governor's appointee occupying his office, the former abandoned and vacated office and new appointee stood in his shoes as hold-over incumbent. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

Acceptance of resignation necessary. —

The common-law rule of requiring an acceptance of a resignation by proper authority before it can become effective so as to divest an incumbent of the public office has not been abrogated in this state. State ex rel. Raymond v. Jefferis, 26 Wyo. 115, 178 P. 909, 1919 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1919).

Arbitrary declaration of vacancy cannot be made, and there must in fact be a vacancy before an appointment can be effective. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

Evidence of appointment. —

Appointment by the governor of a person to the office of fish commissioner is such an official act as the law requires to be evidenced by a written instrument executed by him. State ex rel. Miller v. Barber, 4 Wyo. 409, 34 P. 1028, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1893).

Death before commencement of term and approval of bond. —

After a person had been elected a justice of the peace and had filed his oath and bond but, before the commencement of the term for which he was elected and before his bond was approved, he died, the person already holding the office was the “incumbent” within the meaning of the section, and the death of the other did not create a vacancy. Ballantyne v. Bower, 17 Wyo. 356, 99 P. 869, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1909).

Legislative intent that undersheriff act only while vacancyexists. —

Statute providing undersheriff becomes sheriff upon vacancy in office of sheriff is read in pari materia with sections giving county commissioners power of appointment upon vacancy, providing that every elective office becomes vacant upon death or resignation, and relating to sheriff's bonds, indicating legislative intent that undersheriff act as sheriff only while vacancy exists. State ex rel. Peterson v. Ellsworth, 59 Wyo. 288, 139 P.2d 744, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 1943).

No vacancy during military service. —

A district judge who during his term of office entered the service of the United States as a major in the judge advocate general's department, upon returning to and resuming office of district judge was a de jure and not a de facto judge, where he had not resigned and his office had not been declared vacant and no successor had qualified. State ex rel. Raymond v. Jefferis, 26 Wyo. 115, 178 P. 909, 1919 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1919).

Where mode of filling office provided. —

A former statute provided for a state examiner, to be appointed by the governor with the consent of the senate, who shall hold office for four years, and till his successor is appointed and qualified, and the governor not having appointed, with the consent of the senate, a person to fill the office, at the next meeting of the legislature after a vacancy had been filled by the governor, no vacancy in the office arose, so as to bring into operation art. 4, § 7, Wyo. Const., authorizing the governor to fill a vacancy where no other mode of filling it is provided. State ex rel. Richardson v. Henderson, 4 Wyo. 535, 35 P. 517, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1894).

§ 22-18-102. Determination of existence.

The officer or governmental body having the power to fill a vacancy in the office shall determine whether a vacancy exists in the office.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-256.

§ 22-18-103. Filling vacancy of congressman; generally.

A vacancy in the office of representative in congress shall be filled for the unexpired term at a special election called for the purpose by the governor, provided the vacancy does not occur within six (6) months of the next general election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-257.

§ 22-18-104. Filling vacancy of congressman; procedure.

The governor shall call such special election by issuing a writ of election to the county clerk of each county voting for the office and to the secretary of state. The writ shall specify the day of the election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-258; Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-18-105. Filling vacancy of congressman; whether filled at general or special election.

If the vacancy in the office of representative in congress occurs within six (6) months prior to the next general election, the vacancy shall be filled at the general election. Otherwise the special election shall occur on the Tuesday following the eighty-ninth day after the vacancy occurs, unless that Tuesday falls on a full legal holiday in which case the election shall occur on the next Tuesday which is not a full legal holiday. The governor shall declare the vacancy and issue the writ of election within five (5) days after the vacancy occurs.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-259; 2013 ch. 28, § 1, effective July 1, 2013; 2015 ch. 8, § 1, effective February 25, 2015.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, substituted “fifty-five (55)” for “forty (40)” in the second sentence.

The 2015 amendment, substituted “on the Tuesday following the eighty-ninth day” for “not more than fifty-five (55) days” and added “unless that Tuesday falls on a full legal holiday in which case the election shall occur on the next Tuesday which is not a full legal holiday”.

Object and purpose of section. —

See In re Romer, 436 P.2d 956, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 153 (Wyo. 1968).

§ 22-18-106. Filling vacancy of congressman; nominations by state central committees; independent candidates.

An elector qualified to hold the office of representative in congress shall be nominated by the state central committee of the respective parties to fill a vacancy for the unexpired term of that office. Nominations from such parties shall be filed with the secretary of state and fees paid within seven (7) days after the vacancy is officially declared. Independent candidates shall file an application and pay the filing fee with the secretary of state within seven (7) days after the vacancy is officially declared.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-260; Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2015 ch. 8, § 1, effective February 25, 2015.

The 2015 amendment, substituted “seven (7) days” for “fifteen (15) days” in two places.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

As to amount of fees, see § 22-5-208.

§ 22-18-107. Filling vacancy of congressman; certification of candidates.

Within five (5) days after the end of the candidate filing period, the secretary of state shall certify to the clerks of counties voting to fill the vacancy the name of each candidate qualified to appear on the ballot, and his party affiliation or independent status.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-261; 2015 ch. 8, § 1, effective February 25, 2015.

The 2015 amendment, substituted “five (5) days” for “twenty (20) days”, “end of the candidate filing period” for “vacancy is declared,” and “independent status” for “the name of a group or organization sponsoring an independent candidate”

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-18-108. Filling vacancy of congressman; party requirements.

A candidate for the unexpired term of the office of representative in congress may seek election only as a candidate of the political party in which he was registered on the date the vacancy occurred. A candidate for the unexpired term of office of representative in congress who was not registered with a party on the date the vacancy occurred may run only as an independent.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-262; Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-18-109. Conduct of special election; preparation of ballot.

A special election to fill a vacancy shall be conducted by the county clerk as nearly as possible in the manner of a general election. The county clerk shall have twelve (12) days to prepare the special election ballot after the secretary of state’s certification under W.S. 22-18-107. The candidate who receives a plurality of the votes at a special election shall be issued a certificate of election as provided by law.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-263; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 2015 ch. 8, § 1, effective February 25, 2015.

The 2015 amendment, added the second sentence.

§ 22-18-110. Supreme court justices and district court judges.

A vacancy in the office of justice of the supreme court or judge of any district court shall be filled by a qualified person appointed by the governor under section 4, of article 5 of the constitution of Wyoming.

History.
