Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-264.

§ 22-18-111. Vacancies in other offices; temporary appointments.

  1. Any vacancy in any other elective office in the state except representative in congress or the board of trustees of a school or community college district, shall be filled by the governing body, or as otherwise provided in this section, by appointment of a temporary successor. The person appointed shall serve until a successor for the remainder of the unexpired term is elected at the next general election and takes office on the first Monday of the following January. Provided, if a vacancy in a four (4) year term of office occurs in the term’s second or subsequent years after the first day for filing an application for nomination pursuant to W.S. 22-5-209, no election to fill the vacancy shall be held and the temporary successor appointed shall serve the remainder of the unexpired term. The following apply:
    1. If a vacancy  occurs in the office of United States senator or in any state office  other than the governor, member of the  state legislature, the office of justice of the supreme  court and the office of district court judge, the governor shall immediately  notify in writing the chairman of the state central committee of the  political party which the last incumbent represented at the time of  his election under W.S. 22-6-120(a)(vii), or at the time of his appointment if not elected to  office. The chairman shall call a meeting of the state central committee  to be held not later than fifteen (15) days after he receives notice  of the vacancy. At the meeting the state central committee shall select  and transmit to the governor the names of three (3) persons qualified  to hold the office. Within five (5) days  after receiving these three (3) names, the governor shall fill the  vacancy by temporary appointment of one (1) of the three (3) to hold  the office. If the incumbent who has vacated office did not represent  a political party at the time of his election, or at the time of his  appointment if not elected to office, the governor shall notify in  writing the chairman of all state central committees of parties registered  with the secretary of state. The state central committees shall submit  to the governor, within fifteen (15) days after notice of the vacancy,  the name of one (1) person qualified to hold the  office. The governor shall also cause to be published  in a newspaper of general circulation in the state notice of the vacancy  in office. Persons qualified  to hold the office who do not belong to a party may,  within fifteen (15) days after publication of the vacancy in office,  submit a petition signed by one hundred (100) registered voters, seeking  consideration for appointment to the office. Within five (5) days  after receiving the names of persons qualified to hold the office, the governor shall fill the vacancy by temporary appointment to  the office, from the names submitted or from those petitioning for  appointment;
    2. If a vacancy  occurs in a county elective office, except as provided in W.S. 18-3-524, the board of county commissioners of the county in which the vacancy  occurs shall immediately notify in writing the chairman of the county  central committee of the political party which the last incumbent  represented at the time of his election under W.S. 22-6-120(a)(vii), or at the time of his appointment if not elected to  office. The chairman shall call a meeting of the county central committee  to be held not later than fifteen (15) days after he receives notice  of the vacancy. At the meeting the county central committee shall  select and transmit to the board of county commissioners the names  of three (3) persons qualified to hold the office. Within five (5) days after receiving these three (3) names, the  board of county commissioners shall fill the vacancy by appointment  of one (1) of the three (3) to hold the office. If the incumbent who  has vacated office did not represent a political party at the time  of his election, or at the time of his appointment if not elected  to office, the county commissioners shall publish in a newspaper of  general circulation in the county, notice that within fifteen (15)  days after publication any person qualified to hold the office may make application directly to the county commissioners for appointment  to fill the vacancy. Within twenty (20) days after the publication  of the vacancy in office the county commissioners shall fill the vacancy  by appointment of one (1) person qualified to hold the office from those submitting applications;
    3. If a vacancy occurs in the office of a member of the state legislature:
      1. For vacancies  other than resignations, the board of county commissioners of the  county or counties in which the vacancy occurs shall immediately notify  in writing the chairman of the state central committee of the political  party which the former incumbent represented at the time of his election  under W.S. 22-6-120(a)(vii), or at the time of his appointment if not elected to  office. For resignations, the governor shall notify the appropriate  state central committee or the appropriate board of county commissioners  in accordance with W.S. 28-1-106. For all vacancies in which the incumbent represented a political  party at the time of his election or appointment to the office, the  state central committee of the political party of the former incumbent  shall notify the precinct committeemen and committeewomen for that  party for each precinct within the legislative district which is vacant  and arrange a meeting of those precinct committeemen and committeewomen  at which they will select a list of three (3) persons qualified to hold the office to fill the vacancy.  Only those persons serving as committeemen and committeewomen at least  thirty (30) days prior to the vacancy, or if the vacancy occurs within  thirty (30) days after the first Monday in January in odd-numbered  years, those precinct committeemen and committeewomen elected at the  immediate past primary election and those selected by appointment  prior to December 2 of the year in which the election occurred for  vacant positions, shall be authorized to vote under this subparagraph.  The meeting shall be held not later than fifteen (15) days after the  state central committee is notified of the vacancy. The state central  committee of each political party shall establish procedures for conducting  the vote required under this subparagraph and may delegate the authority  to call the meeting required under this subparagraph;
      2. The state central committee of the political party of the former incumbent shall submit the list selected under subparagraph (A) of this paragraph to the board of county commissioners for each county in which the legislative district is located. Within five (5) days after receiving the list of three (3) names, the board of county commissioners shall fill the vacancy by appointment of one (1) of the three (3) to hold the office;
      3. If the incumbent  who has vacated office did not represent a political party at the  time of his election under W.S. 22-6-120(a)(vii), or at the time of his appointment if not elected to  office, the county commissioners shall proceed in accordance with  the provisions of this subparagraph. The county commissioners shall  publish in a newspaper of general circulation in the county, notice  that within fifteen (15) days after publication, any person qualified to hold the office may make application directly to the county commissioners for appointment  to fill the vacancy. Within twenty (20) days after publication of  the notice of the vacancy in office, the county commissioners shall fill the vacancy by appointing one (1) person qualified to hold the office from among those submitting applications;
      4. If the legislative district is in more than one (1) county, the vacancy shall be filled by the combined vote of the boards of county commissioners for those counties. The vote of each county commissioner in attendance shall be weighted so that the total vote of the commissioners from each county shall be in proportion to the population of the legislative district within that county. For vacancies created other than by resignation, if the legislative district is in more than one (1) county, the determination of the vacancy shall be made in accordance with this subparagraph.
    4. A vacancy in the office of any hospital district trustee or in any other special district office shall be filled by temporary appointment by the governing body of the hospital or special district, both subject to chapter 29 of this title;
    5. A vacancy in a municipal office shall be filled as provided by W.S. 15-1-107;
    6. If the county  commissioners fail to fill any vacancy as required in this section  within the time specified, any person residing  in the county or legislative  district who is qualified to hold the office may file  a petition with the clerk of the district court of the county or legislative district in which the  vacancy occurred requesting the judge of the district court to fill  the vacancy. Within thirty (30) days after the petition is filed the  judge shall fill the vacancy by appointing a person residing in the county or legislative district belonging to  the same political party as the incumbent represented at the time  of his election under W.S. 22-6-120(a)(vii), or at the time of his appointment if not elected to  office, who is qualified to hold the office. If the incumbent did not represent any political party at the time  of his election or at the time of his appointment if not elected to  office, the judge may appoint any person residing  in the county or legislative district who is qualified to hold the  office to fill the vacancy.
  2. The trustees  of a school or community college district shall fill a vacancy in  office by temporary appointment in a manner provided by law. If the  trustees fail to appoint a person qualified to hold the office to fill a vacancy within thirty (30) days from the date the vacancy  occurs, or if, for any reason, the entire membership of the board  of trustees of a school or community college district is depleted,  the board of county commissioners of the county or counties involved,  within ten (10) days of either occurrence, shall appoint a person qualified to hold the office to fill  each vacancy until the next election at which time an election shall  be held to fill the unexpired term, and each appointee shall serve  until his successor is elected and qualified. Each appointee shall  be a resident of the trustee residence area, or election subdistrict,  if any, previously represented.
  3. For purposes  of this section:
    1. A person shall be considered to represent a political party if he was  a nominee of that political party when elected to office or when appointed  to fill a vacancy in office;
    2. “Qualified to hold the office” means  a person meets all applicable qualifications to be elected to a public  office which are set forth in the United States and Wyoming constitutions  and Wyoming law, as applicable, on the date of the person’s  appointment to the public office.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-265; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1979, ch. 3, § 1; ch. 53, § 1; 1981, ch. 159, § 1; 1985, ch. 204, § 1; 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1992, ch. 1, § 6; 1993, ch. 91, § 1; 1994, ch. 99, § 2; 1996, ch. 93, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2004, ch. 22, § 1; 2006, ch. 114, § 1; 2009, ch. 170, § 1; 2011, ch. 38, § 1; 2013 ch. 159, § 1, effective July 1, 2013; ; 2015, ch. 154, § 1; 2015 ch. 154, § 1, effective July 1, 2015; 2018 ch. 118, § 1, effective March 14, 2018.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

As to state committeeman or committeewoman, see § 22-4-112.

As to nominations for elective office, see § 22-5-401.

As to judges of elections and members of counting boards, see § 22-8-112.

As to congressional representative, see § 22-18-103.

As to filling vacancies in the office of justice of the supreme court or judge of district court, see § 22-18-110.

As to filling vacancies in nomination for presidential elector, see § 22-19-105.

As to filling vacancies in office of presidential elector, see § 22-19-106.

For provision concerning filling of vacancies in school or community college districts, see § 22-22-102.

As to filling vacancies in office of county commissioners, see § 18-3-524.

The 2004 amendment rewrote (a), substituting provisions pertaining to a person representing a political party rather than belonging to a political party, and modifying timing and notice requirements; and added (c).

Laws 2004, ch. 22, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 2, 2004.

The 2006 amendment, substituted “title” for “act” in (a)(iv).

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 24, 2006.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in (a)(iii)(D), deleted “according to the most recent decennial census” from the end of the second to last sentence.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in the introductory language of (a), inserted “The person appointed shall,” “Provided,” “in the term's second or subsequent years,” and “election to fill the vacancy shall be held and,” and substituted “the remainder of the unexpired term” for “until the first Monday in January following the second general election thereafter.”

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, added “or if the vacancy occurs within thirty (30) days after a primary election, including precinct committeemen and committeewomen elected at that primary” in (a)(iii)(A).

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, in (a)(iii)(A), substituted “the first Monday in January in odd-numbered years, those precinct committeemen and committeewomen elected at the immediate past primary election and those selected by appointment prior to December 2 of the year in which the election occurred for vacant positions” for “a primary election, including precinct committeemen and committeewomen elected at that primary” in the fourth sentence.

The 2018 amendment, in (a)(i), in the first sentence, inserted “governor, member of the state legislature, the,” in the third and sixth sentences, substituted “hold the office” for “fill the vacancy,” and in the next-to-last and last sentences, substituted “Persons qualified to hold the office” for “Qualified persons”; in (a)(ii), in the third sentence, substituted “hold the office” for “fill the vacancy,” in the next-to-last sentence, substituted “person qualified to hold the office” for “qualified person,” and in the last sentence inserted “to hold the office” following “person qualified,” in (a)(iii)(A), at the end of the third sentence, substituted “to hold the office” for “to fill the vacancy,” in the next-to-last sentence, substituted “person qualified to hold the office” for “qualified person” preceding “may,” and, in the last sentence, inserted “to hold the office” following “qualified”; in (a)(iii)(C), in the second sentence, substituted “person qualified to hold the office” for “qualified person” preceding “may,” and in the last sentence substituted “appointing one (1) person qualified to hold the office from among” for “appointment of one (1) person qualified from” preceding “those submitting applications,” in (a)(vi), inserted “who is qualified to hold the office” wherever it appears, in the first sentence, substituted “person residing in the county or legislative district” for “qualified elector of the county” and inserted “or legislative district” preceding “in which,” in the second sentence, substituted “person residing in the county or legislative district” for qualified elector of the county” and inserted “ or legislative district” preceding “belonging,” and in the last sentence, substituted “person residing in the county or legislative district” for “any qualified elector of”; in (b), twice substituted “person qualified to hold the office” for “qualified person” following “appoint a”; added (c)(ii); redesignated the existing language in (c) as the present introductory language and (c)(i), and made a stylistic change in present (c)(i).

Laws 2018, ch. 118, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 14, 2018.

Editor's notes. —

The word “title” was inserted in brackets following “this act” in subsection (a)(iv) as “this title” appears to be the intended reference.

Laws 2009 ch 170 § 3 provides:

“(a) No authority to issue any license based upon population shall be diminished by application of this act until the 2010 federal decennial census has been conducted and officially released by the bureau of census.

“(b) No distribution of funding shall be diminished or increased based upon application of this act until the 2010 federal decennial census has been conducted and officially released by the bureau of census. To the extent any entity's share of funding would be reduced or increased by application of this act before that time, the distribution of funds shall be administered in accordance with the provisions of law prior to the amendment or repeal of such law by this act.”

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 3, provides: “[A]ny other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

General election. —

A person elected to fill a vacancy in the office of governor on Tuesday next after the first Monday of November, 1892, was elected at a general election. In re Moore, 4 Wyo. 98, 31 P. 980, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1893).

Length of term. —

Where a person appointed to fill a vacancy in the office of state treasurer was afterward elected to the office at a general election held before the term of his predecessor would have expired, he was not entitled to hold the office for four years after such general election, but only for the remainder of his predecessor's term. State ex rel. Irvine v. Brooks, 14 Wyo. 393, 84 P. 488, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1906).

Nomination by state central committee. —

Statutes held not to authorize state central committee to nominate candidate for office of secretary of state to fill unexpired term of one who died 26 days before general election date. State ex rel. Copenhaver v. Jack, 60 Wyo. 405, 153 P.2d 149, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1944).

§ 22-18-112. Certificate of appointment.

The officer or governmental body filling a vacancy by temporary appointment shall issue a “Certificate of Appointment” to the person filling the vacancy. The certificate shall be lawful authority to hold the office.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-266.

Chapter 19 Presidential Electors

  • § 22-19-101.  When elected; number.
  • § 22-19-102.  Nomination.
  • § 22-19-103.  Crediting of votes.
  • § 22-19-104.  Certificate of election; directive.
  • § 22-19-105.  Vacancy in nomination.
  • § 22-19-106.  Certified electors to meet; vacancies.
  • § 22-19-107.  College of electors; duties.
  • § 22-19-108.  How electors to vote.
  • § 22-19-109.  Compensation and mileage.

Cross references. —

For duties of electors, see U.S. Const. amend. XII.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

25 Am. Jur. 2d Elections § 6; 77 Am. Jur. 2d United States § 43.

§ 22-19-101. When elected; number.

At a general election for president and vice-president of the United States, electors for president and vice-president of the United States shall be elected equal in number to senators and representatives in congress allotted to the state of Wyoming.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-267.

§ 22-19-102. Nomination.

  1. In a general election year, the state convention of a political party nominating candidates for president and vice-president of the United States shall nominate the party’s candidates for presidential electors and file certificates of nomination for these candidates with the secretary of state not later than thirty (30) days following termination of the state convention.
  2. Independent candidates for president shall file the candidate’s nominees for presidential electors not less than seventy (70) days prior to the general election. The nominees shall be qualified electors.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-268; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-19-103. Crediting of votes.

The number of votes received by presidential and vice-presidential candidates is the number of votes credited to their electors.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-269; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1997, ch. 40, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-19-104. Certificate of election; directive.

Immediately upon filing of the certificate of the state canvassing board stating the result of the election, the governor shall issue a certificate of election to candidates elected to the office of presidential elector. The certificate shall direct the elector to attend a meeting with the governor in the office of the secretary of state at 12:00 noon on the Monday following the second Wednesday in December of presidential election years.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S 1957, § 22.1-270.

§ 22-19-105. Vacancy in nomination.

A vacancy in nomination for the office of presidential elector occurring before the general election shall be filled by the state central committee of the political party whose vacancy is to be filled or by an independent candidate’s remaining electors, by certifying the name of the person filling the vacancy to the secretary of state.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-271; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-19-106. Certified electors to meet; vacancies.

Certified electors shall convene in the office of the secretary of state at 12:00 noon on the Monday following the second Wednesday in December of presidential election years. A vacancy in the office of elector for any cause including nonattendance shall be filled and certified by a majority of electors present.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-272.

§ 22-19-107. College of electors; duties.

When all electors are present and vacancies filled they shall constitute the college of electors of the state of Wyoming and shall perform duties as required by the constitution and laws of the United States.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-273.

§ 22-19-108. How electors to vote.

All Wyoming electors shall vote for the candidates for the office of president and vice-president receiving the highest number of votes in the Wyoming general election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-274.

§ 22-19-109. Compensation and mileage.

An elector shall receive fifty dollars ($50.00) compensation and mileage at the present rate for state employees.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-275; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

Chapter 20 Constitutional Amendments

  • Article 1. Amendments to Wyoming Constitution
  • Article 2. Amendments to the Constitution of the United States

Cross references. —

For constitutional provisions, see art. 20, §§ 1 to 4, Wyo. Const.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

16 Am. Jur. 2d Constitutional Law §§ 12 to 39.

16 C.J.S. Constitutional Law §§ 6 to 14.

Article 1. Amendments to Wyoming Constitution

  • § 22-20-101.  Ratification of proposed amendment or new constitution.
  • § 22-20-102.  Transmittal to secretary of state; numbering and endorsement; ballot statement.
  • § 22-20-103.  Transmittal to county clerk; posting.
  • § 22-20-104.  Publication by secretary of state; supplemental publication by clerk.
  • § 22-20-105.  Pamphlet.
  • § 22-20-106.  Publication expense.
  • § 22-20-107.  Statement of purpose on ballot.
  • § 22-20-108.  Proclamation of adoption; effective date.
  • § 22-20-109.  Publication in session laws.

§ 22-20-101. Ratification of proposed amendment or new constitution.

A proposed amendment to the constitution of the state of Wyoming submitted by a two-thirds vote of each of the houses of the state legislature or a proposed new constitution submitted by a constitutional convention may be ratified by a majority of the electors voting at the next general election. Voting on a proposed amendment or new constitution shall be regulated by general election laws.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-276.

Cited in

Geringer v. Bebout, 10 P.3d 514, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 2000).

§ 22-20-102. Transmittal to secretary of state; numbering and endorsement; ballot statement.

  1. A proposed amendment shall be transmitted to the office of the secretary of state by the house in which it originates or by a constitutional convention. The secretary of state shall letter each proposed amendment serially in the order received from the legislature or convention and shall endorse upon a proposed amendment, a brief statement of the purpose of the amendment. If the bill proposing the amendment provides this statement, it shall be adopted by the secretary of state.
  2. The letter and statement endorsed on a proposed amendment are part of the amendment for purposes of reference in submitting the amendment to the electors and shall constitute the ballot statement of the amendment.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-277; Laws 1995, ch. 115, § 1.

§ 22-20-103. Transmittal to county clerk; posting.

The secretary of state shall mail a certified copy of a proposed amendment and statement of its purpose filed in his office to each county clerk not less than sixty (60) days prior to the election at which the proposed amendment is submitted to the electors. The county clerk shall immediately post in his office the copy of a proposed amendment and statement of its purpose received from the secretary of state. The copy shall remain posted until after the election at which the amendment is submitted to the vote of the electors.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-278; Laws 1985, ch. 204, § 1; 1990, ch. 42, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-20-104. Publication by secretary of state; supplemental publication by clerk.

  1. The secretary of state shall publish each proposed amendment and a notice that it will be submitted to the electors at the next general election, once a week for at least twelve (12) consecutive weeks prior to the election in a newspaper of general circulation published in each county and, if possible, once each week for three (3) consecutive weeks within thirty (30) days prior to the election in one (1) other newspaper of general circulation in each county.
  2. The clerk may supplement publication thereof by radio or television broadcasts or both. The broadcasts shall identify the proposed amendment or other question, by letter and statement of purpose as prescribed by law, and shall state the name of the newspaper in which the published notice will appear and the date on which it will appear.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-279; Laws 1995, ch. 115, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-20-105. Pamphlet.

The secretary of state shall print a reasonable number of pamphlets containing every proposed amendment and provide a copy of the pamphlet upon request to any person or organization.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-280; Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-20-106. Publication expense.

The expense of publication of notice of proposed amendments and voter pamphlets shall be paid out of the general fund of the state.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-281.

§ 22-20-107. Statement of purpose on ballot.

The county clerk shall print on the official nonpartisan general election ballot for the next general election the statement of purpose of each proposed amendment certified to him by the secretary of state.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-282.

§ 22-20-108. Proclamation of adoption; effective date.

The governor shall issue a proclamation of adoption not later than ten (10) days after the adoption of each proposed amendment has been officially certified by the state canvassing board. A proposed amendment is effective on the date it is proclaimed adopted by the governor.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-283.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-20-109. Publication in session laws.

Each constitutional amendment proposed by the legislature, and if possible each proposed by a constitutional convention, and each constitutional amendment adopted by the vote of the people, shall be published in the next session laws.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-284.

Article 2. Amendments to the Constitution of the United States

  • § 22-20-201.  Proclamation of governor calling state ratifying convention.
  • § 22-20-202.  Election of delegates to state ratifying convention.
  • § 22-20-203.  Convening of county convention; presiding officer; certification of results.
  • § 22-20-204.  Rules of practice for county conventions; convention ballots.
  • § 22-20-205.  Determining apportionment of representation at conventions.
  • § 22-20-206.  Board of commissioners to act as election commissioners.
  • § 22-20-207.  Costs and expenses to be borne by county.
  • § 22-20-208.  Convening of state ratifying convention; costs and expenses; certification of results.
  • § 22-20-209.  Procedure when congress directs manner of holding ratifying convention.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

25 Am. Jur. 2d Elections, §§ 1, 2.

§ 22-20-201. Proclamation of governor calling state ratifying convention.

  1. If the congress of the United States of America proposes any question of repealing, amending or altering the constitution of the United States of America, or any part thereof, to be submitted to a ratifying convention of delegates chosen by the qualified electors of the state and does not prescribe the manner and method of calling, holding and conducting the convention and of canvassing the returns of the votes of the delegates thereto and determining, declaring and publishing the result of the vote of the delegates to the ratifying convention on any question voted upon, for which the ratifying convention is called, it is the duty of the governor to make a public proclamation:
    1. Calling the state ratifying convention;
    2. Calling for the election of delegates to the state ratifying convention;
    3. Specifying the place where and the time when the ratifying convention shall be held;
    4. Specifying the number of delegates (who shall be qualified electors) of which the ratifying convention shall consist; and
    5. Specifying the method and manner by and in which delegates to the ratifying convention shall be elected.

History.

Laws 1978, ch. 37, § 2; 2017 ch. 197, § 2, effective July 1, 2017.

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, in (a) added “ratifying” before “convention” throughout the subsection and substituted “proposes” for “enact any law requiring” in the first sentence.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 22-20-202. Election of delegates to state ratifying convention.

In each county of this state there shall be held a county convention of the qualified electors of the county at the time fixed by the proclamation. An election shall be held in which not less than five (5) delegates from each county and (1) one additional delegate for each five thousand (5,000) or major portion thereof of the inhabitants of the county shall be elected as delegates to the state ratifying convention specified in W.S. 22-20-201.

History.

Laws 1978, ch. 37, § 2; 2017 ch. 197, § 2, effective July 1, 2017.

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, rewrote the section.

§ 22-20-203. Convening of county convention; presiding officer; certification of results.

It is the duty of the chairman of the board of county commissioners or some other member of the board in each county to convene the county convention and preside over it until the delegates chosen thereto select a chairman of the convention. It is the duty of the chairman and secretary of the convention to certify, under oath, to the secretary of state and to the state ratifying convention, the names of the delegates to the state ratifying convention chosen by the county convention.

History.

Laws 1978, ch. 37, § 2; 2017 ch. 197, § 2, effective July 1, 2017.

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, in (a) added “ratifying” before “convention” twice.

§ 22-20-204. Rules of practice for county conventions; convention ballots.

  1. The rules of practice, procedure and conduct of the business of the several county conventions specified in W.S. 22-20-202 are those prescribed by “Robert’s Rules of Parliamentary Procedure and Order”.
  2. The vote on the selection of delegates to the state ratifying convention shall be by written or printed ballot.

History.

Laws 1978, ch. 37, § 2; 2017 ch. 197, § 2, effective July 1, 2017.

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, in (b) substituted “state ratifying convention” for “county and state conventions.”

§ 22-20-205. Determining apportionment of representation at conventions.

In the apportionment of representation in the county convention and state ratifying convention, the last federal census is the basis upon which the right to representation in the conventions shall be determined.

History.

Laws 1978, ch. 37, § 2; 2009, ch. 170, § 1; 2017 ch. 197, § 2, effective July 1, 2017.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, substituted “federal census” for “census enumeration taken by the United States government.”

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, added “convention” following “county” and substituted “state ratifying convention” for “state conventions”.

Editor's notes. —

Laws 2009 ch 170 § 3 provides:

“(a) No authority to issue any license based upon population shall be diminished by application of this act until the 2010 federal decennial census has been conducted and officially released by the bureau of census.

“(b) No distribution of funding shall be diminished or increased based upon application of this act until the 2010 federal decennial census has been conducted and officially released by the bureau of census. To the extent any entity's share of funding would be reduced or increased by application of this act before that time, the distribution of funds shall be administered in accordance with the provisions of law prior to the amendment or repeal of such law by this act.”

§ 22-20-206. Board of commissioners to act as election commissioners.

For the purpose of providing the necessary facilities and conveniences for conducting each of the meetings and conventions provided for by this chapter, the board of county commissioners of the several counties of this state are appointed election commissioners of their respective counties. It is their duty to do all things necessary and proper to facilitate the qualified electors of their respective counties in expressing their will upon any question submitted to them by the congress of the United States of America.

History.

Laws 1978, ch. 37, § 2.

§ 22-20-207. Costs and expenses to be borne by county.

All costs incurred in carrying out the provisions of this chapter in each county shall be borne and paid by the county in which the costs accrued.

History.

Laws 1978, ch. 37, § 2.

§ 22-20-208. Convening of state ratifying convention; costs and expenses; certification of results.

  1. If the governor issues a proclamation calling a state ratifying convention, it is the duty of the secretary of state to convene the ratifying convention and make all necessary arrangements.
  2. The costs incidental to the holding of the state ratifying convention shall be borne and paid by the state, as appropriated by the legislature.
  3. It is the duty of the officers of the state ratifying convention to certify, under oath, to the secretary of state, the result of the vote cast at the ratifying convention on each question submitted thereto. When the result of the vote of the delegates to the state ratifying convention is certified to the secretary of state, it is then the duty of the secretary of state to certify the result to the president and secretary of state of the United States, and to the president of the senate and the speaker of the house of representatives of the congress of the United States.

History.

Laws 1978, ch. 37, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2017 ch. 197, § 2, effective July 1, 2017.

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, in (a), (b), and (c) substituted “states ratifying convention” for “state convention” numerous times.

§ 22-20-209. Procedure when congress directs manner of holding ratifying convention.

  1. If congress, either in the resolution submitting the question or by statute, prescribes the manner in which the ratifying convention shall be constituted, the provisions of this chapter are inoperative, and the ratifying convention shall be constituted and shall operate as the resolution or act of congress directs. All officers of the state who may be authorized or directed by the resolution or statute to take any action to constitute a ratifying convention for this state are authorized and directed to act in accordance therewith and in obedience thereto with the same force and effect as if acting under a statute of this state.
  2. If an article V convention as defined in W.S. 9-22-101 is called, the provisions of this chapter are inoperative to the extent that they conflict with a convention conducted in accordance with W.S. 9-22-102.

History.

Laws 1978, ch. 37, § 2; 2017 ch. 197, § 2, effective July 1, 2017.

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, added the designation (a), substituted “ratifying convention” for “conventions”, added “ratifying” before “convention” twice; and added (b).

Chapter 21 Bond Elections

  • Article 1. Political Subdivisions
  • Article 2. State

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

25 Am. Jur. 2d Elections § 1 et seq; 64 Am. Jur. 2d Public Securities and Obligations §§ 130 to 162.

Inclusion of several structures or units as affecting validity of submission of proposition to voters at bond election, 4 ALR2d 617.

Validity of municipal bond issue as against owners of property, annexation of which to municipality became effective after date of election at which issue was approved by voters, 10 ALR2d 559.

Rescission of vote authorizing school district or other municipal bond issue, expenditure or tax, 68 ALR2d 1041.

Absentee Voters' Laws as applied to municipal bond elections, 97 ALR2d 257.

Inclusion or exclusion of first and last days in computing time for giving notice of bond issue election, which must be given a certain number of days before a known future date, 98 ALR2d 1331.

Article 1. Political Subdivisions

  • § 22-21-101.  Political Subdivision Bond Election Law.
  • § 22-21-102.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-21-103.  How bond question to be submitted to electors; contents.
  • § 22-21-104.  Publication or posting of election notice; contents.
  • § 22-21-105.  Election districts.
  • § 22-21-106.  Errors.
  • § 22-21-107.  Contests; procedure.
  • § 22-21-108.  Who is entitled to vote.
  • § 22-21-109.  Supplies; regulations; costs.
  • § 22-21-110.  Ballot canvass; results certified; declaration; effect of defeat.
  • § 22-21-111.  Authority granted.
  • § 22-21-112.  Effect on prior bond elections.

§ 22-21-101. Political Subdivision Bond Election Law.

This chapter including W.S. 22-21-101 through 22-21-112, shall be known as the “Political Subdivision Bond Election Law,” and each election required by law to authorize the issuance of bonds shall be conducted under the provisions hereof, except that statewide bond elections shall be conducted as provided in W.S. 22-21-201.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-285; Laws 1978, ch. 38, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to community college bond elections, see § 21-18-314.

Applicability. —

The Political Subdivision Bond Election Law is only applicable when an election is “required by law.” Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

The Political Subdivision Bond Election Law appears to be a commendable effort by the legislature in 1973 to make uniform the procedures to be followed when an election is required prior to issuance of bonds of any sort. There is no language requiring an election approval in all instances when revenue bonds are to be issued. Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Legislature did not intend for financing of municipal water project to be considered a “bond,” and therefore there was no statutory requirement for an election prior to town's incurring debt. Cooper v. Town of Pinedale, 1 P.3d 1197, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 74 (Wyo. 2000).

Constitutionality. —

Law for elections in high school districts on bond issues where property and nonproperty owners may vote, held not to violate constitution regarding free elections or elections creating debts. State ex rel. Voiles v. Johnson County High Sch., 43 Wyo. 494, 5 P.2d 255, 1931 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1931).

Immaterial provision. —

Provisions that ballots are to be placed in separate boxes for property owners and nonproperty owners held immaterial, as the provision for box “A” was surplusage. State ex rel. Voiles v. Johnson County High Sch., 43 Wyo. 494, 5 P.2d 255, 1931 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1931).

Presumption of validity. —

An act must be determined as to its validity under the principle that all enactments are presumed to be valid. State ex rel. Voiles v. Johnson County High Sch., 43 Wyo. 494, 5 P.2d 255, 1931 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1931).

School bond elections. —

High school districts derive right to vote on bond issue from statutes which must be substantially followed, as they have no inherent right to vote on bond issues. State ex rel. Voiles v. Johnson County High Sch., 43 Wyo. 494, 5 P.2d 255, 1931 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1931).

Statutory provisions providing for school elections on bond issue where property and nonproperty owners may vote are not in conflict with constitutional requirements of free elections, art. 1, § 27, Wyo. Const., and equality, art. 6, § 1, Wyo. Const.State ex rel. Voiles v. Johnson County High Sch., 43 Wyo. 494, 5 P.2d 255, 1931 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1931).

§ 22-21-102. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, provided definitions for the article on political subdivision bond elections.

§ 22-21-103. How bond question to be submitted to electors; contents.

Each bond question shall be submitted to a vote of the qualified electors of the political subdivision. Every bond election shall be held on the same day as a primary election or a general election, or on the Tuesday next following the first Monday in May or November, or on the Tuesday next following the third Monday in August. Not less than one hundred ten (110) days before a bond election, the political subdivision shall provide written notification to the county clerk specifying the date of the election and the bond question. The bond question shall state the purpose of the bonds, the maximum principal amount thereof, the maximum number of years allowed for the indebtedness and the maximum rate of interest to be paid thereon. The secretary of state may promulgate reasonable rules for conducting bond elections where the election is not held at the same time as the general or primary election.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-287; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1979, ch. 133, § 2; 1983, ch. 183, § 2; 1994, ch. 99, § 2; 1996, ch. 97, § 2; 1997, ch. 115, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 18, § 2; 2018 ch. 101, § 1, effective March 14, 2018.

The 2018 amendment, at the beginning of the third sentence, substituted “Not less than one hundred ten (110) days before a bond election, the political subdivision shall” for “If calling the election in May, the body political subdivision shall by March 1,” and deleted the former fourth sentence, which read: “If the political subdivision specifies the date of the election to be a primary or general statewide or other August or November election, then the political subdivision shall provide notice to the county clerk not less than one hundred ten (110) days before the election if for a primary or other August election, and not less than seventy (70) days before the election, if for a general or other November election.”

Laws 2018, ch. 101, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 14, 2018.

Law reviews. —

For article, “Corporate Expression in Wyoming Ballot Issues, Referenda and Initiatives: A Political and Legal Dilemma,” see XIV Land & Water L. Rev. 449 (1979).

Notice. —

In a challenge to a school district's use of funds obtained from the sale of bonds to construct school facilities, to the extent the challengers' claim challenged the election itself, it was barred as untimely because it was not filed within the 14 day limit for election contests. However, even if the claim was not time barred, there was no defect in the notice provided the public regarding the bond election where the bond questions clearly stated the purpose of the bonds as required by this statute. Snell v. Johnson County Sch. Dist. No. 1, 2004 WY 19, 86 P.3d 248, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2004).

§ 22-21-104. Publication or posting of election notice; contents.

Between one hundred one (101) and ninety-one (91) days before a bond election held in conjunction with a primary or other August election and between ninety (90) and seventy (70) days before a bond election held in conjunction with a May, general or other November election, the county clerk shall publish notice of the election at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the political subdivision. If there is no newspaper of general circulation in the political subdivision, notice shall be posted at each polling place in the political subdivision between ninety (90) and seventy (70) days before the election. Any notice of election hereunder shall specify the name of the political subdivision, the date, time and place of election, the question or questions to be submitted, and the fact that only qualified electors of the political subdivision may vote thereon. If a bond election is being held within a political subdivision at the same time and place as a regular or other election, the notice of bond election may, at the discretion of the county clerk, be combined with and given in the same manner as the notice of the regular or other election in such political subdivision.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-288; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1979, ch. 133, § 2; 2018 ch. 101, § 1, effective March 14, 2018.

The 2018 amendment, in the first sentence, added the language preceding “the county clerk” and deleted “not less than thirty (30) nor more than forty (40) days before the election” at the end, and in the second sentence substituted “between ninety (90) and seventy (70) days” for “not less than thirty (30) nor more than forty (40) days” following “subdivision.”

Laws 2018, ch. 101, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 14, 2018.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

§ 22-21-105. Election districts.

The political subdivision may be divided by the governing body into convenient subdivisions for the purpose of such election or the governing body may adopt the election districts and precincts established for general or other elections.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-289.

§ 22-21-106. Errors.

No error in any election on the creation of an indebtedness shall invalidate the election, unless it is determined that the error would change the result.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-290; Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-21-107. Contests; procedure.

Any five (5) qualified electors of the political subdivision may contest an election on the question of the creation of an indebtedness upon filing in the district court of any county in which the political subdivision is wholly or partially located, within fourteen (14) days after the result of the election shall have been determined, a petition alleging an error that would change the result of the election, in like form as in other cases of contested elections in the district court. The political subdivision shall be made defendant, and process shall be served upon the clerk of the governing body or other chief clerical officer as in other civil actions. No civil action contesting the results of such an election or alleging election errors may be commenced after the expiration of such fourteen (14) day period.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-291; Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Contests of election results are not actions at law or suits in equity and were unknown to the common law. Johnson v. Cheyenne, 504 P.2d 1081, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 414 U.S. 990, 94 S. Ct. 342, 38 L. Ed. 2d 229, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1184 (U.S. 1973).

Proceedings are special and summary in their nature. Johnson v. Cheyenne, 504 P.2d 1081, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 414 U.S. 990, 94 S. Ct. 342, 38 L. Ed. 2d 229, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1184 (U.S. 1973).

Strict observance of steps necessary to give jurisdiction is required. Johnson v. Cheyenne, 504 P.2d 1081, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 414 U.S. 990, 94 S. Ct. 342, 38 L. Ed. 2d 229, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1184 (U.S. 1973).

And jurisdictional facts must appear on face of proceedings. If these steps are not followed, courts are powerless to entertain such proceedings. Johnson v. Cheyenne, 504 P.2d 1081, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 414 U.S. 990, 94 S. Ct. 342, 38 L. Ed. 2d 229, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1184 (U.S. 1973).

Claim time-barred. —

In a challenge to a school district's use of funds obtained from the sale of bonds to construct school facilities, to the extent the challengers' claim challenged the election itself, it was barred as untimely because it was not filed within the 14 day limit for election contests. Snell v. Johnson County Sch. Dist. No. 1, Snell v. Johnson County Sch. Dist. No. 1, 2004 WY 19, 86 P.3d 248, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2004).

Petitioner must show that results would have been changed.—

The legislature was aware that even in the absence of such statutory provisions as provided in this section the petitioner would still have the burden of showing that the results would have been changed. Johnson v. Cheyenne, 504 P.2d 1081, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 414 U.S. 990, 94 S. Ct. 342, 38 L. Ed. 2d 229, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1184 (U.S. 1973).

§ 22-21-108. Who is entitled to vote.

Any qualified elector in the political subdivision shall be entitled to vote on the bond question in person or by absentee ballot, for the precinct in which he is registered, as provided by law.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-292; Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

Cross references. —

As to registration generally, see §§ 22-3-101 to 22-3-117.

As to absentee voting generally, see §§ 22-9-101 to 22-9-125.

The 2015 amendment, substituted “for the precinct” for “in the precinct”.

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

Constitutionality of durational residence requirements. —

Durational residence laws are unconstitutional unless a state can demonstrate that such laws are necessary to promote compelling governmental interest, it not being sufficient for a state to show that requirements further a very substantial state interest. Torres v. Laramie County School Dist. No. 1, Torres v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 506 P.2d 817, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 144 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 414 U.S. 990, 94 S. Ct. 342, 38 L. Ed. 2d 229, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1185 (U.S. 1973).

The legislature is free to establish durational residence requirements for any period for which their investigation shows there is a compelling reason. Torres v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 506 P.2d 817, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 144 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 414 U.S. 990, 94 S. Ct. 342, 38 L. Ed. 2d 229, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1185 (U.S. 1973).

Guidelines as to residence requirements pending action by legislature. —

The Wyoming supreme court has established guidelines for the direction of election officials and citizens with respect to residence requirements pending action by the legislature. Torres v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 506 P.2d 817, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 144 (Wyo. 1973), appeal dismissed, 414 U.S. 990, 94 S. Ct. 342, 38 L. Ed. 2d 229, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1185 (1973). See § 22-1-102 for definition of “residence.”

§ 22-21-109. Supplies; regulations; costs.

The county clerk may utilize voting machines or electronic voting systems at any bond election and may prescribe the form of the ballot, the duties of election officials, and other reasonable regulations pertaining thereto. The political subdivision holding the bond election shall pay the actual costs of the election or an equitably proportioned share of a concurrent election, as determined by the county clerk.

History:

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-293; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014.

The 2014 amendment, in the first sentence, substituted “the ballot” for “ballot label.”

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

§ 22-21-110. Ballot canvass; results certified; declaration; effect of defeat.

Immediately after the closing of the polls, the counting board shall proceed to count the ballots. The results disclosed by the count shall be certified by the counting board to the clerk of the political subdivision. If the majority of the ballots cast on a bond question is in favor of the issuance of the bonds, the proposal shall be approved, and the governing body of the political subdivision, in the manner provided by law, shall then proceed to declare the results of said election, and complete the printing, execution, advertising, and sale of the bonds, but if the majority is opposed to such issuance, the proposal to issue bonds for the same general purpose shall not again be submitted to election within a period of twelve (12) months or as otherwise provided by law.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-294; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-21-111. Authority granted.

Nothing herein contained shall be construed as authorizing any type of project or the issuance of bonds for any purpose not otherwise authorized by the laws specifically applicable to the political subdivision in question.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-295.

§ 22-21-112. Effect on prior bond elections.

This act [§§ 22-21-101 through 22-27-101] shall have no effect on any bond election heretofore conducted, and any bonds authorized at such an election which have not been delivered may be sold and delivered as if this act had not been adopted.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-296.

Article 2. State

  • § 22-21-201.  State bond elections.

§ 22-21-201. State bond elections.

  1. A statewide bond election may be held on the same days as authorized for bond elections under W.S. 22-21-103. A statewide bond election shall be conducted as nearly as possible in the same manner as a general election.
  2. The proclamation of such an election shall be published as provided in W.S. 22-2-109. No other notice of such election need be published.
  3. Precincts may be consolidated for the purpose of any special election held under this section at the discretion of the county clerk. Three (3) judges shall be appointed for the polling place in such special elections, and additional judges may be appointed if deemed necessary by the county clerk.
  4. The question submitted at such a bond election shall be deemed adopted, if a majority of the electors voting thereon approve the proposition.

History.


Laws 1978, ch. 38, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 22-2-115; Laws 1983, ch. 183, § 2; 1991, ch. 243, § 4; 1996, ch. 97, § 2; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

The 2015 amendment, in the second sentence in (c), deleted “in each precinct” following “polling place.”

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

Editor's notes. —

Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 4, renumbered this section, which was former § 22-2-115, effective July 1, 1991.

Chapter 22 School Elections

  • Article 1. General Provisions
  • Article 2. Nominations
  • Article 3. School or Community College Election Procedure

Article 1. General Provisions

  • § 22-22-101.  Cost of school or community college district elections.
  • § 22-22-102.  Date of election of trustees; terms; interim vacancies.
  • § 22-22-103.  Establishment of election dates by boards of county commissioners.

§ 22-22-101. Cost of school or community college district elections.

The cost of a school or community college district election or equitably proportioned shares of a concurrent election as determined by the county clerk shall be paid by the appropriate board from the funds of the school district or community college district.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-297; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2.

§ 22-22-102. Date of election of trustees; terms; interim vacancies.

  1. The election of members of the board of trustees of each school district and community college district shall be held at the regular polling places for each district on the Tuesday next following the first Monday in November in general election years. Terms of office shall run for four (4) years beginning at 12:00 noon on the first day in December following the election.
  2. Repealed by Laws 1985, ch. 204, § 2.
  3. Not more than a simple majority of members of the board of trustees of each school district and each community college district shall be elected at any election unless the election is to fill an unexpired term.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-298; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1975, ch. 185, §§ 2, 3; 1985, ch. 204, §§ 1, 2; 1987, ch. 222, § 1; 1988, ch. 24, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

The 2015 amendment, substituted “polling places for each district” for “polling places in each district”.

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

Cross references. —

As to filling vacancies in office generally, see §§ 22-18-101 to 22-18-112.

As to initial election of community college district board, see § 21-18-308.

§ 22-22-103. Establishment of election dates by boards of county commissioners.

For school or community college district elections set by boards of county commissioners, in determining the date of an election each county commissioner’s vote shall be weighted in proportion to the number of county commissioners and the population of electors of the district residing within that commissioner’s county. The population of electors shall be determined by the most recent voter registration lists.

History.

Laws 1996, ch. 97, § 1.

Article 2. Nominations

  • § 22-22-201.  Eligibility for office.
  • § 22-22-202.  Filing of application; form.
  • § 22-22-203.  Determining validity of application; placement on ballot; procedure for multi-county districts.

§ 22-22-201. Eligibility for office.

  1. A qualified elector resident in a school district is eligible to hold the office of school district trustee in the school district, but only from the trustee residence area in which he resides if the district is divided into residence areas.
  2. A qualified elector resident in a community college district may be elected to the district board of the community college district, but only from the subdistrict in which he resides if the district is divided into subdistricts.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-299.

Cross references. —

As to elector qualifications, see § 22-3-102.

Section does not purport to eliminate or restrict rule against holding incompatible offices. Haskins v. State, 516 P.2d 1171, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 192 (Wyo. 1973).

Employment as teacher and office as member of board of trustees of school district are incompatible within the meaning and intent of the common-law rule that a person cannot hold incompatible offices or positions. Haskins v. State, 516 P.2d 1171, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 192 (Wyo. 1973).

For person to hold office as trustee while acting as teacher would deprive the citizens of the school district of the independent judgment of a full and impartial board of trustees elected to represent the entire public interest. Haskins v. State, 516 P.2d 1171, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 192 (Wyo. 1973).

A party who obtained office as a member of the school district's board of trustees while a teacher in that district and who sought to retain both positions was precluded by rule of incompatibility which operated to vacate party's office as trustee rather than position as school teacher. Haskins v. State, 516 P.2d 1171, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 192 (Wyo. 1973).

§ 22-22-202. Filing of application; form.

  1. A qualified elector may be nominated for the office of school district trustee or member of a community college board by filing an application for election in the office of the county clerk not more than ninety (90) nor less than seventy (70) days prior to the election. The application shall be in substantially the following form:
  2. Repealed by Laws 1983, ch. 80, § 2.

APPLICATION FOR ELECTION FOR SCHOOL ORCOMMUNITY COLLEGE TRUSTEE I, the undersigned, swear or affirm that I was born on , (year), and that I have been a resident of the State of Wyoming since , and that I am a registered voter of the school district or community college district (and resident of trustee residence area or subdistrict , if any), residing at , and I do hereby request that my name, , be printed on the ballot of the election to be held on the day of , (year), as a candidate for the office of for a term of years. I hereby declare that if I am elected, I will qualify for the office. Dated: (Signature of Candidate) Name as it is to appear on the ballot

Click to view

History:

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-300; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 1979, ch. 133, § 2; 1981, ch. 159, § 1; 1983, ch. 80, § 2; 1988, ch. 24, § 1; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 47, § 1; 2014 ch. 108, § 1, effective March 10, 2014.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

The 2014 amendment, in (a), deleted “ . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . (Residence Address)” from the end of the form.

Laws 2014, ch. 108, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

§ 22-22-203. Determining validity of application; placement on ballot; procedure for multi-county districts.

  1. The county clerk receiving a nomination application shall determine whether the person seeking nomination is a qualified candidate. If the application is sufficient in all respects, the name of the person nominated shall appear on the official ballot for the election specified in the application. In the case of a school or community college district which crosses county boundaries, the clerk of the county in which a valid application is filed shall certify the name of the person nominated to the clerk of the other county or counties involved for placement on the official ballot for the election specified in the application.
  2. Each county clerk in each election involving a school or community college district which crosses county boundaries shall determine whether voting machines, electronic voting system, paper ballots, or a combination thereof, shall be used to insure that each qualified elector votes only for the candidate or candidates from the school district and trustee residence area, if any, and from the community college district and subdistrict, if any, for which he is entitled to vote.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-301; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2.

Article 3. School or Community College Election Procedure

  • § 22-22-301.  “District” defined.
  • § 22-22-302.  Conduct of elections.
  • § 22-22-303.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-22-304.  Ballot information; format.
  • §§ 22-22-305 through 22-22-308.  [Repealed.]

§ 22-22-301. “District” defined.

As used in this article including W.S. 22-22-301 through 22-22-308, inclusive, the term “district” refers to a community college district board or a school district board of trustees.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-302.

Cross references. —

As to partitioning community college district into election subdistricts, see § 21-18-308.

As to community college district annexation elections, see § 21-18-310.

As to community college district formation elections, see § 21-18-312.

§ 22-22-302. Conduct of elections.

Unless specifically otherwise provided, a school or community college district election shall be governed by the laws regulating statewide elections and in even-numbered years be conducted and canvassed by the same election officials, using the same poll lists, and at the same times and polling places, as county elections.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-303.

Cross references. —

For time of county elections, see §§ 22-2-104 and 22-2-105.

§ 22-22-303. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, provided that the county clerk was to provide sufficient supplies to polling places.

§ 22-22-304. Ballot information; format.

  1. The official ballot shall contain the following information:
    1. The name of the school district or community college district;
    2. The county or counties in which the district is located;
    3. The number of offices to be filled, the length of term for each office, and the number and names of candidates for each office for whom each voter is entitled to vote;
    4. In districts divided into trustee residence areas or subdistricts, the trustee residence area or subdistrict of each candidate and the number to be elected from each trustee residence area or subdistrict;
    5. Ballot propositions to be voted on at the election.
  2. Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-306; Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

§§ 22-22-305 through 22-22-308. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

These sections, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, related to certification of results, the breaking of tie votes, and disposition of ballots.

Chapter 23 Municipal Elections

  • Article 1. General Provisions
  • Article 2. Concurrent Elections
  • Article 3. Nominations
  • Article 4. General Municipal Election
  • Article 5. Offices and Terms
  • Article 6. Terms of Office After First Election
  • Article 7. Changing Form of Government
  • Article 8. Special Elections
  • Article 9. Special Elections Following Incorporation
  • Article 10. Initiative and Referendum

Cross references. —

For constitutional provision requiring the consent of the electors with reference to organization of municipalities, see art. 13, § 2, Wyo. Const. See, also, art. 3, § 52, Wyo. Const.

Law reviews. —

For article, “No Home On the Range For Home Rule,” see XXXI Land & Water L. Rev. 791 (1996).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

25 Am. Jur. 2d Elections § 1 et seq.

“At-large” elections as violation of § 2 of Voting Rights Act of 1965 (42 USC § 1973), 92 ALR Fed 824.

29 C.J.S. Elections § 1 et seq.; 62 C.J.S. Municipal Corporations § 350 et seq.

Article 1. General Provisions

  • § 22-23-101.  Laws governing; costs.
  • § 22-23-102.  Qualifications of municipal officers.
  • § 22-23-103.  Division of city into wards; residency.
  • § 22-23-104.  [Repealed.]

§ 22-23-101. Laws governing; costs.

Unless otherwise specifically provided, a municipal election shall be governed by laws regulating statewide elections. The municipality holding any election shall pay the actual costs of the election, or an equitably proportioned share of a concurrent election as determined by the county clerk.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-311; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2.

§ 22-23-102. Qualifications of municipal officers.

All municipal offices are nonpartisan, and municipal officers shall be qualified electors residing in the municipality and any ward established under W.S. 22-23-103 or 15-11-105(b).

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-312; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to qualifications of electors, see § 22-3-102.

Requirement that municipal officers be “resident in the municipality” is clear and unambiguous. Karn v. Hayes, 530 P.2d 156, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 121 (Wyo. 1975).

Dwelling or habitation place within municipal boundaries required.—

One may not be a candidate for municipal office in a city or town without having and maintaining a dwelling or place of habitation physically situated within the municipal boundaries of such city or town. Karn v. Hayes, 530 P.2d 156, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 121 (Wyo. 1975).

Where there was no showing that appellant had a place of fixed habitation within corporate limits of the city to which she had the intention of returning, she had not brought herself within the statutory qualifications to stand for election in that city. Karn v. Hayes, 530 P.2d 156, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 121 (Wyo. 1975).

Candidate's failure to be registered. —

Candidate's failure to be registered to vote at the time of filing her application for nomination was inconsequential and a mere irregularity since shortly thereafter she reregistered and met all criteria during the primary election, the general election, and at the time she assumed the municipal office. Rue v. Carter, 919 P.2d 633, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 110 (Wyo. 1996).

§ 22-23-103. Division of city into wards; residency.

  1. A city may be divided into wards by ordinance of the governing body of the city. The wards shall be compact in form and as nearly equal in population as possible.
  2. Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a person shall not be a candidate for the council from a ward for the purpose of meeting residency requirements for the city ward, unless he has been a resident of that ward for at least one (1) year next preceding his election.
  3. In any general election year in which city wards are redrawn but not enacted into law at least one (1) year prior to the applicable filing periods, a person may be a candidate for a ward if he:
    1. Is a resident of the city on the date he files an application under W.S. 22-5-204 or a petition under W.S. 22-5-301; and
    2. Has been a resident of the city for at least one (1) year next preceding his election.
  4. A person seeking election from a ward as provided under subsection (c) of this section, including a councilman whose term otherwise would expire as a result of completing his term of office, shall be a resident of the ward at the time he takes office.
  5. Following the redrawing of ward boundaries, a councilman whose term of office does not expire following the next general election shall continue to serve until the completion of his term.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-313; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 69, § 1.

§ 22-23-104. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, provided that the provisions of chapter 24 of the Election Code would apply to municipal elections.

Article 2. Concurrent Elections

  • § 22-23-201.  Conduct; who may vote.
  • § 22-23-202.  Optional mode of election for towns; procedures by charter ordinance.
  • § 22-23-203.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-23-204.  Certification and printing of ballot propositions.

§ 22-23-201. Conduct; who may vote.

  1. Except as provided in W.S. 22-23-202 municipal primary and general elections are held at the same time, in the same manner, at the same polling places, and are conducted by the same election officials, using the same poll lists, as the statewide primary and general elections.
  2. Only voters residing in precincts within a municipality may vote in its elections.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-315; Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 2; 2015 ch. 138, § 1, effective March 4, 2015.

Cited in

Karn v. Hayes, 530 P.2d 156, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 121 (Wyo. 1975).

The 2015 amendment, in (a), substituted “election officials” for “precinct officials”.

Laws 2015, ch. 138, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

§ 22-23-202. Optional mode of election for towns; procedures by charter ordinance.

  1. Any municipality may, by charter ordinance enacted pursuant to article 13, section 1(c) of the Wyoming constitution, elect not to conduct its elections for office or for municipal ballot propositions in the same manner as statewide elections, in which case the charter ordinance shall at a minimum provide:
    1. The manner in which notice of elections shall be given;
    2. The procedure by which candidates shall be nominated for office, and by which vacancies in nomination are to be filled;
    3. The date, time and place of the election which shall be held on the Tuesday next following the first Monday in the month of May every two (2) years;
    4. The manner in which precinct officials and a canvassing board shall be appointed;
    5. That the municipal clerk is responsible for:
      1. Determining if a person seeking nomination is a qualified candidate;
      2. Preparing the ballots in substantially the same form as the general election nonpartisan ballot;
      3. Designating polling places;
      4. Otherwise conducting the election.
    6. That the municipality shall bear the expense of the election;
    7. The manner in which election results are certified and persons receiving the highest number of votes are notified.
  2. Those matters not otherwise provided for in a charter ordinance shall be governed by chapters 1 through 21, 23, 25 and 26 of this Election Code.

History.

Laws 1975, ch. 185, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-315.1; 1996, ch. 97, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

§ 22-23-203. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1998, ch. 100, § 5.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1, provided that electors at municipal elections would be subject to challenge.

§ 22-23-204. Certification and printing of ballot propositions.

A municipal ballot proposition to be voted on at a general election shall be certified by the municipal clerk to the county clerk not less than sixty (60) days before the general election and shall be printed on the municipal ballot by the county clerk unless state law provides otherwise.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-22.1-319; Laws 1991, ch. 243, § 2; 1998, ch. 100, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to computing periods of time, see § 22-2-110.

Article 3. Nominations

  • § 22-23-301.  Municipal officers.
  • § 22-23-302.  Filing fee; application form.
  • § 22-23-303.  Certification of candidates; names on ballots.
  • § 22-23-304.  Ballot form.
  • §§ 22-23-305 and 22-23-306.  [Repealed.]
  • § 22-23-307.  Candidates nominated; certificate of nomination.
  • § 22-23-308.  Vacancies in nomination.

§ 22-23-301. Municipal officers.

All candidates for municipal office shall be nominated at the municipal primary election. In order to be eligible, a candidate must be a registered voter and a resident of the municipality and ward which he seeks to represent on the day the petition is filed, and shall not be an employee of the municipality. As used in this section, the term “employee” includes only those persons receiving an hourly wage or salary from a municipality. A person who provides volunteer services to a municipality shall not be considered an “employee” under this section based solely upon coverage under the Wyoming Worker’s Compensation Act or other pension, death or disability program.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 251, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 22.1-320; Laws 1974, ch. 24, § 2; 1997, ch. 173, § 1; 2003, ch. 36, § 1.

Worker's Compensation Act. —

See §§ 27-14-101(a), 27-14-102(a)(xxvii).

Constitutionality of candidacy requirements. —

Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-23-301 does not require a person to resign municipal employment in order to run for municipal office; it only requires that a person resign municipal employment prior to holding municipal office. Thus, the statute is not unconstitutional on the grounds that it creates a class of persons who must resign their employment before seeking election to municipal office. Hayes v. City of Sheridan, 2005 WY 10, 105 P.3d 459, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 2005).

Candidate's failure to be registered. —

Election of a candidate for town council was properly annulled because: (1) the candidate was not a registered voter at the time he filed his petition for candidacy and thus violated Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-23-301 and Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-23-302; and (2) failure to meet this requirement was not a mere irregularity. Smith v. Brito, 2007 WY 191, 173 P.3d 351, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 203 (Wyo. 2007).

§ 22-23-302. Filing fee; application form.

Not more than ninety-six (96) days and not later than eighty-one (81) days preceding the municipal primary election, each candidate for a municipal office shall pay a nonrefundable filing fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and sign and file with the municipal clerk an application in substantially the following form:
